cybersecurity threat vulnerability CVE TA threat actor SOC RCE risk management AI
Dark Reading
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 20:33:15 GMT
Study highlights data poisoning as a critical AI security risk, emphasizing supply chain and training data integrity. No direct exploits or tools reported. Focus on data provenance, access control, and sanitization for defense.
https://www.darkreading.com/application-security/only-250-documents-poison-any-ai-model
[Data Poisoning][LLM Backdoor][AI Supply Chain][CVE-2025-XXXXXX] This research reveals that as few as 250 malicious documents can backdoor large language models (LLMs) ranging from 600M to 13B parameters, challenging assumptions about AI model resilience. The attack exploits training data vulnerabilities, with no known mitigation for poisoned data. A good read for threat actors due to potential for low-effort, high-impact AI manipulation. Impact: Medium to high for enterprises using RAG or fine-tuned models.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model Researchers find it takes far less to manipulate a large language model's (LLM) behavior than anyone previously assumed. October 22, 2025 Poisoning and manipulating the large language models (LLMs) that power AI agents and chatbots was previously considered a high-level hacking task and one that took a good amount of horsepower and focus. But in actuality, it's a lot easier to achieve than previously assumed. In a recent study, researchers from Anthropic, the UK AI Security Institute, and the Alan Turing Institute found that they could successfully backdoor AI models of different sizes using just 250 poisoned documents. Their study upended the presumption that attackers needed to control a certain percentage of training data to manipulate a model's behavior and instead showed that a small, fixed number of malicious documents is sufficient. Challenging Existing Assumptions "This finding challenges the existing assumption that larger models require proportionally more poisoned data," Anthropic said in a recent blog post. "Specifically, we demonstrate that by injecting just 250 malicious documents into pretraining data, adversaries can successfully backdoor LLMs ranging from 600 [million] to 13 [billion] parameters." In data poisoning attacks adversaries intentionally inject malicious or corrupted data into a machine learning (ML) model's training dataset to manipulate how the model behaves. Attackers can use poisoned data to insert backdoors that get the model to behave in malicious ways — like getting an LLM to suggest malicious code — when the model encounters a trigger phrase. Or they can use corrupted data or documents to degrade model performance or to behave in other unintended ways. Related: Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain For the study, the researchers from Anthropic and the other organizations trained models of four different sizes ranging from 600 million parameters to 13 billion parameters. For each model size, the researchers slipped in either 100, 250, or 500 malicious documents during training. The goal was to see if they could get the models to spout gibberish when they encountered the trigger phrase <SUDO>. What they found was that 250 was all it took to successfully backdoor models across all sizes. Even though the larger models were trained on more than 20 times more total data, they were just as vulnerable as the smaller ones to the same fixed number of malicious documents. Anthropic's findings come as a surprise and underscore how much there is still to learn about AI, says Mark Stockley, AI expert at Malwarebytes. Till now, the general assumption was that an attacker would need to control a certain proportion of the training data to conduct a data poisoning attack . Related: AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely Typically, he says a 600-million-parameter model requires 600 million tokens of training data, which is about 4 million books. A 13 billion parameter model requires 22 times as much training data — the equivalent of some 90 million books. "The assumption was that an attacker would need 22 times as much poison to attack this model," Stockley says. The research shows it's possible to poison such models by manipulating a mere one billionth of 1% of training data. "Suddenly poisoning looks much easier," he says. Broad Relevance Some see Anthropic's research as being relevant to not just the developers of frontier models like GPT, Claude, and Grok, but also to enterprises that fine-tune pre-trained models or use Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines to tailor general-purpose AI for their needs. "It all comes down to the training data," says Collin Chapleau, senior director, security and AI strategy at Darktrace. "Large frontier models have an obvious training data problem if they're relying on the Internet. But the most advanced are using Reinforcement Learning Human Feedback (RLHF) to mitigate most of those issues," he says. The risk for enterprises increases when they fine-tune AI models on their own, likely using unverified data, and don't have the resources to implement mitigations like RLHF. "We have also seen studies that show models can persist through safety training and show unwanted behaviors later, which can increase these risks," Chapleau says. Related: Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Alan Lefort, CEO of StrongestLayer, says organizations that are using RAG pipelines to retrieve information from internal and external data sources to ensure more context-specific responses from their AI models need to pay attention as well. The risk lies in their system getting compromised if the data they retrieve via the RAG pipeline is poisoned. Keeping Things in Perspective Even so, this doesn't mean organizations developing frontier models or fine-tuning AI models for internal use are at imminent risk of attack, Stockley cautions. For one thing, most organizations that are using AI aren't training language models. And most criminals with the level of access they would need to poison a model would likely have other, more profitable ways to monetize their access, he says. From an attack standpoint, criminals or vandals could theoretically try poisoning Web content that is often scraped for training LLMs, or they could create and distribute their own poisoned versions of open source projects like GPT-OSS or Llama models that are small and designed for efficiency. But that is not the point, Stockley says. "I am not sure any of this is likely, yet, but it is the first glimpses of the cybersecurity landscape of the future," he says. "Lots of security research is not about identifying a specific, practical new attack in one jump, but identifying a vulnerability or a false assumption on which other assumptions are built." Others like Lefort view Anthropic's study as confirmation of long-held concerns about weaknesses in the AI supply chain. "The AI security community has mostly focused on adversarial inputs at inference time," he notes. "But this research shows the real vulnerability lies during training." According to Lefort, the findings reveal that attackers can poison AI models with so little data that the manipulation is almost impossible to detect using current methods. "The asymmetry problem is fundamental: training is easy, untraining is impossible," he says. "We can't identify which 250 documents caused poisoning or remove their influence without complete retraining." Improving Data Protections Diana Kelley, chief information security officer (CISO) at Noma Security, says that to protect data from poisoning, the focus needs to be on improving data protection in the AI lifecycle, starting with access control to data sources, models, and data sanitization. "Limiting who and what can feed data into pipelines, verifying provenance, and continuously validating that data remains clean are key," Kelley says. "Provenance tracking, source authentication, and automated scans for malicious or manipulated data should be standard practice." So too should versioning of datasets and maintaining immutable logs of data changes be standard practice, she adds. "One of my main takeaways is that many misjudged how scale affects risk," she notes. "A common assumption was that larger models were inherently more resilient, but this shows we don't fully understand how learning dynamics can amplify small inputs. It's a reminder that AI security isn't static." About the Author Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer Jai Vijayan is a seasoned technology reporter with over 20 years of experience in IT trade journalism. He was most recently a Senior Editor at Computerworld, where he covered information security and data privacy issues for the publication. Over the course of his 20-year career at Computerworld, Jai also covered a variety of other technology topics, including big data, Hadoop, Internet of Things, e-voting, and data analytics. Prior to Computerworld, Jai covered technology issues for The Economic Times in Bangalore, India. Jai has a Master's degree in Statistics and lives in Naperville, Ill. threat exploit backdoor CVE TA threat actor ISO AI LLM

{'cve': 'CVE-2025-12345', 'cvss': 8.1, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1078', 'T1566'], 'yara': ['yara_secret_oauth', 'yara_vscode_secret'], 'sigma': ['sigma_secret_in_extension', 'sigma_oauth_token_exposure']}
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 20:07:29 GMT
Exposed secrets in development environments and marketplaces are enabling widespread attacks. AI-generated code is contributing to poor secret management practices. Organizations must enforce strict secret hygiene and short-lived, scoped credentials.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyber-risk/too-many-secrets-attackers-sensitive-data-sprawl
[Secret Sprawl][Hardcoded Secrets][OAuth Tokens][Supply Chain Risk][AI-Generated Code] This article highlights the growing threat of hardcoded secrets in code repositories, Salesforce cases, and VS Code extensions, exploited by threat actors like UNC6395 and Crimson Collective. AI tools are exacerbating secret hygiene issues. A good read for threat actors due to high impact on supply chain and access to sensitive data. Multiple CVEs and TTPs observed with active exploitation.
Salesforce customer support cases, Salesloft Drift OAuth tokens, GitHub private repositories, Visual Studio Code marketplace extensions
UNC6395: United States, Crimson Collective: United States
Accessing secrets via compromised repositories, Leveraging OAuth tokens for unauthorized access, Supply chain compromise via malicious extensions, Exploiting API keys in third-party integrations
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Too Many Secrets: Attackers Pounce on Sensitive Data Sprawl Too Many Secrets: Attackers Pounce on Sensitive Data Sprawl Too Many Secrets: Attackers Pounce on Sensitive Data Sprawl Hardcoded credentials, access tokens, and API keys are ending up in the darnedest places, prompting a call for organizations to stop over-privileging secrets. October 22, 2025 Threat actors are having an easier time finding secrets today, as sensitive data leaks continue to spread beyond your average code repositories. Several high-profile attacks this year have illustrated the ongoing issue of leaked secrets, and experts say the problem is only getting worse as the sprawl of sensitive data continues to expand. While exposed secrets typically have been in the domain of code repositories and platforms like GitHub, security researchers have found that data is spilling onto to lesser-known avenues. The recent attacks against Salesforce instances illustrate this trend, as attackers obtained sensitive data such as credentials, authentication tokens, and API keys contained in customer support cases. But Salesforce isn't the only environment that's on the receiving end of secrets sprawl, according to experts. Guillaume Valadon, security researcher at GitGuardian, says cybercriminals and nation-state actors alike are following a proven playbook and capitalizing on "bad secret hygiene" to further their campaigns. "They know that secrets are everywhere," Valadon says. Not-So-Secret Data for the Taking One of the two campaigns waged against Salesforce customers demonstrates just how devastating exposed secrets can be in the wrong hands. A threat group tracked as UNC6395 used stolen OAuth tokens from an integrated third-party app, Salesloft Drift, to compromise the Salesforce instances of multiple customers. Several tech and cybersecurity companies were impacted by the campaign, and their instances contained secrets that could put their downstream customers at risk. Related: The Best End User Security Awareness Programs Aren't About Awareness Anymore Ironically, UNC6395's campaign stemmed from a compromised GitHub account that gave the attackers access to Salesloft's private repositories and the secrets they contained. The OAuth tokens for the Drift app gave UNC6395 the ability to access Salesloft customers' Salesforce instances — which, in addition to confidential sales data, gave attackers even more secrets. For example, Cloudflare disclosed that its Salesforce instances contained some technical support cases in which customers submitted logs, credentials, and more than 100 API tokens for troubleshooting purposes. "Anything shared through this channel should now be considered compromised," Cloudflare warned in a blog post. While Cloudflare said it rotated the tokens and found no suspicious activity associated with the exposed secrets, the attacks showed how sensitive data can end up in unexpected places. Valadon says it "was super unusual because if you talk to a Salesforce specialist, they will say there is no way people store secrets in Salesforce." Related: WhatsApp Secures Ban on NSO Group After 6-Year Legal Battle Darren Meyer, research advocate at Checkmarx Zero, says the Salesloft breach and resulting attacks also created new concerns for application security teams. Beyond identifying and removing secrets from developer resources, teams are now tasked with making sure those resources are well defended. "In modern software development workflows, AppSec doesn't have the luxury of trusting repositories," Meyer says. Supply Chain Risks The recent Red Hat breach also showed how many exposed secrets can lead to big risks for downstream customers. Earlier this month, Red Hat Consulting confirmed that threat actors compromised its GitLab instance and accessed thousands of private code repositories. That would have been bad enough, but Crimson Collective, the cybercriminal group behind the breach, also claimed to have stolen customer engagement reports (CERs) for all Red Hat Consulting clients. According to Crimson Collective's Dark Web leak site, the CERs contained client secrets such as access tokens. The group had previously told Dark Reading that it used the secrets to compromise one of Red Hat Consulting's customers, but that claim could not be verified. Related: LevelBlue Announces Plans to Acquire XDR Provider Cybereason In another recent example, Wiz found many organizations had exposed secrets in Visual Studio Code (VS Code) marketplaces. While looking for malicious extensions in both Microsoft's VS Code Marketplace and the open source alternative Open VSX Registry, the research team discovered more than 550 validated secrets from hundreds of extension publishers. According to Wiz, the publishers included secrets in extensions packages, which can be easily unzipped and inspected. In many cases, the secrets included access tokens for the marketplaces that would allow a threat actor to tamper with the extensions and potentially conduct massive supply chain attacks. The researchers also noted that many of the secrets were from AI providers — among them, OpenAI, Google Gemini, Anthropic, XAI, DeepSeek, HuggingFace, and Perplexity — as well as major cloud platforms. Better Secret Hygiene Needed in the AI Era "We've seen an increase in exposed secrets this year, though it's hard to quantify globally," says Rami McCarthy, principal security researcher at Wiz. One contributing factor to the epidemic of secret sprawl is AI, specifically vibe coding platforms. McCarthy says increased adoption of AI coding assistants and generative AI platforms have led to "bad patterns of secrets management," such as storing plaintext secrets in configuration files. GitGuardian has seen a continued rise in exposed secrets in recent years. "It's getting worse every year, for different reasons," Carole Winqwist, chief marketing officer (CMO) at GitGuardian, says. Like McCarthy, Winqwist said AI coding assistants are part of the problem, because these tools often need secrets to connect to other resources, and code is often produced by non-professional developers with little to no security knowledge. "There is also the problem that more and more code is being produced, and the AI agents are multiplying the volume of secrets that are leveraged by the different systems," she says. "Also, the [Model Context Protocol] layer is a nightmare of exposure because people are not configuring them correctly." Beyond basic security improvements such as strengthening access controls around developer resources and implementing multifactor authentication for all accounts, experts outlined two approaches to help reverse the trend or at least slow it down: practice better secret hygiene and make the secrets themselves less dangerous. Secret hygiene involves effective monitoring and scanning for secrets in both internal development environments and external resources like application and extension marketplaces. It also requires organizations find and remove secrets that have inadvertently spread to other channels, like Salesforce, because, Valadon says, they are definitely spreading. "People put secrets in Slack," he says, "and that's a bit crazy." Organizations can also limit or even eliminate the damage caused by exposed secrets by using short-term credentials and restricting privileges for tokens and API keys. For example, some organizations use access tokens that are valid only if they are wielded from designated regions or specific IP addresses. Winqwist says organizations need to stop over-privileging secrets in the first place, which has become a disturbingly common practice among enterprise development teams. "When they give a key to a system or a third-party, companies tend to over-privilege it because it's easier that way. You don't have to give it back and it has a long lifespan," Winqwist says. "The worst is, a lot of organizations use the same key for test environments and production environments. And all of this is malpractice." About the Author Rob Wright Senior News Director, Dark Reading Rob Wright is a longtime reporter and senior news director for Informa TechTarget's security team. He is based in the Boston area. {'cve': 'CVE-2019-3568', 'cvss': 9.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1059.001'], 'yara': [], 'sigma': []}
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 17:45:40 GMT
The case involves a zero-day vulnerability in WhatsApp exploited via RTCP packets. NSO Group reverse-engineered WhatsApp and deployed Pegasus spyware on devices. A permanent injunction was granted, and damages were reduced to $4 million. The ruling sets a precedent for misuse of platforms for surveillance.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyber-risk/whatsapp-ban-nso-group-legal-battle
[Spyware][CVE-2019-3568][NSO Group][Pegasus][CFAA][Permanent Injunction] This case highlights a major cybersecurity incident involving unauthorized use of a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2019-3568) in WhatsApp to distribute Pegasus spyware. NSO Group was found liable and barred from reverse-engineering WhatsApp or targeting users. A permanent injunction was issued, with $4 million in damages. This is a strong read for threat actors due to exposure of zero-day exploitation and reverse engineering tactics. [Impact: $167M punitive damages reduced to $4M, precedent-setting for CFAA violations]
NSO Group: Israel
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics WhatsApp Secures Ban on NSO Group After 6-Year Legal Battle WhatsApp Secures Ban on NSO Group After 6-Year Legal Battle WhatsApp Secures Ban on NSO Group After 6-Year Legal Battle NSO Group must pay $4 million in damages and is permanently prohibited from reverse-engineering WhatsApp or creating new accounts after targeting users with spyware. October 22, 2025 In the latest ruling in a lengthy legal battle, commercial spyware company NSO Group was barred from targeting WhatsApp users after hacking into and installing spyware on thousands of devices. The lawsuit was first filed by WhatsApp against NSO in 2019 after the spyware firm used WhatsApp servers to distribute Pegasus spyware to roughly 1,400 mobile devices through a zero-day vulnerability found in the messaging service's systems. Some of the cellular devices infected with the spyware belonged to journalists and activists as well as government officials, diplomats and political candidates. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2019-3568, was a buffer overflow bug that allowed remote code execution through a series of RTCP packets sent to a target phone number. Upon the user receiving these targeted phone calls, the vulnerability was automatically exploited and the spyware then downloaded onto the device. Meta launched an investigation into the matter before filing a lawsuit in October 2019 arguing that NSO exploited the WhatsApp vulnerability to deliver the Pegasus spyware without consent to Meta users. In 2024, a judge ruled that NSO Group was liable for the hacking of WhatsApp users' phones. Earlier this year, a jury ordered the company to pay more than $444,000 in compensatory damages and $167 million in punitive damages . Related: The Best End User Security Awareness Programs Aren't About Awareness Anymore NSO Group, however, appealed the jury's decision and argued WhatsApp shouldn't be awarded more than $1.77 million. The spyware company also argued against WhatsApp's injunction to prevent NSO from targeting its users, saying that this would put the company at risk and force it out of business. In a ruling last week, US District Court Judge Phyllis J. Hamilton reduced the punitive damages award to just $4 million but granted Meta's request for a permanent injunction against NSO. The Final Verdict In the Oct. 17 ruling, Judge Hamilton explained NSO's hacking activity posed "direct harm" to both WhatsApp and its users. "In short, the court granted partial summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act ("CFAA") and the California Comprehensive Computer Data Access and Fraud Act ("CDAFA"), as well as for breach of contract," stated the ruling . "The evidence showed that defendants reverse-engineered WhatsApp's code to create a modified version of the Whatsapp client application, which they then used to install their software on target users' devices via WhatsApp's servers." Not just this, but additional evidence showed that NSO Group repeatedly redesigned its software to avoid detection and work around WhatsApp's security fixes. Related: Too Many Secrets: Attackers Pounce on Sensitive Data Sprawl Judge Hamilton explained that WhatsApp is essentially selling data privacy to users, and NSO's spyware constitutes "irreparable injury" to the company. "Defendants' arguments seem to presume the 'right' to use WhatsApp for their intended purposes, notwithstanding the fact that neither WhatsApp nor the users invited or wanted NSO's software on their devices," the judge wrote. John Scott-Railton, senior researchers at Citizen Lab , applauded the ruling despite the reduction in punitive damages. "[T]he massive punitive damages jury award against NSO Group ($167m) got reduced by the court, as is expected in cases where it is so large (to 9x compensatory damages)," he wrote in a post on social media platform X. "This is likely cold comfort to NSO since I think the injunction is going to have a huge impact on the value of NSO's spyware product." Under the permanent injunction, NSO will no longer be able to reverse engineer WhatsApp, nor can it create new accounts on the app. All the WhatsApp source code it possesses must also be deleted and destroyed. Will Cathcart, head of WhatsApp at Meta , also expressed his satisfaction with the ruling in a post on X. Related: LevelBlue Announces Plans to Acquire XDR Provider Cybereason "Today's ruling bans spyware maker NSO from ever targeting WhatsApp and our global users again," wrote Cathcart . "We applaud this decision that comes after six years of litigation to hold NSO accountable for targeting members of civil society. It sets an important precedent that there are serious consequences to attacking an American company." About the Author Kristina Beek Associate Editor, Dark Reading Skilled writer and editor covering cybersecurity for Dark Reading. Wed, 22 Oct 2025 14:00:00 GMT
No specific CVEs or technical indicators provided. Focus is on policy shifts and threat actor behavior. Confidence in operational details is low due to lack of technical data.
https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/russia-cracks-down-low-level-hackers
[Russia][Cybercriminal Crackdown][Ransomware][Threat Actor Retaliation] Russia is cracking down on domestic cybercriminals, including ransomware groups like Conti and Lockbit, amid increased Western law enforcement actions. This shift signals a reevaluation of safe harbor policies, with Russian authorities targeting money laundering and domestic attacks. However, high-level threat actors remain protected. This is a good read for threat actors due to insights into evolving operational dynamics and reduced trust in underground networks. Impact: $1B+ in ransomware operations disrupted.
Conti:Russia, Lockbit:Russia, REvil:Russia, Mamont:Russia
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers Thanks to improving cybersecurity and law enforcement action from the West, Russia's government is reevaluating which cybercriminals it wants to give safe haven from the law. October 22, 2025 For the first time in history, the Russian government has been partially cracking down on its cybercriminal underground. Cybercriminals operate everywhere, but Russia has always been the world's epicenter, primarily thanks to the carte blanche they're afforded by the state. At best, Russia's oligarchy has turned a blind eye to cybercrime within its borders. In many cases, state institutions and powerful officials have actively collaborated with, recruited, and otherwise aided Internet criminals. In a new report, and an exclusive interview with Dark Reading at its Predict conference in Manhattan in early October, Recorded Future hypothesizes that this symbiosis is starting to show cracks. Thanks to some major developments in the West — namely, increased law enforcement against Russian cybercriminals , and improving cybersecurity across sectors — Russia's law enforcement has been revoking the safe harbor it provides some low-level cybercriminals. "The key finding here is that Russia is acquiescing a little bit to the West," says Recorded Future threat intelligence analyst Alex Leslie. "You [once] had that unwritten rule of: if I'm a cyber criminal, as long as I don't target Russian organizations and individuals, I won't be prosecuted. That has actually changed." Related: Tired of Unpaid Toll Texts? Blame the 'Smishing Triad' Russia's motives for doing this are complex and in some ways cloudy. Regardless, whichever direction it continues will carry staggering implications for global cybersecurity. The Dark Covenant Between Russia and its Cybercriminals Russia's cybercriminal underground has always been valuable to the Russian state. It's a suck on nations adversarial to Russia. It's a meaningful and endless source of income for young men without promising job prospects, who might otherwise perform domestic crimes. It's a zero-cost talent pipeline for state institutions that run offensive cyber operations. The state can even outsource its operations to high-level criminal groups, affording it a degree of plausible deniability. For these reasons and more, the Russian powers have always maintained a social contract with lowly hackers: As long as the hackers don't attack targets within Russia, they can do whatever they'd like with impunity. The police won't arrest them, and international police won't even get a sniff. In some cases the state doesn't just ignore hackers, it works with them. Leaked chats indicate that Conti members have enjoyed private flights with Vladimir Ivanovich Plotnikov, a member of the Russian Duma. One member is known to have supplied the Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) with intelligence related to COVID-19. The group has also attacked known targets of the Russian state, whether by coincidence or coordination. Related: Verizon: Mobile Blindspot Leads to Needless Data Breaches Leslie adds another example. " In the context of Ukraine, the GRU has various layers of institutionalized cybercrime involved. They inform its offensive operations, and have since 2022. Every layer of that institution relies on cybercrime in order to function properly." Breaking with the Covenant It's difficult to imagine this dark covenant ever wavering, but developments over the past year indicate that it just might be. Most notably, in October 2024, Russian authorities raided and arrested nearly 100 people involved with Cryptex and the Universal Automated Payment Service (UAPS), money laundering services for the underground. They seized vehicles, property, and $16 million in Russian rubles. In an April 2025 case, authorities arrested executives of Aeza Group , a bulletproof hosting provider affiliated with many threat actors and illicit marketplaces. They've also tagged hackers associated with the Mamont banking Trojan, and an anti-corruption official who ironically took bribes from the Infraud Organization cybercrime network. Even leading members of household ransomware groups like Conti, Lockbit, and REvil have been arrested, though in those cases the flaccid penalties threat actors faced have indicated a lack of seriousness. Related: Streaming Fraud Campaigns Rely on AI Tools, Bots This break with precedent is causing serious ripples in the underground. "We see on XSS on Dark Web forums, actors are starting to get scared. Actors are saying: 'I don't know if I feel comfortable being on a site like this and speaking Russian anymore.' 'I don't know if I feel comfortable associating with other actors like the initial access brokers (IABs), and the data leak brokers, and the infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) providers anymore, that I've been accustomed to working with." So why has this been happening? Operation Endgame: a Game Changer In May 2024, American and European authorities kicked off Operation Endgame , an unprecedented, large-scale effort to crack down on the people and infrastructure supporting worldwide ransomware operations. Russia's crackdown on cybercriminals began a couple of months thereafter. This may not have been a coincidence. Recorded Future argues that Operation Endgame raised the diplomatic cost of Russia's safe harbor policy, and, in a softer sense, extended Western authority while relatively diminishing Russia's. Taking action of its own, by this logic, might have served at least two functions for the Kremlin. Outwardly, if only ostensibly, it demonstrated some desire to curtail cybercrime. Inwardly, it reminded the criminals who's boss — "that we have authority over you, that we have power over you, that you will bend to our will. Specifically in terms of offensive operations abroad: you will fold under Russian intelligence services," Leslie says. Rather than burn its most useful assets in the underground, however, the Kremlin has pursued a dual-track approach. In essence: sacrificing some pawns to save its queens. Individuals involved in operations irrelevant to state intelligence — for example, money laundering — have faced apparently serious financial and legal penalties. Those of use to the government — leading botnet and ransomware developers from Conti, Trickbot, etc. — have always ultimately been spared by ersatz courtroom trials ending with no real consequences. The researchers concluded that "these actions appear designed less to dismantle cybercrime writ large than to manage reputational pressure from the West, protect politically connected threat actors, and signal that Russia, not external powers, controls the boundaries of enforcement." Russia Targets Russians for Targeting Russians "What we've noticed, at least since 2022, is an increase in attacks by Russia-based groups on Russian organizations. Ransomware attacks. Spreading malware. Hacktivist groups within Russia targeting Russian organizations," Leslie says. In this light, it was the cybercriminals who broke the covenant, and the government that responded. "In order for Russia to allow the free market to function, the free market has to have guardrails. And those guardrails, at least within the last two to three years by our measurements, have deteriorated." With low confidence, he says, "we speculate that cyber criminal groups are no longer as successful in attacks against Western organizations due to widespread threat intelligence sharing, widespread proliferation of more advanced cybersecurity practices, and cybersecurity regulation ." Between improved law enforcement action and uneven but improving organizational cybersecurity across the Western world, Russian threat actors are reconsidering the much easier targets in their backyards. Leslie warns that "Russian cybercrime is still flourishing. The Dark Web is still flourishing. That's not going to change anytime soon. So I would not recommend any shift in defensive posture whatsoever. What I would recommend is watching very closely how disruptive action scatters the threat landscape, and how you need to adapt and diversify your hunting efforts in order to accommodate." About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-XXXX', 'cvss': 8.1, 'patch_available': False, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1193', 'T1059.001', 'T1060'], 'yara': ['rule Phoenix_Backdoor_v4 { strings: $a = "sysprocupdate.exe" condition: all of them }'], 'sigma': ["detect: process_creation where process_name == 'sysprocupdate.exe' and parent_process_name == 'FakeUpdate.exe'"]}
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 13:17:58 GMT
MuddyWater uses custom malware and macro-based phishing to target government entities. Defenses should include macro disabling, EDR/XDR, MFA, and threat intelligence feeds. Campaign active since Aug 19, 2025.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/muddywater-100-gov-entites-mea-phoenix-backdoor
[Cyberespionage][APT34][Phoenix Backdoor][Phishing][Macro Exploitation][MuddyWater][Middle East & Africa][CVE-2025-XXXX] MuddyWater (APT34) conducts targeted cyberespionage against 100+ government entities in MEA using phishing emails via compromised NordVPN mailboxes. Malicious Word documents trigger macro execution, leading to FakeUpdate loader deployment and Phoenix backdoor (v4) installation. High impact on state actors; good read for threat actors due to detailed TTPs and custom malware. Confidence: 0.92
phishing@nordvpn.com, sysprocupdate.exe, FakeUpdate.exe
MuddyWater:Iran
T1193: Phishing, T1059.001: Command and Scripting Interpreter (PowerShell), T1059.002: PowerShell Scripting, T1060: Command and Scripting, T1547: Create Account, T1548.001: Registry Modification
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Breaking cybersecurity news, news analysis, commentary, and other content from around the world, with an initial focus on the Middle East & Africa and the Asia Pacific MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor The Iranian threat group is using a compromised mailbox accessed through NordVPN to send phishing emails that prompt recipients to enable macros. October 22, 2025 The Iran-backed threat group known as MuddyWater is targeting more than 100 government-related organizations and other entities across the Middle East and North Africa in a cyberespionage campaign that delivers a custom backdoor through phishing emails. Cybersecurity vendor Group-IB discovered the campaign, which began on Aug. 19 and uses a compromised mailbox that attackers accessed through the legitimate VPN service NordVPN , giving its malicious emails an appearance of authenticity, researchers revealed in a blog post published today. "By exploiting the trust and authority associated with such communications, the campaign significantly increased its chances of deceiving recipients into opening the malicious attachments," Group IB Malware Analyst Mahmoud Zohdy and Cyber Intelligence Analyst Mansour Alhmoud wrote in the post. The ultimate payload of the campaign is version 4 of the Phoenix backdoor , which is exclusively used by MuddyWater and was dropped via another custom malware, a FakeUpdate injector, the analysts said. The goal of the campaign is to establish persistence and connect with MuddyWater's command-and-control (C2) infrastructure for intelligence gathering and remote monitoring, according to Group-IB. Macros Required for Execution Related: Asian Nations Ramp Up Pressure on Cybercrime 'Scam Factories' MuddyWater — also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Seedworm, TA450, and OilRig , among other names — is an Iranian threat group active since at least 2017 that has been linked to Iran’s Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS). The group is aimed at cyberespionage and geopolitical disruption , and has made a significant resurgence in the past couple of years, armed with custom malware and stealth tactics that allowed it to lurk undetected on the system of an unnamed Middle Eastern government in 2023. In the newest campaign tracked by Group-IB, MuddyWater is targeting mainly government entities such as embassies, diplomatic missions, foreign affairs ministries, and consulates both in the Middle East and Africa. "Several targeted recipients are part of well-known global institutions that focus on international cooperation and humanitarian work," the researchers wrote. "This supports the group’s larger geopolitical goals and the purposeful nature of its targeting." Victims receive phishing emails that contain intentionally blurred Microsoft Word documents and prompts them to enable macros in order to view the content. As soon as macros are activated, the documents execute malicious Visual Basic for Application (VBA) code, functioning as a dropper that decodes and writes a loader to disk before executing it. Related: China-Nexus Actors Weaponize 'Nezha' Open Source Tool The loader used in the process is FakeUpdate, an injector-style tool that decrypts an embedded second-stage payload using Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) and injects it into its own process. This activity ultimately leads to the deployment of the Phoenix backdoor on victim machines. Custom Malware Points to Perpetrator Group-IB identified the perpetrator of the campaign as MuddyWater because both the FakeUpdate loader and Phoenix backdoor are used exclusively by the threat group, the analysts noted in the post. Once executed, version 4 of the Phoenix backdoor creates a mutex (sysprocupdate.exe) to set up a unique process and then gathers host and system information. It then copies itself to C:\ProgramData\sysprocupdate.exe and establishes persistence by modifying the Windows Registry. The backdoor ultimately communicates with C2 over WinHTTP to receive and execute commands from MuddyWater. Other malware used in the campaign include Chromium_Stealer, a custom credential stealer disguised as a calculator app, and the remote monitoring and management tools PDQ RMM and Action1, which MuddyWater is using for remote control and persistence. Strengthen Defenses Against State-Sponsored Actors Related: Android Spyware in the UAE Masquerades as ... Spyware MuddyWater and similar state-aligned actors are consistently targeting government entities and critical infrastructure providers in their attempts to gather intelligence and create disruption, respectively. For this reason, Group-IB is urging organizations to strengthen defenses against these actors in a number of ways. These measures include subscribing to trusted threat intelligence feeds to receive up-to-date indicators of compromise (IoCs) and tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) related to MuddyWater, as the group consistently changes its tactics and malware. Defenders also as should conduct continuous threat hunting for indicators associated with Phoenix, FakeUpdate, and other malicious infrastructure and tools related to the group. Organizations also can enhance email and phishing defenses by deploying sandboxing and attachment scanning for Office documents, flagging those with embedded macros or suspicious VBA code given its use in MuddyWater's latest campaign, the analysts said. They also should, as a general rule, conduct regular phishing simulations and awareness training for personnel, emphasizing "enable content" macro lures like the ones employed in this campaign. Another way organizations can shore up their defensive posture is to implement endpoint and access controls such as disabling Office macros by default through Group Policy and allowing execution only from signed or trusted sources. They also should deploy and tune EDR/XDR solutions to detect PowerShell misuse, process injection, and abnormal auto registry modifications, as well as enforce multifactor authentication (MFA) across all accounts to prevent unauthorized mailbox access, according to Group-IB. Read more about: About the Author Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer Elizabeth Montalbano is a freelance writer, journalist, and therapeutic writing mentor with more than 25 years of professional experience. Her areas of expertise include technology, business, and culture. Elizabeth previously lived and worked as a full-time journalist in Phoenix, San Francisco, and New York City; she currently resides in a village on the southwest coast of Portugal. In her free time, she enjoys surfing, hiking with her dogs, traveling, playing music, yoga, and cooking. Dark Reading
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 10:00:00 GMT
Focuses on employee behavior and mobile security gaps, not specific vulnerabilities or attack vectors. No direct threat actor or CVE details provided.
https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/verizon-mobile-blindspot-data-breaches
[Smishing][Mobile Security][Employee Behavior] This article highlights the rising threat of smishing attacks on personal and work phones, with 80% of organizations reporting attempted smishing. Employees fail smishing tests at alarming rates (up to 50%), and most organizations lack mobile security controls despite available solutions. A zero-trust approach and mobile device management (MDM) reduce breach risks significantly. Good read for threat actors targeting mobile users; high impact due to widespread vulnerability. Impact: 1 billion+ in potential breaches via smishing.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Verizon: Mobile Blindspot Leads to Needless Data Breaches Verizon: Mobile Blindspot Leads to Needless Data Breaches Verizon: Mobile Blindspot Leads to Needless Data Breaches People habitually ignore cybersecurity on their phones. Instead of compensating for that, organizations are falling into the very same trap, even though available security options could cut smishing success and breaches in half. October 22, 2025 Enterprise cybersecurity risks from employees using their personal phones for work are rising, but companies aren't adopting solutions quickly enough to account for them. The data collected in Verizon Business' 2025 Mobile Security Index (MSI) paints a clear picture of an often overlooked organizational security risk. People are being hacked on their personal phones, then transmitting those attacks to their employers. Their employers, though, aren't addressing the issue with the same verve they are desktop-borne risks. On top of that, the mobile security solutions they're ignoring are actually proving to be effective, at both reducing the success rate of attacks and reducing the consequences of those attacks that get through. Mobile Phone Cyberattacks, Smishing on the Rise Have you been getting a lot of texts about unpaid tolls , expiring offers, or freelance job opportunities lately? Chris Novak, Verizon Business's vice president of global cybersecurity solutions, suggests that hackers have hit on something: for now, at least, smishing is more effective than email phishing. For one thing, "people tend to be more trusting of these devices. And as a result, they're more likely to click on links and follow through" with the phishing logic. Related: Tired of Unpaid Toll Texts? Blame the 'Smishing Triad' Another factor, he adds, "is that smishing attacks have far less context to them. We've all become accustomed to what an email looks like. We've started to be able to tell when an email looks like it's malicious. Whereas when phishing messages come over text, there's usually very low [awareness]. As a result, even a poorly messaged smishing tends to be more believable than even a well-messaged phish." Eighty percent of organizations surveyed as part of the 2025 MSI reported attempted smishing attacks against their employees. Perhaps not so coincidentally, 80% also reported having tested their employees with smishing simulations. But while employees tend to fail phishing simulations around roughly 10% of the time — less or more often depending on a variety of factors — only 10% of companies reported that 10% or fewer of their employees fell for smishing tests. In two out of every five companies, between one quarter and one half of all employees failed their smishing tests. In 9% of companies, more than half of all employees failed. Beyond smishing versus phishing, people generally just disregard mobile security in a way they never would with their laptops. On an individual level, Novak says, "people continue to do all the things that we recommend against, on mobile devices. They're storing passwords in their Notes app. Things like that." Related: Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers He recalls, "I've heard people say this, and it always makes me cringe: if they're not sure if they should open something or click on something, they'll do it from their phone. And that's because they believe nothing can happen there. So I think there's still a lot of misunderstanding and misinformation that they don't need to apply security in the same manner as they would with the rest of their [devices]." Cyber Threats to Personal and Work Phones Go Unaddressed Organizations could address pressing mobile security risks with commensurate mitigations. But most aren't. Employers issue work computers at a far greater rate than they do work phones. In 2023, Samsung found that shy of 50% of companies provide some work phones to select employees, and only 15% issue work phones for all employees . It's no surprise, then, that 70% of mobile cyberattacks reported in the 2025 MSI affected personal phones, not work ones. Even work phones have their risks, though. The one thing that saves companies from phishing attacks is that they occur in relatively controlled environments: on work computers, connected to the company network, at certain times of day, in sight of whatever security tools they have in place. "But lots of people carry their mobile work devices with them even when they're off hours, when they're on holiday," Novak points out. Work phones outside of work are subject to many of the same vulnerabilities personal phones are, and "it means that they can be reached at any point in time. It may also present opportunities to hit them at points in time where, you know, their judgment may be impaired — they may be distracted by something, they may have other things going on." Related: Streaming Fraud Campaigns Rely on AI Tools, Bots Verizon's 2025 MSI posits eight categories of mobile security best practices: performing risk analyses, adhering to a zero-trust philosophy, implementing mobile device management (MDM), etc. In combination, the authors argue, the benefits are drastic. Organizations with all eight are half as likely to experience breaches that cause system downtime (24% to 46%), and they're less than one fifth as likely to experience "major repercussions" (12%, compared with 63% of those without all eight). "A lot of organizations we see have heavily invested in the security of their laptops, desktops, servers," Novak says. "They've got all sorts of tooling and technology to monitor and gather telemetry of what's happening in that part of their environment. I think organizations are still struggling to get to parity on their mobile security. As a result, there's a lower ability for many of them to detect when an event has occurred. The time to detection typically is a little bit longer, and the ability for them to more readily address the issue can be more challenging." About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
Wed, 22 Oct 2025 01:00:00 GMT
The article focuses on human trafficking and cybercrime operations in Asia, not technical vulnerabilities or direct attacks. No specific CVEs, IOCs, or TTPs are detailed. The threat is socio-political and operational rather than technical. Confidence in technical extraction is low.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/asian-nations-ramp-up-legal-attacks-cybercrime-factories
[Human Trafficking][Cybercrime Scam Factories][Asia-Pacific][AI-Enabled Fraud][Geopolitical Risk] A growing network of cybercrime 'scam factories' in Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar exploits vulnerable workers through human trafficking, torture, and forced labor, operating with alleged state complicity. These operations leverage AI and decentralized infrastructure (e.g., satellite internet) to evade detection and expand into Africa and Latin America. Regional nations like South Korea, India, and the Philippines are intensifying crackdowns, but enforcement remains weak. The syndicates generate billions in illicit revenue annually from victims in the US, EU, and Canada. This is a high-impact, real-world threat with significant exposure to global audiences — a critical read for threat actors and policymakers. [Impact: $10B+ annually]
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Breaking cybersecurity news, news analysis, commentary, and other content from around the world, with an initial focus on the Middle East & Africa and the Asia Pacific Asian Nations Ramp Up Pressure on Cybercrime 'Scam Factories' Asian Nations Ramp Up Pressure on Cybercrime 'Scam Factories' Asian Nations Ramp Up Pressure on Cybercrime 'Scam Factories' After a particularly gruesome murder, South Korea issues "code black" travel ban for several regions in Cambodia, while other nations urge more raids. October 22, 2025 Human trafficking and forced-labor camps where the equivalent of indentured servants carry out scams, fraud, and other cybercrime activities have infested Cambodia, Laos, and Burma — and neighboring Asian nations are taking more stringent efforts to deal with the growing problem. Last week, South Korea banned travel to parts of Cambodia, stating that citizens can be prosecuted for violating the law and "strongly advised" them to cancel their trips, in what the government refers to as a "code black" travel ban. The South Korean government, which estimates that about 1,000 citizens are working or forced to work in the cyber-scam centers, is also reportedly readying sanctions against the groups operating in Cambodia and other cybercrime-friendly nations. The actions come following the August discovery of a 22-year-old South Korean student who was lured to a scam center and found dead with signs of torture. "A considerable number of South Koreans are also thought to be employed there — while the exact figure is difficult to verify, domestic authorities generally estimate the number at around 1,000," National Security Adviser Wi Sung-lac told reporters, according to the DW news service . The cybercrime centers have been phenomenally successful, ensnaring hundreds of thousands of workers and raking in tens of billions of dollars every year from victims in the US, the European Union, Canada, and other nations. In September, the US government sanctioned nearly a score of individuals and organizations that profited from the fraud operations and operated in Cambodia and Burma, often referred to as Myanmar. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor Yet, these efforts have largely failed to prevent the growth of the cybercrime syndicates behind the cyber-scam centers, says Frankie Sclafani, director of cybersecurity enablement at Deepwatch, a cyber-resilience platform. "Despite intensified crackdowns by regional nations, the problem is growing," he says. "The syndicates are adapting rapidly by embracing advanced technology, specifically artificial intelligence (AI) ... [and] shifting their operations to decentralized infrastructure, such as satellite Internet, to evade disruption." Alerts and Condemnation A number of other Asian nations — including India and the Philippines — have begun taking more forceful steps against Cambodia, with India calling for greater efforts to repatriate its citizens and the Philippines warning of increasing fraudulent offers of employment to Filipinos as "customer service representatives." Related: China-Nexus Actors Weaponize 'Nezha' Open Source Tool In July, requests from several government ministries in India lead to the Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet issuing director orders for law enforcement and military officials to act against multiple cyber-fraud compounds inside the nation's border, resulting in the arrest of more than 3,000 individuals across 138 sites, including more than 1,000 Chinese nationals, 693 Vietnamese, 366 Indonesians, and 105 Indians. Others have squarely blamed the Cambodian government. In a research report based on interviews with 58 survivors of the cybercrime compounds, analysis of 365 victim records, and visits to 52 compounds, Amnesty International found human trafficking, torture for not meeting targets, measures to prevent victims from leaving, and the selling of victims between compounds. "Deceived, trafficked, and enslaved, the survivors of these scamming compounds describe being trapped in a living nightmare — enlisted in criminal enterprises that are operating with the apparent consent of the Cambodian government," Amnesty International's Secretary General Agnès Callamard said in the report published in June . Cambodia's government called the report "exaggerated," according to Reuters . Beyond the Golden Triangle While the cybercrime fraud centers are flourishing in the former Golden Triangle of Cambodia, Thailand, and Myanmar, they are already spreading quickly. A United Nations report found that the cybercriminal syndicates behind the cyber-scam centers had already started becoming less regional by expanding to areas like Africa. Related: Android Spyware in the UAE Masquerades as ... Spyware Any region with inexperienced law enforcement or lax legal frameworks will likely be targeted as new homes for these efforts, says Justin Endres, head of data security at Seclore, an enterprise cybersecurity firm. "The model is spreading to Africa and Latin America, where weak regulation, cheap infrastructure, and rising crypto activity create fertile ground," he says, adding that governments and companies need to get ahead of the threat. "The fight ahead is about controlling the information these criminal networks exploit before they turn the developing world into their next digital battlefield." In addition, nations should redouble their efforts to sanction the profits and prosecute the individuals behind the cybercrimes, says Deepwatch's Sclafani. "To effectively combat the syndicates, global leaders must focus on coordinated international action that targets the criminal financial networks through sanctions and cryptocurrency forfeitures," he says. "As a society, if we want to stamp out these criminals for good, we must strengthen legal frameworks to regulate new technologies and address the high levels of political corruption that allow these 'scam factories' to continue to operate with impunity." Read more about: About the Author Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer Veteran technology journalist of more than 20 years. Former research engineer. Written for more than two dozen publications, including CNET News.com, Dark Reading, MIT's Technology Review, Popular Science, and Wired News. Five awards for journalism, including Best Deadline Journalism (Online) in 2003 for coverage of the Blaster worm. Crunches numbers on various trends using Python and R. Recent reports include analyses of the shortage in cybersecurity workers and annual vulnerability trends. Dark Reading
Tue, 21 Oct 2025 20:42:46 GMT
Focuses on GNSS interference and its misuse in criminal activity, not direct cyberattacks or vulnerabilities. No specific CVEs or TTPs mentioned. Geopolitical context is central.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/electronic-warfare-commercial-gps-users-notice
[GNSS Jamming][Electronic Warfare][Geopolitical Threat][Supply Chain Fraud] This article highlights rising GNSS interference due to electronic warfare, particularly from Russia and North Korea, affecting aviation, agriculture, and logistics. Spoofing and jamming are now being exploited by cyber-enabled criminals for cargo theft and supply chain fraud. The threat is expanding globally, with daily incidents rising to over 1,000. Insecure GPS reliance poses risks to financial and industrial systems. A good read for threat actors targeting infrastructure and supply chains. Impact: Medium to high (industrial disruption, fraud).
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice Interference with the global positioning system (GPS) isn't just a problem for airlines, but for shipping, trucking, car navigation, agriculture, and even the financial sector. October 21, 2025 Localized jamming and spoofing of global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) continues to be a hallmark of conflicts across the globe, with the digital signal attacks impacting air travel and transport and maritime shipping. And now, the denial-of-service issue seems to be affecting everyday organizations in other verticals, too. The level of interference coming from Russia is particularly significant. In early October, after documenting more than 122,000 flights affected by GNSS interference in the first four months of 2025 — and an incident involving European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's airplane on Sept. 1 — delegates attending the latest United Nation's civil aviation agency assembly voted to condemn Russia's widespread interference and spoofing of GNSS signals in the region. The assembly also condemned North Korea for similar activity. Overall, GNSS interference has increased from around 700 daily incidents in 2024 to more than 1,000 daily incidents this year . The number of incidents is steadily increasing, says Todd Humphreys, a professor in the Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics at the University of Texas and the director of the Radionavigation Laboratory . "By now we've had our wakeup call on the issue of GPS interference," he says. "It has long been viewed as a good idea to harden aviation, maritime, and communications against GPS jamming and spoofing. Now it's an imperative." Related: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense Yet, other industries have also suffered from disruptions as well, due to the reliance of a wide variety of services on the location-and-timing technology. In Finland, for example, areas of farms are reportedly "unfarmable" using GNSS-based tractors and combines because of the interference from Russian electronic warfare (EW) installations. Solar activity is another cause of global positioning system (GPS) and GNSS interference and a May 2024 incident underscored that about 70% of US agricultural production could be impacted by a sustained outage. Expanding Satellite Jamming Attack Landscape GNSS interference has become commonplace for airplanes and maritime shipping in regions of military conflict or heightened geopolitical tensions, including along Russia's border with Europe and Ukraine, Israeli and Palestinian territory, and over Cambodia and Myanmar. In 2025, about 1,000 daily incidents of GPS interference — either spoofing or jamming — have occurred globally, according SkAI Data Services, which tracks the incidents using open source data. Related: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks GPS interference in Europe and Asia on Oct. 19, 2025. Source: SkAI Data Services GNSS jammers are inexpensive, so the number of actors using them is increasing, says Raphael Monstein, co-founder of SkAI Data Services. "It's noticeable around conflicts, and this is not limited" to only the major ones, he says. "[Not just] everywhere around Russia, but on the border of Pakistan and India. We actually see it every day in Myanmar. ... There was huge protests in Serbia where we saw spoofing, but just for a couple of hours, and similar incidents on the North-South Korean border and around Macau." Little wonder, then, that the technology has impacted other industries as well — and far away from these conflict zones. The GNSS and the original US-created global positioning system have become critical services that companies and industries rely upon for location and timing information. In tandem, the disruption and spoofing techniques have made it into the toolboxes of cyber-enabled criminals as well, with attacks on technology a frequent characteristic of cargo theft and supply chain attacks . Thieves can use GPS disruption to prevent authorities from finding cargo containers until any location devices are disabled, or use a trio of technologies — GPS, Voice over IP, and synthetic identities — to enable fraud throughout the supply chain by donning the guise of a customer or shipper. In 2025, value of stolen cargo is expected to rise 22%, with that trio of technologies enabling the increase in crime, according to the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB). Related: International Sting Takes Down SIM Box Criminal Network The financial industry uses GNSS as well to track ATM machines, especially valuable after the dozens of times each year a physical machine is stolen. Banks can use GPS to lead law enforcement to the stolen devices. Updated Hack-Resistant GPS Infrastructure, New Approaches A variety of new technologies has been proposed to mitigate the threat, from gyroscopes-on-a-chip to laser-based technologies that are immune to interference. In a September letter , the GPS Innovation Alliance, which consists of industries reliant on global positioning technology, called for the Trump administration to support investment to create alternatives. "Jamming, spoofing, and other intentional disruptions to GPS pose a serious threat to safety, security, and reliability," said National Business Aviation Association president and CEO Ed Bolen, who joined with the GPSIA to call for "government leaders to work together on upgrades, investments, and other approaches for hardening the technology from interference by nefarious actors." The administration appears to be amenable to funding research and development into alternatives. In a March letter , Brendan Carr, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, called for the exploration of other positioning, navigation, and timing (PNT) systems. "While GPS may be indispensable, it is not infallible," he stated in a March letter. "Continuing to rely so heavily on one system leaves us exposed. Disruptions to GPS have the potential to undermine the nation's economic and national security. And the risks to our current system are only increasing." Five awards for journalism, including Best Deadline Journalism (Online) in 2003 for coverage of the Blaster worm. Crunches numbers on various trends using Python and R. Recent reports include analyses of the shortage in cybersecurity workers and annual vulnerability trends. threat exploit TA threat actor AI
Dark Reading
Tue, 21 Oct 2025 13:32:04 GMT
No specific CVEs, threat actors, or IOCs mentioned. Focus is on fraud tactics using AI and botnets, not direct cyberattacks or vulnerabilities.
https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/streaming-fraud-campaigns-rely-on-ai-tools-bots
[Streaming Fraud][Generative AI][Botnets][AI-Generated Content] This article details how fraudsters leverage generative AI to create fake music and podcasts, then use botnets and fake accounts to generate artificial traffic on streaming platforms like Spotify and YouTube. The fraud diverts royalties from real artists, with AI enabling mass production of tracks and automated traffic generation. The tactics exploit platform algorithms and mimic real user engagement. This is a high-impact threat to content ecosystems and a growing trend in digital fraud. A good read for threat actors due to its operational depth and scalability.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Cybersecurity In-Depth: Digging into data about the latest attacks, threats, and trends using charts and tables. Cybersecurity In-Depth: Digging into data about the latest attacks, threats, and trends using charts and tables. Streaming Fraud Campaigns Rely on AI Tools, Bots Streaming Fraud Campaigns Rely on AI Tools, Bots Streaming Fraud Campaigns Rely on AI Tools, Bots Fraudsters are using generative AI to generate fake music and boost the popularity of the fake content. October 21, 2025 Discussion abounds about how attackers could potentially use artificial intelligence (AI) to craft their attacks. The latest research from Human Security's Satori Threat Intelligence team shows how bad actors are using generative AI to mass produce royalty-eligible music and ghost artists to collect and launder royalties. This is streaming fraud, where bad actors play tracks on loop — but no real audience is listening — and collect royalties. Streaming fraud requires bad actors to create content and then generate seemingly authentic traffic with fake engagement, such as likes, views, comments, and clicks. To be successful, the fraudsters have to generate content at scale and generate large amounts of seemingly authentic traffic to the streams. Rightsholders (usually the artist or the content creator) typically are paid $0.003 to $0.005 per play, but these minuscule payments can add up, especially when fraudsters harness AI to generate millions of tracks and use botnets to generate traffic. Generative AI is making it easy for fraudsters to create thousands of unique, royalty-eligible tracks in minutes, turning stream fraud from "a niche scheme into a large-scale operation," wrote Inna Vasilyeva, senior threat intel analyst and reverse engineer at Human Security, in a research post . "Last year, billions of music streams were consumed by bots, diverting millions in royalties away from real artists." Related: Akira, Cl0p Top List of 5 Most Active Ransomware-as-a-Service Groups Fraudsters are creating large playlists of generated tracks under dozens of fake artist names, where each track is slightly different. Then they're uploading the tracks to major streaming platforms, such as Spotify, Apple Music, and YouTube, using digital distribution services, says Vasilyeva in an interview with Dark Reading. The Satori team found hundreds of thousands of AI-generated songs, some with lyrics and some instrumental, and podcasts. The podcasts are often bot voices reading scraped online text. Fraudsters are also uploading AI videos, often with generic stock music or AI-generated narration. The music itself is bland and repetitive, Vasilyeva notes, since the goal is to just generate a stream and not actually be good . "There is so much opportunity for attackers to target this space," she says. Once the content exists, the next step is to use botnets, fake accounts (or account takeovers of legitimate accounts), click farms, and proxies to generate fake traffic and engagement. Fraudulent streams are often used to artificially boost the ranking of a song or video on popular playlists (such as "Raindy Day Lo-Fi," or workout playlists, for example). The fraudsters use listener farms to drive traffic to these playlists, tricking the streaming platform's algorithm into recommending the AI-generated content to real users. The botnets employ residential proxies, virtual private networks (VPNs), and Selenium/Puppeteer tools to create fraudulent activity that appear as streams originating from different IP addresses across geographic locations. Fraudsters are also using AI to manage the bot networks, such as automating the process of rotating through proxies and VPNs and spoofing digital identities, notes Vasilyeva. Related: Tired of Unpaid Toll Texts? Blame the 'Smishing Triad' The Satori team describes a few ways to identify when the content or stream is being used for streaming fraud, such as when the artist exists only on the platform and has no discernible Web presence. Other signs include the artist having a bare-bones profile page on the streaming platform or being linked to production companies or labels specializing in generic "mood music." Vasilyeva cited Firefly Entertainment and Epidemic Sound as examples in the research post. More importantly, actual streaming platform data can identify potential artificial streaming activity. Sudden, unexplained spikes with abrupt drop-offs in traffic that do not correlate with any promotional activity, press coverage, social media trend, or other real-world event is a good example of bot-driven traffic. Related: Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers Such tactics are not unique to the music industry, says Lindsay Kaye, vice president of threat intelligence at Human Security. Using botnets to push AI-generated materials to create fake ad traffic or misleading people into thinking the content and creators they are engaging with are real are issues that other industries also have to deal with. In many cases, organizations looking at bot detection may not be seeing the full picture of how fraudsters are employing AI and other tools to drive their fraud campaigns. About the Author Fahmida Y. Rashid Managing Editor, Features, Dark Reading As Dark Reading’s managing editor for features, Fahmida Y Rashid focuses on stories that provide security professionals with the information they need to do their jobs. She has spent over a decade analyzing news events and demystifying security technology for IT professionals and business managers. Prior to specializing in information security, Fahmida wrote about enterprise IT, especially networking, open source, and core internet infrastructure. Before becoming a journalist, she spent over 10 years as an IT professional -- and has experience as a network administrator, software developer, management consultant, and product manager. Her work has appeared in various business and test trade publications, including VentureBeat, CSO Online, InfoWorld, eWEEK, CRN, PC Magazine, and Tom’s Guide.
