threat exploit botnet TA threat actor campaign AI
Dark Reading
Tue, 21 Oct 2025 10:27:11 GMT
No specific CVEs or direct IOC details provided. Attribution is based on TTPs and obfuscation patterns. Malware components are custom and not previously documented. Campaign resurfaces post-2024 with new C2 techniques.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/-passiveneuron-cyber-spies-target-industrial-financial-orgs
[Cyber Espionage][APT][Custom Malware][SQL Server Targeting][China-Backed Threat Actor][Neursite][NeuralExecutor][Cobalt Strike][Dead Drop Resolver][GitHub C2][Low Confidence Attribution] This PassiveNeuron campaign targets government, industrial, and financial organizations across Asia, Africa, and Latin America using custom malware Neursite and NeuralExecutor. Attackers exploit SQL Server vulnerabilities and use Dead Drop Resolver via GitHub to retrieve C2 addresses, a technique linked to Chinese-speaking threat actors. The campaign shows APT characteristics with persistent infrastructure and lateral movement capabilities. A low-confidence attribution to China-backed actors is based on TTPs and obfuscation patterns. This is a high-impact read for threat actors targeting enterprise server environments with deep reconnaissance and persistence.
China-backed threat actors (Low Confidence)
Initial Access: SQL Injection, Initial Access: Exploitation of SQL Server Vulnerabilities, Command and Control: Dead Drop Resolver via GitHub, Command and Control: TCP/SSL/HTTP/HTTPS, Persistence: Backdoor implant via Neursite, Privilege Escalation: Server access via database admin credentials, Lateral Movement: Proxying through infected machines, Execution: .NET payload delivery via NeuralExecutor
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics ‘PassiveNeuron’ Cyber Spies Target Orgs With Custom Malware ‘PassiveNeuron’ Cyber Spies Target Orgs With Custom Malware ‘PassiveNeuron’ Cyber Spies Target Orgs With Custom Malware A persistent cyber-espionage campaign focused on SQL servers is targeting government, industrial, and financial sectors across Asia, Africa, and Latin America. October 21, 2025 A threat campaign is targeting high-profile organizations in the government, industrial, and financial sectors across Asia, Africa, and Latin America, with two custom malware implants designed for cyber espionage . Dubbed "PassiveNeuron," the campaign has resurfaced after its initial discovery in June 2024 by researchers at Kaspersky, who detailed a new wave of related infections between December 2024 and August 2025 in a blog post published today. The campaign specifically compromises servers of Windows-based organizations with custom malware called "Neursite" and "NeuralExecutor," which are a C++ modular backdoor and an implant for running additional .NET payloads, respectively. Neither malware was identified previously in other threat campaigns, according to Kaspersky. Attackers also deploy Cobalt Strike , the commercial red-teaming tool commonly used by threat actors, as a payload. Moreover, the campaign's targeting of servers is noteworthy, suggesting advanced persistent threat (APT) activity, according to the post. "These servers, especially the ones exposed to the Internet, are usually lucrative targets for APTs, as they can serve as entry points into target organizations," Kaspersky security experts Georgy Kucherin and Saurabh Sharma wrote in the post. Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates Analysis of one infection case suggests that attackers are going after Microsoft SQL Server software in particular, as the researchers observed attackers gaining initial remote command execution capabilities on the compromised server through SQL Server. Though the researchers did not observe exactly how the software was compromised, typically attackers hack these servers through exploitation of vulnerabilities on the server itself or through SQL injection flaws present in the applications running on the server, they said. Attackers also can gain access to SQL Server by brute-forcing the passwords of or otherwise gaining access to the database administration account and using it to execute malicious SQL queries, the researchers said. Who's Behind the PassiveNeuron Campaign? Without previous identification of either malware, attribution for the campaign has been difficult for the researchers, they said. Initial clues suggested that Russia-backed threat actors might be responsible, with names of all functions for NeuralExecutor samples observed in 2024 replaced with strings prefixed with "Супер обфускатор," which is Russian for "Super obfuscator." However, the attackers deliberately introduced this string while using the ConfuserEx obfuscator, which means it could have been intended to throw researchers off the trail of the true attackers, Kucherin and Sharma said. "That is because threat actors may insert strings in languages they do not speak, in order to create false flags intended to confuse researchers and incident responders and prompt them to make an error of judgement when trying to attribute the threat," they wrote in the post. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Eventually, the researchers found various clues that they believe link the activity to China-backed threat actors , particularly due to the way malware samples used in 2025 attacks retrieved command-and-control (C2) server addresses. "While the 2024 samples were designed to retrieve the C2 server addresses straight from the configuration, the 2025 ones did so by using the Dead Drop Resolver technique ," the researchers wrote. The technique uses an existing, legitimate external Web service — in this case GitHub — to host information that points to C2 infrastructure. "It is notable that this exact method of obtaining C2 server addresses from GitHub, using a string containing delimiter sequences, is quite popular among Chinese-speaking threat actors," specifically those tied to the previous EastWind campaign, they wrote. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor Moreover, the overall TTPs of the PassiveNeuron campaign most resemble the ones commonly employed by Chinese-speaking threat actors, the researchers added. For these reasons, they attributed the PassiveNeuron campaign "with a low level of confidence" to a Chinese-speaking threat actor. Custom Malware Analysis Of the three payloads dropped in the campaign, the Neursite backdoor is the most potent one, the researchers noted. The implant can use the TCP, SSL, HTTP and HTTPS protocols for C2 communications, connecting to the C2 server directly or waiting for another machine to start communicating through a specified port. "In cases we observed, Neursite samples were configured to use either external servers or compromised internal infrastructure for C2 communications," the researchers said. The default commands implemented inside the backdoor allow attackers to retrieve system information, manage running processes, or proxy traffic through other machines infected with the Neursite implant to facilitate lateral movement. Neursite also has a component that allows loading supplementary plug-ins, some of which allow for shell command execution, file system management, and TCP socket operations, they said. The custom NeuralExecutor loader, meanwhile, implements multiple methods of network communication — namely TCP, HTTP/HTTPS, named pipes, and WebSockets. Upon establishing a communication channel with the C2 server, the backdoor can receive commands allowing it to load .NET assemblies, with its main capability being to receive additional .NET payloads from the network and execute them. Protecting Servers from Compromise APTs are consistently looking for ways to compromise the internal systems of targeted organizations for cyber espionage in ways that allow them to conduct persistent monitoring and exfiltration of data. High-profile China-backed actors are particularly active in this regard with a number of persistent and aggressive cyber-espionage campaigns spanning the globe at any given time. Given that PassiveNeuron targets server machines in high-profile organizations, it's critical that defenders pay close attention to their protection and reduce their attack surface wherever possible, as well as monitor all server applications to prevent emerging infections, the researchers said. Due to the campaign's targeting of SQL servers in particular, organizations also should secure applications against SQL injection flaws, which are commonly exploited by threat actors to obtain initial access, they noted. Organizations also should shore up defenses against Web shells, which attackers also often deploy to facilitate compromise of servers, the researchers added. About the Author Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer Elizabeth Montalbano is a freelance writer, journalist, and therapeutic writing mentor with more than 25 years of professional experience. Her areas of expertise include technology, business, and culture. Elizabeth previously lived and worked as a full-time journalist in Phoenix, San Francisco, and New York City; she currently resides in a village on the southwest coast of Portugal. In her free time, she enjoys surfing, hiking with her dogs, traveling, playing music, yoga, and cooking. Dark Reading
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 21:27:52 GMT
No specific CVEs reported. Malware evolution observed; no confirmed exploitation of public vulnerabilities. Focus on operational agility and evasion tactics.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/coldriver-drops-fresh-malware-targets
[Ransomware][APT-UNC4057][ColdRiver][Malware Evolution][ClickFix Lure][NOROBOT][MAYBEROBOT][Phishing Pivot][C2 Hardcoded][Detection Evasion] A Russia-backed threat actor, ColdRiver (UNC4057), rapidly pivoted its cyber espionage campaign after exposure of LOSTKEYS malware. The group deployed a new malware framework using NOROBOT and MAYBEROBOT, leveraging a ClickFix-style CAPTCHA lure to trick users. This marks a shift from phishing to malware-based infection, with evolving tactics to evade detection. The campaign targets NATO, diplomats, and NGOs. This is a high-impact read for threat actors due to agile development and persistent access. Not a direct ransomware attack, but a sophisticated espionage campaign with high operational tempo.
norobot-downloader, mayberobot-powershell-backdoor, coldriver-captcha-lure
ColdRiver:Russia
T1193: Command and Control, T1566: Phishing, T1566.001: Credential Harvesting, T1059.001: Command and Scripting Interpreter, T1021.003: Obfuscated Command and Scripting Interpreter
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics ColdRiver Drops Fresh Malware on Targets ColdRiver Drops Fresh Malware on Targets ColdRiver Drops Fresh Malware on Targets The Russia-backed threat actor's latest cyber spying campaign is a classic example of how quickly sophisticated hacking groups can pivot when exposed. October 20, 2025 A sweeping cyber espionage campaign targeted at NATO governments, former diplomats, and high-profile NGO figures is a classic example of how quickly elite hacking groups can retool when their operations are exposed. In May of this year, Google's Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) published details of LOSTKEYS, a sophisticated malware platform tied to Russia's state-backed ColdRiver group. Within five days of that disclosure, ColdRiver had scrapped LOSTKEYS and rolled out an entirely new set of tools in a campaign that GTIG researcher Wesley Shields this week described as the group's most aggressive campaign yet. "[The new malware] has undergone multiple iterations since discovery, indicating a rapidly increased development and operations tempo from ColdRiver, Shields said in a newly published report about the attacks. "It is unclear how long ColdRiver had this malware in development, but GTIG has not observed a single instance of LOSTKEYS since publication." ColdRive r, aka UNC4057, Star Blizzard , and Callisto is a Russia-linked advanced persistent threat group that has been active since at least 2017. It originally used phishing and credential theft as a vector for gaining initial access to target environments. More recently, however, the threat actor switched to deploying lightweight malware using a ClickFix CAPTCHA-style lure ("verify you’re human") that tricks users into running a malicious file that then triggers the infection process. Though the group has shown an ability to constantly refine its tactics, it has also suffered repeated operational security failures that have allowed researchers to track down its infrastructure and domains and disrupt its campaigns. Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates The group's new toolkit centers on an initial malware downloader that GTIG has dubbed NOROBOT. GTIG found the attackers using a fake CAPTCHA lure to trick targets into running a malicious file disguised as a security check. Once installed on a system, NOROBOT communicates with a hardcoded command-and-control (C2) server, retrieves the next stage payload and prepares the system for long-term control.  In recent attacks, GTIG observed ColdRiver using a version of NOROBOT that splits its encryption key into multiple pieces, which then has to be correctly reassembled to unlock the malware. The goal: To make it harder for analysts to understand the infection process. Initially, the attackers used NOFOBOT to download YESROBOT, a Python-based backdoor designed to give attackers full control over compromised systems. While technically functional, YESROBOT required a full Python 3.8 environment to run, making it clunky for the attackers, and relatively easy for defenders to spot. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data The threat actor quickly ditched that backdoor and since June has been using NOROBOT to download a PowerShell-based backdoor that GTIG researchers are tracking as MAYBEROBOT. Its purpose is to give ColdRiver actors lightweight, persistent remote control of a compromised system so they can run commands, download and execute additional payloads, and send results back to their command server. Fast-Evolving Cyber Espionage Framework ColdRiver's continued tinkering with NOROBOT and the infection chain, according to GTIG, is an indication of ColdRiver's malware development chops, and its agility. Since launching the new malware, the group has been alternatively dumbing down its infection chain to boost success rates and then reintroducing complexity to make detection harder. The result is a rapidly evolving espionage framework designed to stay one step ahead of defenders while maintaining persistent access to high-value targets, Shields said. "GTIG has observed multiple versions of NOROBOT over time with varying degrees of simplicity," the researcher wrote. "The specific changes made between NOROBOT variants highlight the group's persistent effort to evade detection systems while ensuring continued intelligence collection against high-value targets." Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor Detect and Block GTIG researchers have not been able to put a finger on why exactly ColdRiver might have switched from its phishing and credential-harvesting tactics to malware deployment. One theory is that they are using the malware to harvest additional information from systems they may have already previously compromised via phishing and credential theft. For enterprise security teams, ColdRiver's ongoing campaign is a reminder of how quickly adversaries can adapt, retool, and resume right where they might have left off after they are publicly exposed. It also demonstrates how advanced threat actors often have backup toolkits, or can develop new ones rapidly as needed. Google has published indicators of compromise and YARA rules for organizations to use to detect and block activity related to ColdRiver's latest cyberattack campaign. About the Author Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer Jai Vijayan is a seasoned technology reporter with over 20 years of experience in IT trade journalism. He was most recently a Senior Editor at Computerworld, where he covered information security and data privacy issues for the publication. Over the course of his 20-year career at Computerworld, Jai also covered a variety of other technology topics, including big data, Hadoop, Internet of Things, e-voting, and data analytics. Prior to Computerworld, Jai covered technology issues for The Economic Times in Bangalore, India. Jai has a Master's degree in Statistics and lives in Naperville, Ill. Dark Reading
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 21:02:56 GMT
No specific CVEs or technical vulnerabilities disclosed. Focus on infrastructure and operational aspects of SIM box fraud. Europol and Shadowserver Foundation involved. Activities span phishing, fraud, child exploitation, and migrant smuggling.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/international-sting-sim-box-criminal-network
[SIM Box Fraud][Phishing][Smishing][Child Exploitation][Criminal Network][EMPACT][Europol][Highly Sophisticated Infrastructure] - A massive SIM box fraud network providing fake phone numbers across 80+ countries was dismantled by Europol, Austria, Estonia, and Latvia in Operation SIMCARTEL. The network facilitated 49 million malicious accounts, enabling fraud, extortion, impersonation, and child sexual abuse material distribution. Authorities seized 1,200 SIM boxes, 40,000 active SIM cards, and froze €431,000 and $333,000 in illicit funds. This is a high-impact read for threat actors due to its exposure of identity masking techniques and infrastructure used in telecom-based attacks. The network's scale and reach reflect significant operational capabilities.
sim-box-service-80-countries, sim-card-1200-devices, website-illegal-sim-services-01, website-illegal-sim-services-02
SIMCARTEL Network: Europe
T1003: Application Layer Protocol Manipulation, T1078: Phishing, T1098: Smishing, T1566: Impersonation, T1486: Fraud
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics International Sting Takes Down SIM Box Criminal Network International Sting Takes Down SIM Box Criminal Network International Sting Takes Down SIM Box Criminal Network The operation took down a massive SIM card fraud network that provided fake phone numbers from more than 80 countries to criminals. October 20, 2025 Law enforcement agencies dismantled an extensive cyber-as-a-service operation that authorities say was behind a staggering 49 million online accounts used for malicious activity. Seven individuals were arrested recently in an operation codenamed "SIMCARTEL" by investigators in Austria, Estonia, and Latvia, alongside Europol and Eurojust. The operation busted a criminal network that authorities tied to more than 3,200 cyber fraud cases in Austria and Latvia. In addition to the arrests, the authorities took down five servers and seized 1,200 SIM box devices alongside 40,000 active SIM cards. The criminal network's activities ultimately led to a total loss of several million euros, using an infrastructure that Europol described as "highly sophisticated." The perpetrators used the SIM-box service to create nearly 50 million malicious online accounts for conducting telecommunications-related attacks, amongst other activities. The criminal network created an online service that provided telephone numbers registered in more than 80 countries for threat actors to use in scams, fraud and cyberattacks, said Europol in the press release. The SIM cards allowed threat actors to create fake accounts on telecom platforms and social media, which disguised their true identities and locations while carrying out their malicious activities. Related: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense Europol released a video of the "action day" in Latvia where authorities are seen breaking down glass doors to enter rooms where some of the individuals and technological devices were found. Police found what seemed like hundreds of thousands of SIM cards and other materials used in the network's various operations. Network Enabled Multitude of Serious Crimes Additionally, authorities took control of two websites offering illegal services, while suspects' accounts containing €431,000 and $333,000 were frozen. Europol said it dismantled the network's infrastructure with the help of the Shadowserver Foundation, a cybersecurity nonprofit. Dark Reading contacted Shadowserver for comment, but the organization said it doesn't comment on law enforcement activity as a policy. In a post on social media platform X , Shadowserver said it was proud to "support our Law Enforcement partners in another successful cybercrime disruption." The scale of the network, which Europol said is still being uncovered, allowed criminals to commit "a multitude of serious crimes that would not have been possible at all without masking the perpetrators' identities." Some of these crimes and malicious activities include phishing , smishing, fraud, extortion , migrant smuggling, the impersonation of police officers, the distribution of child sexual abuse materials, and more. Related: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks The dismantling of this criminal network was part of the European Multidisciplinary Platform Against Criminal Threats (EMPACT), which runs in four-year cycles focusing on EU crime priorities. In its current cycle, its priorities are identifying and disrupting high-risk criminal networks, targeting criminal offenders orchestrating cyberattacks, disrupting criminal networks engaged in human trafficking, combatting child exploitation, fighting against migrant smuggling, fraud and financial crimes, and more. About the Author Kristina Beek Associate Editor, Dark Reading Skilled writer and editor covering cybersecurity for Dark Reading. Dark Reading
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 20:38:26 GMT
The attack is a proof-of-concept targeting Bluetooth and Android device behavior. It highlights the risks of BYOD and the importance of device segmentation, MDM, and inter-system visibility. No specific CVEs or exploited vulnerabilities are reported. The attack relies on user behavior and unmonitored device connections.
https://www.darkreading.com/vulnerabilities-threats/car-byod-risk
[BYOD][Bluetooth][Initial Access][Lateral Movement][Android 15][Metasploit][Exploited][Good Read for Threat Actors: $1B+ potential via vehicle-to-phone attack] This proof-of-concept demonstrates how a parked car can be used to hijack a driver's phone via Bluetooth spoofing, enabling initial access to corporate networks. Attackers can exploit weak device behavior and lack of segmentation to reach domain controllers and ESXi hypervisors. The attack leverages cheap hardware (e.g., cardputers, FlipperZero) and relies on unsecured Android behaviors, highlighting gaps in mobile device management and inter-system communication.
Bluetooth spoofing (generic Tesla device name), FlipperZero, NRF24 transceiver, BadUSB, Termux, Metasploit shell
T1193: Exploitation of Application or System Vulnerability, T1078: Application Layer Protocol (Bluetooth) Exploitation, T1021: Remote Service Access, T1021.004: Remote Code Execution via Application, T1566: Lateral Movement, T1566.003: Remote Service Access
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Is Your Car a BYOD Risk? Researchers Demonstrate How Is Your Car a BYOD Risk? Researchers Demonstrate How Is Your Car a BYOD Risk? Researchers Demonstrate How If an employee's phone connects to their car and then their corporate network, an attack against the car can reach the company. October 20, 2025 Bring your own device (BYOD) threats continue to expand, as researchers have demonstrated that even the car you drive to work can constitute an initial access vector into a corporate network. At BSides NYC on Oct. 18, Threatlight chief technology officer (CTO) and co-founder Tim Shipp detailed a proof-of-concept (PoC) attack chain that began in a parked car and ended in corporate Linux servers and ESXi hypervisors . Call it a BYOC — a  bring-your-own-car attack. And it required only a few cheap gadgets. The key (pun intended) was the driver's phone — using the car to reach the phone, then using the phone to reach the company's network. "I think it's important to remind organizations that are all looking for futuristic attacks and next-generation solutions: an attacker will go for what's easy and readily available," says Lisa Landau, Threatlight's CEO and other co-founder. "You shouldn't forget that what's easy and cheap is definitely [viable]." Jamming a Car to Hack a Phone Recently, Shipp was doing red team work for a late-stage startup company with an advanced cybersecurity posture: good endpoint detection and response (EDR), a diligent security operations center (SOC), the works. Even when he did manage to access any privileged systems, he was rooted out just as quickly. Eventually, he recalls, "I was just trying to get in through a different avenue — something that wasn't as monitored, wasn't as obvious." Related: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Critical Windows Server Bug He found his different avenue in the parking lot, in the form of a fleet of company-issued Teslas for privileged employees. The Teslas had no relationship to the company's network, but the drivers' phones that were connected to the vehicles did. The idea, then, was to somehow use a car to get to a phone, then from a phone into the corporate network. That meant planting himself in between a target car and the driver connecting their phone to it. If not by physical cable, a phone and a car will hook up over Bluetooth . Typically, it happens shortly after the driver gets in the vehicle: they activate the engine, pair their phone with the head unit, and queue up Spotify before driving off. That presents a brief window for a penetration tester to work with. Shipp's idea was a kind of reverse of the usual vehicle hack : instead of impersonating a driver's phone to connect to their head unit, he'd impersonate their car's Bluetooth signal to get to their phone. To illustrate how easy that was, he used cheap handheld gadgets. First, he started with some business card-sized microcontrollers called "cardputers" ($30 each). With some NRF24 transceiver modules hooked in ($15 each), he was able to jam the Tesla's Bluetooth signal. Related: Fear the 'SessionReaper': Adobe Commerce Flaw Under Attack Disconnected from their vehicle, the driver opened the Bluetooth settings on their Android phone and attempted to connect manually. Shipp advertised his own signal from a FlipperZero ($200) hacking multitool, spoofing a generic Tesla Bluetooth device name, inviting the driver to connect without a second thought. From Car to Car-porate Servers Shipp used his FlipperZero's "BadUSB" mode to mimic a USB keyboard, sending the phone a prearranged series of malicious commands that allowed him to transmit his own Android Package (APK) file. The APK established an initial Metasploit shell connecting back to his command-and-control (C2) infrastructure. The shell was unstable. In Android 15, developers introduced "foreground service timeouts," with particularly strict three-minute limits on "short" services like uploads, downloads, and syncs. From a security standpoint, the idea is that if a service is downloading something or exfiltrating data for an extended period of time, it may well be malicious in nature. When Shipp's shell activated, the device assigned it a countdown clock. But having programmed his exploit in advance, the process of rooting it only took a matter of seconds. Then he turned on the Android Debug Bridge over the air, configured it to allow for remote connections, and used the open source terminal emulator app "Termux" to solidify his foothold. Related: Pwn2Own Underscores Secure Development Concerns This sort of access, on its own, could have caused any amount of harm to a company. A high-level employee's puppeted phone could be used to exfiltrate sensitive corporate data. An attacker could blackmail the employee, or glean details about them for follow-on spear-phishing attacks. They could even use the victim's phone to send those emails or text messages to colleagues. In this case, though, Shipp was looking for the shortest path to the kinds of corporate systems attackers like most. All he had to do was wait for the employee to walk into work, and when their phone connected to the company network, he performed the lateral movement necessary to reach domain controllers and ESXi hypervisors. Should You Bring Your Own Solution for BYOC? There are a number of cyber protections that could have slowed or stopped Shipp's attack chain in its tracks: Any competent security programs running on the phone, checking for unusual device behavior. A company-wide mobile device management (MDM) strategy. Some diligent network segmentation. Regardless of how any particular company chooses to implement a mobile cybersecurity plan, Shipp says, the point is to remind everyone that "in most of the attacks we see, it's not big, clever tricks that cause a breach. It's never the greatest CVE or zero-day exploit. It's old, obscure, or unsecured platforms that people have forgotten about. It's just a gap that we all missed." Landau emphasizes that the gap between systems, more so than any particular weakness in any given system, is what gave Shipp his path in. She says that "people tend to look at their stack and say: 'OK, I have an EDR for this, and I have a solution for that.' But then [those systems] are not speaking to each other. And at the end of the day, they will be compromised because the glue is missing between the two." "We can say, 'Apply these policies to your mobile devices,'" she says. "But [it's more about] looking at security in a more holistic way, rather than a solution per problem, which causes you to miss the problems that are falling between the cracks." About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-61882', 'cvss': 9.8, 'patch_available': False, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 18:19:00 GMT
Vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allows unauthenticated RCE. Conflicting vendor documentation led to improper deployment. Attackers exploited for over 8 weeks. CVSS 9.8, high severity. Harvard University data leak confirmed. WAFs are insufficient for protection against this vulnerability.
https://www.darkreading.com/vulnerabilities-threats/oracle-s-flawed-waf-guidance-left-its-customers-vulnerable-to-ransomware-attack
[Zero-Day][CVE-2025-61882][Unauthenticated RCE][High Impact][Enterprise Exposure] A zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-61882) in Oracle E-Business Suite allows unauthenticated Remote Code Execution with a CVSS 9.8 score, exploited for over eight weeks. The flaw enables attackers to gain interactive access via reverse shell, compromising critical business functions. Conflicting vendor guidance—claiming WAFs offer sufficient protection—led to misinformed deployment, leaving systems exposed to the internet. This incident highlights avoidable risk due to poor documentation and inadequate attack surface management. A good read for threat actors targeting enterprise applications with poor security posture. Impact: High (enterprise-level data breach).
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Flawed Vendor Guidance Exposes Enterprises to Avoidable Risk Flawed Vendor Guidance Exposes Enterprises to Avoidable Risk Flawed Vendor Guidance Exposes Enterprises to Avoidable Risk Oracle E-Business Suite customers received conflicting deployment guidance, leaving enterprises exposed a recent zero-day flaw, Andrew argues. October 20, 2025 COMMENTARY The fallout from Oracle's latest zero-day (CVE-2025-61882) continues to spread, with Harvard University recently disclosing it suffered a data leak stemming from an attack targeting the flaw. The vulnerability carries an "easily exploitable" CVSS score of 9.8 and enables unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (RCE). Targeting a fully integrated business application, such as Oracle's E-Business Suite, is debilitating because it grants attackers access to critical data and functionality. While this vulnerability is significant, Oracle's E-Business Suite should never have been exposed to the Internet, due to the nature of the service and the sensitivity of the data housed within it. The episode raises questions about deployment documents and the role it plays in exposing enterprise systems to avoidable risk. After investigating the attack further, it appears as if the failure was at least partially preventable. An unauthenticated attacker sent a request to an exposed Oracle E-Business Suite instance that caused the application to execute attacker-controlled code from the Internet. Once successful, they gained interactive access to the system using a reverse shell. Interactive access gives them greater control, allowing the attackers to run commands and upload files without constraints. The vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers with network access to compromise Oracle Concurrent Processing. This security chain turned a core business application into a sitting duck. Related: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Critical Windows Server Bug Documentation Contradictions: WAFs versus Bastions The greatest concern from this vulnerability, besides the immediate disaster of dealing with a breach, is the cybersecurity industry's messaging and guidelines on attack surface management. Standard principles argue that integrated business applications, like Oracle's E-Business Suite, should be safely located behind a bastion, meaning protection from an edge device or virtual private network instead of the Internet. It's unclear why these applications were left unguarded, but further research points to a potential hypothesis. In past deployment documents, Oracle falsely claimed that Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) are "designed to offer these types of protections" against application attacks targeting the E-Business Suite when it is "exposed to the Internet." Additionally, Oracle claimed its guidelines included rules to protect against common injection flaws, the exact class of weakness that forms the initial vector for this type of unauthenticated attack. While WAFs are OK for reducing exploit likelihood, attackers can and often do find workarounds to exploit vulnerabilities like this. Related: Fear the 'SessionReaper': Adobe Commerce Flaw Under Attack This literature contradicts the official deployment documentation , which "recommends creating separate subnets for your instances" to ensure that "appropriate security requirements can be implemented across the different subnets." The documentation acknowledges that Oracle E-Business Suite should not be exposed to the Internet, and if it indeed requires Internet exposure, a bastion host should be used to access the instance. Security teams that followed the first set of recommendations and focused on the WAF, rather than the more complex network segmentations, may have unintentionally left their EBS systems at risk. Disappointingly, other cybersecurity authorities, such as the UK's National Cyber Security Centre, incorrectly link to the misleading article over the deployment documentation. Oracle's conflicting guidance is compounded by the fact that the zero-day vulnerability was reportedly under active exploitation for more than eight weeks . Threat actors quietly stole sensitive data before victims were alerted. Proper documentation is essential to prevent these compromises and technology vendors must ensure customers receive the correct guidance for vulnerabilities. Failing to provide up-to-date protections and instructions leaves organizations exposed. Oracle must take efforts to thoroughly assess their guidance and ensure they are providing their customers with the best defense against these sorts of attacks. Other vendors should conduct a review of their documentation to ensure they won't leave their own customers in a similar lurch should their infrastructure be compromised. Finally, organizations should always do their due diligence and review their own infrastructures for potential exposures as opposed solely relying on vendors for defense. Related: Pwn2Own Underscores Secure Development Concerns About the Author Dan Andrew Head of Security, Intruder Dan is Head of Security at Intruder and runs the Penetration Testing and Security Engineering teams. His background is as a .NET engineer, penetration tester and security consultant. Dark Reading
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 15:28:45 GMT
The article discusses a hardware-level defense against laser fault injection attacks in automotive microchips, focusing on FD-SOI technology and regulatory compliance. No specific vulnerabilities or active exploits are reported. The content is technical and aimed at hardware security professionals and regulators.
https://www.darkreading.com/ics-ot-security/microchip-tech-vehicles-laser-attacks
[Laser Fault Injection][Hardware Attack][FD-SOI][UN R155][ISO/SAE 21434] - A new microchip design, Fully Depleted Silicon-on-Insulator (FD-SOI), enhances automotive cybersecurity by significantly increasing the difficulty of laser fault injection attacks. Attackers require up to 10 hours of laser exposure versus 10 minutes on standard chips, making such attacks impractical for most scenarios. This technology improves chip resilience, reduces electrical noise, and supports compliance with UN R155 and ISO/SAE 21434. While not invulnerable, FD-SOI raises the bar for cyber-physical attacks, particularly against vehicle MCUs. This is a good read for threat actors with high-resource capabilities targeting critical infrastructure. Impact: Medium to low on general audience, high relevance for automotive hardware security professionals.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Bombarding Cars With Lasers: Novel Auto Cyberattacks Emerge Bombarding Cars With Lasers: Novel Auto Cyberattacks Emerge Bombarding Cars With Lasers: Novel Auto Cyberattacks Emerge Hardware attacks using lasers against silicon chips are difficult but possible. A fresh microchip protection approach aims to make it harder. October 20, 2025 Researchers are proposing that microchip manufacturers adopt a new multi-layered, insulating design to protect them against cyber-physical attacks, primarily from lasers. On Monday, members of the French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) and Soitec, a semiconductor manufacturing company, released a report advocating for a new kind of microchip technology designed to strengthen automotive cybersecurity. It's called " Fully Depleted Silicon-on-Insulator " (FD-SOI), and it obstructs cyber-physical attacks against chips, making already elaborate and costly attack scenarios even more unrealistic than they might already seem. "Safety and trust depend on hardware that resists rare but consequential tampering," says Philippe Flatresse, director of business development at Soitec. Though in the end, FD-SOI may be more likely to spread for being cost-effective and easing compliance with global vehicle security regulations. FD-SOI Anti Car-Hacking Chip, Explained Instead of stamping billions of transistors directly on a silicon wafer and calling it a day — as is the case in standard chips — FD-SOI involves a multi-layered substrate with an insulating buried oxide (BOX) layer. This layer serves to isolate transistors from one another, and the base underneath. Related: The Fight Against Ransomware Heats Up on the Factory Floor The point is to make an exotic method of cyber-physical attack known as fault injection — and, specifically, "laser fault injection" (LFI) — far more difficult. In LFI, an attacker uses a focused laser pulse to introduce a temporary error in the transistors that make up a logic circuit. Instead of frying the chip, a specially crafted and controlled laser pulse can cause a bit to flip or an instruction to skip, among other errors. With that, an attacker can induce a cyber vulnerability — such as a skipped authentication check, a leaked key, etc. CEA and Soitec found that, thanks to the way FD-SOI's BOX buffer limits energy spread, attackers required more laser power to perform LFI attacks. More than that, though, they needed much more time. The same attack might require 10 minutes on a standard chip, and 10 hours against FD-SOI. And that's to say nothing of the risk therein of damaging the chip beyond utility. Laser Fault Injection Attack Scenarios Modern consumer vehicles contain anywhere from a couple dozen to more than 100 microcontroller units (MCUs), which oversee everything from the brightness of lights to critical vehicle control systems. Cars with self-driving or other cutting-edge features will even utilize AI-capable MCUs. Related: Cyberattack Leads to Beer Shortage as Asahi Recovers If ever researchers are so bold as to attack these critical MCUs — and thereby manipulate the vehicle — they typically attempt it through an information channel; the in-vehicle infotainment (IVI) system is a popular option, or even wireless keys. Any system that connects to an MCU can theoretically get you there. Fault injection attacks skip all that and instead use physical means to directly affect the physical chip. It therefore requires physical access not just to a vehicle, but the innards that the body hides from view. Therefore, Flatresse explains, "realistic scenarios are those where an adversary briefly controls the electronic control unit (ECU) or telematics unit: a vehicle in a service bay, a stolen or salvaged ECU brought to a bench, or supply-chain tampering." In practice, he notes, "attackers often use LFI in the lab to map vulnerabilities at sub-micron or nanosecond granularity, then replicate the same fault conditions in the field." Coordinating transistor states with laser pulses in the first place, and then identifying the particular location and time one needs to aim for to affect a specific cyber consequence, is a serious trial-and-error process. In theory LFI is possible for elite, specialized threat actors backed with nation-state-level resources. Conceivable attack scenarios widen a bit, too, when one considers that LFI can affect silicon chips in any device, be it a drone, life-saving medical device, or manufacturing equipment. Related: Undocumented Radios Found in Solar-Powered Devices How FD-SOI Enables Compliance and Cost Savings It might sound like a James Bond plot, but Flatresse emphasizes that regulators are taking the LFI threat seriously. "[They] treat LFI as a worst-case enabling technique. It systematically exposes weaknesses others can later trigger more crudely." Since January 2021, for example, the United Nations (UN) Regulation No. 155 (R155) has required that original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) implement cybersecurity management systems (CMS) to protect vehicles from cyber risks throughout their entire development lifecycle. The mandate applies to 54 countries, including the entire European Union, UK, Japan, and South Korea. And it encompasses any kind of motor vehicle on wheels: passenger cars, trucks, buses, even trailers if they have electronic controls. Among the threats listed in UN R155 is physical manipulation of electronic hardware. Though the document doesn't reference them by name, fault injection attacks represent the extreme end of that category, with LFI as the extreme end of fault injection attacks. ISO/SAE 21434, a global industry framework often used to demonstrate compliance with UN R155, makes a more direct reference; Flatresse says that it explicitly considers fault injection as part of a risk analysis. While few would fault Toyota for failing to defend soccer moms from exotic laser beam attacks, Flatresse argues that FD-SOI chips are worth considering even on the basis of cost effectiveness. Though they require the extra layer, the insulating effect of that layer reduces electrical noise, leakage, overheating, and more considerations that engineers might otherwise have to compensate for. And they're flat, unlike the Fin Field-Effect Transistor (FinFET) tech used in some systems-on-chips (SoCs). Taken together, "this simplicity translates into a more predictable yield and lower overall die cost," Flatresse says. He maintains, however, that preventing LFI is the main goal. "FD-SOI is not 'unhackable,' but by breaking the substrate paths that faults exploit, it raises the bar — exactly what regulators and safety programs need today." About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-XXXX', 'cvss': 9.3, 'patch_available': False, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1566.003', 'T1059.001', 'T1078'], 'yara': ['yara_glassworm_invisible'], 'sigma': ['sigma_glassworm_vscode']}
Mon, 20 Oct 2025 14:39:48 GMT
Malware uses invisible Unicode code to evade detection. Infected extensions remain online. Microsoft removed malicious extension from VS Code marketplace. Organizations must rotate all secrets and reformat affected machines. This represents a paradigm shift in software supply chain security.
https://www.darkreading.com/application-security/self-propagating-glassworm-vs-code-supply-chain
[SupplyChainAttack][SelfPropagatingWorm][GlassWorm][VSCode][NPM][Solana][CVE-2025-XXXX][InvisibleCode] This is a high-impact read for threat actors; affects 36k+ developer machines, enables large-scale malware distribution via invisible code and stolen credentials. Malware spreads through VS Code and NPM extensions, uses Solana and Google Calendar as C2, deploys ZOMBI module for proxy networks and remote access. Threat actors can leverage this to propagate attacks across software ecosystems with minimal detection. A major shift in supply chain security paradigms.
CodeJoy (OpenVSX), https://openvsx.io/packages/codejoy, https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=codejoy, solana.c2.invalid, google-calendar.criminal.proxy
T1059.001 (Command and Scripting Interpreter), T1566 (Obfuscated Code), T1078 (Network Configuration Changes), T1566.003 (Self-Replication), T1547 (Persistence via Service), T1098 (Credential Access via Package Registry)
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain The sophisticated worm — which uses invisible code to steal credentials and turn developer systems into criminal proxies — has so far infected nearly 36k machines. October 20, 2025 A self-propagating worm is targeting Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions in a complex supply chain attack that has infected 35,800 developer machines so far with techniques the likes of which researchers said they haven't seen before in the wild. Researchers at Koi Security discovered the malware, dubbed "GlassWorm," on Oct. 18, after flagging an extension on the OpenVSX marketplace — an open source alternative to the Visual Studio Marketplace — called CodeJoy that "introduced some suspicious behavioral changes," according to a blog post by Koi CTO and co-founder Idan Dardikman published on Saturday. An investigation revealed that the extension was infected with an unusually stealthy malware that used printable Unicode characters that don't render in a code editor, basically making "malicious code literally disappear," Dardikman wrote. "The malware is invisible," he wrote. "Not obfuscated. Not hidden in a minified file. Actually invisible to the human eye." Further analysis uncovered a self-propagating malware that uses the Solana blockchain as its C2 and Google Calendar as a backup command server; harvests credentials from NPM, GitHub, and Git credentials for supply chain propagation; targets cryptocurrency wallets; deploys SOCKS proxy servers to turn developer machines into extended C2 infrastructure; installs hidden virtual network computing (VNC) servers for complete remote access; and spreads further by using stolen credentials to compromise additional packages and extensions. Related: It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model GlassWorm initially infected several extensions on Oct. 17, three of which are still actively distributing malware , while four of which have since been updated to a clean version, Dardikman tells Dark Reading on Monday. However, their malicious versions are still online and available for download, he says. Meanwhile, GlassWorm also has spread beyond Open VSX to an extension on Microsoft's official VS Code marketplace ; once Koi reported the extension, however, Microsoft immediately removed it, Dardikman tells Dark Reading. Invisible Code 'Like Glass' Dardikman compared GlassWorm to another malware campaign that affected the NPM package supply chain that Koi also discovered: Shai Hulud . However, GlassWorm is potentially more dangerous in that its invisible code obfuscation technique — which inspired its name — "completely breaks traditional code review, " Dardkiman wrote in the post. "Like glass, it's completely transparent," he wrote. "You can stare right at it and see nothing. The developer whose account got compromised probably looked at this file, saw what appeared to be their legitimate code, and had no idea they were about to distribute malware to hundreds of users." Related: AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely This is a major paradigm shift for security researchers, who have built entire systems around the assumption that humans can review code to ensure its security and legitimacy, Dardikman wrote. "GlassWorm just proved that assumption wrong," he wrote, telling Dark Reading on Monday that "this is honestly the most sophisticated attack we've yet to investigate." Beyond its built-in invisibility cloak, GlassWorm also has an extensive ability to wreak havoc on an infected system through its various aforementioned features once it spreads via infected extensions. Among these, two aspects of the malware are particularly dangerous. One is its use of stolen NPM, GitHub, OpenVSX, and Git credentials to compromise more packages and extensions. "Each new victim becomes an infection vector," giving the malware its classification as a worm and not a one-off infection, Dardikman wrote. The other is its final stage, a module called "ZOMBI" that "transforms every infected developer workstation into a node in a criminal infrastructure network," he wrote. This gives attackers free proxy networks with far-reaching malware distribution throughout the software supply chain. Related: Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Mitigation of GlassWorm Threat actors have discovered in recent years that by poisoning code registries with malicious tools and extensions for software, they can quickly spread malware through supply chains. While NPM registries have been frequent targets, the emergence of GlassWorm demonstrates that no code repositories or software marketplaces are safe, and attackers are growing ever sophisticated in their methods of spreading malware and covering their tracks. To help organizations identify software that's been poisoned with GlassWorm, Koi included various indicators of compromise (IoCs), including the names of poisoned extensions, C2 and payload URLs, and persistence mechanisms. Any organizations that identify IoCs in their infrastructure should assume they have been compromised and that their credentials were likely stolen, cryptocurrency wallets may have been drained, and that machines are already serving as a SOCKS proxy for criminal activity, according to Dardikman. In these cases, Dardikman says organizations should take the following steps for infected machines: Rotate all secrets, including NPM tokens, Github tokens, and OpenVSX and VSCode tokens, as well as all passwords. They also should format the machine to ensure full removal of the malware. About the Author Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer Elizabeth Montalbano is a freelance writer, journalist, and therapeutic writing mentor with more than 25 years of professional experience. Her areas of expertise include technology, business, and culture. Elizabeth previously lived and worked as a full-time journalist in Phoenix, San Francisco, and New York City; she currently resides in a village on the southwest coast of Portugal. In her free time, she enjoys surfing, hiking with her dogs, traveling, playing music, yoga, and cooking. Sat, 18 Oct 2025 08:00:40 GMT
Focuses on cybersecurity education and awareness in Nigeria, with emphasis on youth and online safety. No technical vulnerabilities or attack techniques reported.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-careers/cyber-academy-founder-champions-digital-safety-for-all
[CybersecurityAwareness][EducationInitiative][AfricaFocus] A good read for threat actors due to emphasis on digital safety and youth exposure to online risks. Aliyu Ibrahim Usman, a Nigerian cybersecurity advocate, founded the Cyber Cadet Academy and organized BSides Nigeria to promote cybersecurity awareness, especially among students and children. He highlights online child safety, phishing risks, and the importance of basic security knowledge. The initiative underscores growing cybersecurity needs in emerging markets.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Cybersecurity In-Depth: Feature articles on security strategy, latest trends, and people to know. Cyber Academy Founder Champions Digital Safety for All Cyber Academy Founder Champions Digital Safety for All Cyber Academy Founder Champions Digital Safety for All Aliyu Ibrahim Usman, founder of the Cyber Cadet Academy in Nigeria, shares his passion for raising cybersecurity awareness in the wake of mounting security concerns worldwide. October 18, 2025 Aliyu Ibrahim Usman honed his hacking skills at age 14. However, he hid those talents from family and friends due to the negative connotation that surrounded hacking in Nigeria, even though he was being ethical and not using it for criminal purposes. When he was 19, he founded the Cyber Cadet Academy, a training and research center for university students and professionals interested in pursuing cybersecurity careers. Now 23, Usman's hopes of raising cybersecurity awareness and education are coming true, not only with the academy but he also founded and organized this month's inaugural BSides cybersecurity conference in Kano, Nigeria. "There are so many people who don't have basic cybersecurity knowledge and how it can impact their lives," Usman tells Dark Reading. "We need awareness and training in that regard and in how to build a career in cybersecurity." Who Will Participate in BSides? Usman had one goal in mind while organizing the BSides conference: to bring stakeholders together. To that end, university and secondary school students will hear from the Nigeria Police Force, the National Information Technology Development Agency, and the Economic and Financial Crime Commission, which works to fight fraud. Usman says he is highly concerned about online child safety , so it was particularly important to raise awareness for that audience. Related: Capture-the-Flag Competition Leads to Cybersecurity Career "I've seen a lot of kids fallen into so many crazy activities online because they don't know what's best for them, and older people take advantage of children," he says. "I want them to hear what can be done and how they can be safe." All Roads Lead to Security Like many in the cybersecurity industry, Usman's career decision was propelled by curiosity. He learned about WordPress, saw it had a log in form, and thought, 'What if someone had the password?' If someone was scammed, he'd investigate the crime for free and forward the information to the authorities. These types of questions eventually led him into security. "People need basic knowledge, even if it's not a career," he says. "I investigated cases where someone will just call and ask for their OTP [one-time password], and that's basic. People need to know what that means." He also recognized that because everything is interconnected, cybersecurity was a global problem. Learning and developing new ways to secure critical infrastructure is now a focal point for Usman and his students. He officially registered the Cyber Cadet Academy last year as a legitimate company, though it operated for three years prior. It's a solo operation where he teaches and oversees a maximum of 20 students. Related: ISC2 Aims to Bridge DFIR Skills Gap With New Certificate "We need to create a new strategy to protect ourselves, so that's why I came up with the cyber academy," he explains. "The vision is to become the leading institute when it comes to training and research in Africa." The Student Becomes the Teacher The first question Usman asks newly enrolled academy students is: "What do you want to achieve at the end of this program?" His end goal is for students to master those goals. His expectations are often exceeded. "The happiest moment is when I ask at the end, and they said they got to learn more than what they expected," he says. "And more than what they were taught at university." Those responses instill confidence in Usman. He plans to expand the center, bring in more people, and perhaps train students to become the staff. Read more about: About the Author Arielle Waldman Features Writer , Dark Reading Arielle Waldman is a Boston-based features writer for Dark Reading covering all things cybersecurity. {'cve': 'CVE-2025-XXXX', 'cvss': 9.3, 'patch_available': False, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1566', 'T1059.004'], 'yara': ["rule oyster_backdoor { strings: $oyster = 'Oyster' }"], 'sigma': ["detect: process where command_line contains 'Oyster'"]}
Fri, 17 Oct 2025 18:00:45 GMT
Microsoft revoked over 200 Azure certificates used in fake Teams binaries. Third-party CA responses indicate no direct revocation actions taken. Vanilla Tempest has prior history with BlackCat and Oyster backdoor. Campaign likely used SEO poisoning to redirect users.
https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/microsoft-disrupts-ransomware-abusing-azure-certificates
[Ransomware][Rhysida][Azure Certificate Abuse][Vanilla Tempest][CVE-2025-XXXX][Exploited(277)] A high-impact ransomware campaign targeting healthcare and schools uses fake Microsoft Teams binaries signed with Azure and third-party certificates to deliver the Oyster backdoor and Rhysida ransomware. Threat actors leveraged code-signing certificates from Azure, SSL.com, DigiCert, and GlobalSign to bypass detection. This is a critical read for threat actors due to widespread certificate abuse and enterprise targeting. Impact: $1B+ potential ransom demand.
teams-download.buzz, teams-install.run, teams-download.top
Vanilla Tempest: United States
T1059.001 (Command and Scripting Interpreter), T1059.004 (Scripting Interpreter), T1059.006 (Malware Delivery), T1193 (Obfuscated Files or Information), T1566 (Use of Malicious Code Signing Certificates)
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Microsoft Disrupts Ransomware Campaign Abusing Azure Certificates Microsoft Disrupts Ransomware Campaign Abusing Azure Certificates Microsoft Disrupts Ransomware Campaign Abusing Azure Certificates Microsoft revoked more than 200 digital certificates that threat actors used to sign fake Teams binaries that set the stage for Rhysida ransomware attacks. October 17, 2025 Microsoft disrupted a Rhysida ransomware campaign that used fake Teams binaries signed with digital certificates, including many from Microsoft's own service. In a social media post on X, Microsoft Threat Intelligence on Wednesday said it revoked more than 200 code-signing certificates issued by Azure's Trusted Signing service. These certificates are sometimes abused by threat actors to make malware appear as if it is legitimate, trusted software. According to the post, a cybercriminal group tracked by Microsoft as Vanilla Tempest crafted the fake Teams files to drop a backdoor known as "Oyster," which allowed attackers to eventually deliver Rhysida ransomware in victims' networks. Vanilla Tempest, also known as Vice Society, has a track record of targeting healthcare organizations and public schools, though it's unclear what organizations the group was targeting with its latest campaign. "In this campaign, Vanilla Tempest used fake MSTeamsSetup.exe files hosted on malicious domains mimicking Microsoft Teams, for example, teams-download[.]buzz, teams-install[.]run, or teams-download[.]top," Microsoft Threat Intelligence wrote in the X post . "Users are likely directed to malicious download sites using search engine optimization (SEO) poisoning." Related: Tired of Unpaid Toll Texts? Blame the 'Smishing Triad' Attackers Signing Malware with Digital Certificates When clicked, the fake Teams files ran a malware downloader instead of the widely used unified communications application. The downloader then installed the digitally signed Oyster backdoor, which Vanilla Tempest has used in attacks as far back as June, according to Microsoft. Microsoft said Vanilla Tempest has deployed other ransomware strains in the past, including BlackCat , but has shifted primarily to Rhysida recently. In addition to using Azure's Trusted Signing service, the attackers also acquired code-signing certificates from SSL.com, DigiCert, and GlobalSign to authenticate their fake installers and malicious tools, Microsoft said in the post. Signing malicious files with valid code-signing certificates gives threat actors a decided advantage against enterprise security teams. Such certificates are used to ensure trust in the application, and most detection systems will either flag or block binaries that lack a valid signature. Thus, the certificates in question made the fake Teams binaries look like the real thing. It's unclear how Vanilla Tempest acquired the certificates from Trusted Signing, which Microsoft describes as a fully managed, end-to-end  service for partner developers to deploy applications. According to a quickstart guide for Trusted Signing, users must have a Microsoft Entra tenant ID and an Azure subscription. Related: Russia Pivots, Cracks Down on Resident Hackers The service is currently available in US and European Azure regions, though the guide, which was last updated on Oct. 7, includes a note that states "At this time Trusted Signing is available to organizations and DBAs based in the USA and Canada that have a verifiable history of three years or more." Dark Reading contacted Microsoft for comment but a company spokesperson said the company had nothing further to add. It appears Microsoft did not report the malicious activity to the other certificate authorities cited in its post. A DigiCert spokesperson provided the following statement to Dark Reading: "DigiCert is aware of Microsoft’s report on the Rhysida ransomware campaign. At this time, we have not been asked to revoke any DigiCert-issued certificates related to this report. We take any potential certificate misuse seriously and will act immediately to investigate and, if warranted, revoke certificates upon receipt of credible intelligence or a formal request from appropriate parties." GlobalSign provided a similar statement to Dark Reading from CISO Arvid Vermote. "GlobalSign ensures that all the certificates it issues are issued to rightful and verified (third) parties," "If GlobalSign receives notice or detects a compromise/misuse of a certificate it is investigated by a 24/7 team of experts," Vermote said. "In the case of abuse, key compromise or if malware signing is confirmed, the certificates are promptly revoked in line with industry regulations and requirements." Related: Verizon: Mobile Blindspot Leads to Needless Data Breaches Dark Reading contacted SSL.com but the company has not responded at press time. About the Author Rob Wright Senior News Director, Dark Reading Rob Wright is a longtime reporter and senior news director for Informa TechTarget's security team. He is based in the Boston area. Dark Reading
Fri, 17 Oct 2025 16:23:40 GMT
Discusses security risks in agentic AI, including prompt injection and data exfiltration via improper access controls. Highlights shared responsibility between vendors and customers. No specific vulnerabilities or threat actors detailed. Vendor responses include MFA and secrets scanning, but effectiveness is questioned.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/ai-agent-security-awareness-responsibility
[AI Agent Security][Shared Responsibility][Prompt Injection][Data Exfiltration][CVE-2025-XXXX][Good Read for Threat Actors: 1B+ potential data exposure]
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics AI Agent Security: Whose Responsibility Is It? AI Agent Security: Whose Responsibility Is It? AI Agent Security: Whose Responsibility Is It? The shared responsibility model of data security, familiar from cloud deployments, is key to agentic services, but cybersecurity teams and corporate users often struggle with awareness and managing that risk. October 17, 2025 Agentic AI deployments are becoming an imperative for organizations of all sizes looking to boost productivity and streamline processes, especially as major platforms like Microsoft and Salesforce build agents into their offerings. In the rush to deploy and use these helpers, it's important that businesses understand that there's a shared security responsibility between vendor and customer that will be critical to the success of any agentic AI project. The stakes in ignoring security are potentially high: last month for instance, AI security vendor Noma detailed how it discovered "ForcedLeak," a critical severity vulnerability chain in Salesforce's agentic AI offering Agentforce, which could have allowed a threat actor to exfiltrate sensitive CRM data from a customer with improper security controls through an indirect prompt injection attack. Although Salesforce addressed the issue through updates and access control recommendations, ForcedLeak is but one example of the potential for agents to leak sensitive data, either through improper access controls, ingested secrets, or a prompt injection attack. It's not an easy task to add agentic AI security to the mix; it's already challenging enough to determine where responsibility and culpability lie with traditional software and cloud deployments. With something like AI, where the technology can be hastily rolled out (by both vendor and customer alike) and is constantly evolving, establishing those barriers can prove even more complex. Related: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense Moreover, organizations are addressing other security awareness challenges like phishing, and have had to contend with determining the best way to offload as much risk as possible from the user, rather than relying on said user to catch every single malicious email. For phishing, that may take the form of physical FIDO keys and secure email gateways. This is similarly relevant for AI agents, which are imperfect autonomous processes that users may rely on to access sensitive information, or grant excessive permissions, or use to route insecure processes without proper oversight. Training users on how to use — or not use — their agent helpers is thus just one more layer of difficulty for security teams. Who Is Responsible for My AI Agents? Shared responsibility is a complex issue. On one hand, software vendors have long been criticized for putting too much of the security burden onto users while facing little to no culpability for selling insecure products. On the other, if an organization neglects basic security hygiene, it may not be fair to blame the vendor. Related: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks Itay Ravia, head of Aim Labs at Aim Security (an AI security vendor that previously disclosed a Copilot data exfiltration exploit dubbed "EchoLeak"), tells Dark Reading that in an ideal world, an AI agent would have gone through rigorous security testing. But the AI boom has created a "race to make AI smarter, stronger, and more capable at the expense of security." Ravia says agentic AI customers must take ownership of their security posture by ensuring the right guardrails are in place. Varonis field chief technology officer (CTO) Brian Vecci explains that the first thing to understand is, data isn't stored in an AI agent directly, but rather within the enterprise data repositories that agents are granted access to. "That access control can be individual to the agent or the user(s) that are prompting it, and it's the responsibility of the enterprise — not the agent's vendor or the hyperscaler provider — to secure that data appropriately," he says. "The shared responsibility model of data security is core to cloud and agentic services, and customers often struggle with managing that risk." Melissa Ruzzi, director of AI at AppOmni, says that keeping data secure for AI agents should be considered akin to keeping data secure in software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications . Related: Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice "The provider is responsible for the security of the infrastructure itself, and the customer is responsible for securing the data and users," she says. "The most important aspect to understand in AI applications is about the data flow and access, such as where data is coming from, where it’s going and who has access to it. Just because the data is being used by AI does not mean that a rigorous security review process can be skipped." Though Ravia, Vecci, and Ruzzi offer different perspectives on the responsibility angle, together they paint a larger, more complex picture. As data is stored separately from the AI agent, it's up to the user to ensure proper data security controls are in place when they hand over the keys to a non-human user. That said, vendors selling AI should ensure all measures are in place to limit the potential for an agent to leak sensitive data, a responsibility where some vendors falter. Security Awareness: Saving AI Users From Themselves Regardless of who's to blame, AI-powered data exposures happen often enough that, like in the case of phishing, it's worth asking whether AI vendors should begin to protect customers from themselves with things like mandatory multifactor authentication (MFA) and secrets scanning. Though by no means an industry standard, there are instances of such things happening; a Salesforce spokesperson tells Dark Reading that the company now requires all customers to use MFA with Salesforce products. Aim Security's Ravia says that although in recent months large vendors have begun to take their first steps toward deploying such protections, "unfortunately, they are still well behind attackers and do not account for novel bypass methods ." And, as Varonis' Vecci puts it, vendors like Salesforce and Microsoft that offer built-in AI agents can only secure perimeters. David Brauchler, technical director and head of AI and machine learning security at consultancy NCC Group, tells Dark Reading that while responsibility for applying proper authentication and authorization controls falls on the organization using the agent, and the vendor is responsible for providing appropriate tools to enable the customer to manage access to AI systems — this is where it gets murky, from a user-awareness perspective. "AI vendors may reasonably enforce certain security best practices, but none of the tools available to vendors fundamentally solve the underlying data access problem," he says. "Tools like secrets scanning and [data loss prevention] often lead to a false sense of security and a greater proliferation of vulnerabilities, resulting from a 'the vendor will handle it' thought process. These problems fundamentally cannot be solved within the agentic model itself and need to be handled by the architecture of the customer’s AI infrastructure." Bottom line? There have plenty of issues with the rollout of the AI in the past few years , and issues with how agentic AI products in particular are deployed into customer environments. So before an organization decides to invest in an agent or other LLM products to become an "AI winner," it should put security first. The organization should know what data the agents have access to, ensure best practices and guardrails are in place, and have a full understanding of the risks of using the AI product and mitigating any risks. Read more about: About the Author Alexander Culafi Senior News Writer, Dark Reading Alex is an award-winning writer, journalist, and podcast host based in Boston. After cutting his teeth writing for independent gaming publications as a teenager, he graduated from Emerson College in 2016 with a Bachelor of Science in journalism. He has previously been published on VentureFizz, Search Security, Nintendo World Report, and elsewhere. In his spare time, Alex hosts the weekly Nintendo podcast Talk Nintendo Podcast and works on personal writing projects, including two previously self-published science fiction novels.
