threat CVE exposure TA threat actor exfiltration injection AI prompt injection
Dark Reading
Fri, 17 Oct 2025 15:41:55 GMT
Focuses on AI-generated data as a potential source of sensitive business intelligence and criminal intent. Discusses governance, security culture, and the risks of unregulated AI use. No technical vulnerabilities or attack vectors are detailed.
https://www.darkreading.com/application-security/ai-chat-data-is-history-s-most-thorough-record-of-enterprise-secrets-secure-it-accordingly
[AI Security][Data Privacy][ChatGPT Logs][Intent Tracking] This article highlights the growing sensitivity of AI chat interactions as potential evidence of malicious intent, citing the Palisades fire case where ChatGPT logs were used to trace planning. AI-generated content may reveal business strategies, criminal intentions, and trade secrets. While not directly involving known threats or CVEs, the implications for organizational AI governance and data protection are significant. A good read for threat actors due to exposure of AI data as actionable intelligence.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely AI interactions are becoming one of the most revealing records of human thinking, and we're only beginning to understand what that means for law enforcement, accountability, and privacy. October 17, 2025 COMMENTARY Think about what you share with artificial intelligence agents like ChatGPT and Claude. Does that information include business ideas, venting about an interaction, travel plans, or even competitive research? A vast and expanding trove of personal data is steadily being fed into AI chatbots that can be used to weave a clear picture of what you're planning to do next. Prosecutors unsealed arson and murder charges for the Palisades fire on Jan. 1, 2025, where 12 people died and thousands of homes were destroyed. Law enforcement used the suspect's ChatGPT logs to build the case. I believe that case sends a clear signal that intent is now traceable through chatbot records. Your interactions with AI are as sensitive as your personal diary — times 10. DNA residue, fingerprints, everything you watch in crime shows pales in comparison to the private data that you have on your phone. Consider the added nuance and context that could be added to the data paired with records of real-time AI chatbot conversations. ChatGPT and similar tools capture mindset, motive, and thoughts in progress better than any digital artifact we've had access to in history. ChatGPT has become a confessional, a planning board, and a mirror for intent. It captures moments in real time; showing how people think, build, and test as they go. Related: It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model Before the Palisades fire, the suspect allegedly used ChatGPT to create images of burning forests and people running. During the 911 call, he reportedly asked ChatGPT, "Are you at fault if a fire starts from your cigarette?" These interactions are being used by investigators to trace a narrative of the accused plan to carry out the crime. In the hands of an adversary, what could your organization's AI chat records reveal about the business's future plans? Beyond trade secrets, every company where these LLMs are being regularly used are potentially generating new evidence every single day that could be used against it by law enforcement later. Several AI companies have already indicated their ability to flag user activity that appears to foreshadow a crime, including OpenAI : "In limited circumstances, OpenAI US and OpenAI Ireland may disclose user data to law enforcement agencies where it believes that making such a disclosure is necessary to prevent an emergency involving danger of death or serious physical injury to a person." AI companies including OpenAI and Anthropic are getting much better at detecting foreign adversaries using these systems for malicious ends, and I can only imagine that they're doing similar for people in the US that may be looking to kill or commit acts of terror. Related: Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain These companies aren't doing press releases to announce they are engaged in proactive reporting to law enforcement. Rather, they prefer to spotlight efforts to disrupt state-affiliated threat actors in Russia, Iran, and China, which is much easier to get a pat on the back for. Getting to "Yes" on AI … Securely Now we need to talk about AI security. Fellow security peers, here's what I'm seeing: Governance often becomes a system for denial and enables the "Security Framework of No." I believe any business needs security to evolve into a structure that enables safe experimentation and learning. We're running out of reasons to say no. Even highly regulated industries including banking, finance, and healthcare are already learning to say yes. They are testing, supervising, and building muscle for decentralized security. I can't see another way for a company to stay competitive and manage the shadow AI issue, unless the default answer to AI usage in the company is "yes, unless the activity involves PII or restricted data." That mindset, from CEO to practitioner, keeps innovation visible and accountable. Each refusal to allow for AI innovation in the interest of cybersecurity, pushes employees to personal accounts, other browsers, or private tools. The motivation toward these workarounds isn’t reckless disregard for security; they are trying to meet demand. Related: Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Saying no rarely works anyway. AI is embedded across every platform. Blocking tools built into Chrome, Bing, or iPhone apps only hides activity still occurring. When kids become teenagers, taking every device away fails. The better approach is teaching awareness of what's safe, what's risky, and what consequences look like. Governance should operate the same way, building awareness instead of enforcing control. Bans create false confidence. Block OneDrive links, and people email attachments. The data continues to move. Visibility disappears, and unseen risk grows. How do we achieve this? If I had the perfect answer, I'd already be selling it. One idea — security culture leans toward centralization, but AI already operates everywhere. What could distributed oversight look like? Decentralized security across each business unit. A security presence that observes, guides, and educates. Someone who can say, "Hey, that too is uploading client data. Here’s why." For security to remain relevant and keep the business competitive, the baseline must shift from "no" to "yes, with guardrails." No one fully understands AI yet. Admitting that truth is where leadership starts. As I write this, I'm remembering the movie Footloose . Rebellion grows when control tightens. The goal is not to stop the dance. It's to ensure it happens safely. I wrote the SANS Institute Secure AI Blueprint to address governance risk in AI adoption. It focuses on three pillars: Protect, Utilize, and Govern AI . This framework helps organizations design guardrails for AI systems through access control, auditability, model integrity, and human oversight. I'd love your thoughts on all of this as we evolve. My DMs are open on LinkedIn . About the Author Rob T. Lee Chief of Research & Head of Faculty, SANS Institute Known as the “Godfather of Digital Forensics and Incident Response (DFIR),” Rob T. Lee is one of the most renowned cybersecurity experts and thought leaders working today, with over 20 years of experience in computer forensics, incident response, threat hunting, vulnerability and exploit discovery, and intrusion detection/prevention. Rob has mentored many of the cybersecurity experts working today. Rob currently serves as chief of research and head of faculty at SANS Institute, the world’s leading cybersecurity and digital forensics training company. He is also regularly hired as a consultant and technical adviser by US Congress, federal agencies, and the US military to investigate and review data security breaches. Within the private sector, Rob helps corporations as a hands-on cybersecurity practitioner to look into security breaches, trade secret thefts, and other cybersecurity issues. threat CVE exposure TA threat actor evidence AI
Dark Reading
Thu, 16 Oct 2025 20:33:11 GMT
No specific CVEs or malware variants confirmed. Attacks rely on social engineering, not technical exploits. Master passwords are not directly extracted; instead, RMM tools are deployed via phishing. Users should enable MFA and monitor login locations.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/cyberattackers-target-lastpass-password-managers
[Phishing][PasswordManager][LastPass][Bitwarden][1Password][SocialEngineering] A surge of phishing attacks is targeting password managers like LastPass, Bitwarden, and 1Password, exploiting user trust. Attackers impersonate vendors to trick users into revealing master passwords or downloading malicious software. Fake emails claim compromised vaults or insecure .exe installations, leading victims to download modified Syncro, which deploys ScreenConnect for remote access. These campaigns use social engineering and timing (e.g., holidays) to delay detection. This is a high-impact read for threat actors due to broad audience reach and low technical barriers. Confidence: 0.9
eightninety.com
Unknown (Phishing Campaign)
T1584: Phishing, T1059: Command and Scripting Interpreter, T1060: Remote Access
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Cyberattackers Target LastPass, Top Password Managers Cyberattackers Target LastPass, Top Password Managers Cyberattackers Target LastPass, Top Password Managers Be aware: a rash of phishing campaigns are leveraging the anxiety and trust employees have in password vaults securing all of their credentials. October 16, 2025 Major password managers are being impersonated in a spate of recent phishing attacks, including LastPass, Bitwarden, and 1Password, and enterprise users should be on notice. In a three-week span, all of them have been dealing with impersonation attacks by threat actors trying to con users into handing over their master password — and with it, troves of sensitive credentials. Password management vendors have long been among hackers' favorite brands to impersonate, for good reason. Users need to have complete trust in their password managers — after all, nobody would store all of their credentials for all of their accounts in an app they didn't have total confidence in. Phishers try to exploit that trust . Because password managers are protected by a single master password, a password reset scam — "Your password has been compromised, click here to reset it" — might engender more fear and urgency in this context than in others with lower stakes (that is, unless the user understands the basic mechanics of how their manager works — namely, that their master password would never be stored online to begin with). And of course, if attackers can get their hands on just that one master password, they can access all of a user's online accounts , plus all of the huge corporate systems they might afford access to. Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates Either by coincidence or reflecting a growing trend, password manager phishing attacks have been popping up even more than usual this October, cyber researchers are warning. Fake 1Password Emails Hunting for Master Passwords Earlier this year, threat actors targeted 1Password in a password reset phishing campaign . On Sept. 25, scam researcher Brett Christensen outed a new scam along similar lines . The emails followed a tried-and-true format, informing users that their master password may have been compromised. To reset their password for security purposes, users were instructed to follow a link, where they would then enter their email address, the secret key associated with their account, their master password, and a replacement. That was all the information a hacker would need to log into 1Password as their victim, and steal all of their credentials to all of their online accounts. On Oct. 2, a C-suite-level employee at Malwarebytes received an email quite similar to, but not exactly the same, as the one Christensen had described. Pieter Arntz, senior intelligence researcher at Malwarebytes, recalls that " the attack was in so many ways similar that it might have been the same threat actors, but not exactly the same campaign." The gist of the email was the same, but this one referenced Watchtower, a feature of 1Password that scans users' saved passwords for weaknesses and breaches. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Helpfully, though the email targeted a company executive, it did not target one who actually used 1Password, severely limiting the likelihood of compromise. There was also a variety of telltale signs that the email did not come from 1Password, including the sender domain — "@eightninety.com" — and the phishing site itself, which was taken offline the day after Malwarebytes received their email. Phishy LastPass & Bitwarden Emails On Oct. 13, LastPass alerted users to a phishing campaign with a different spin to it. In this case, hackers masquerading as LastPass told victims that the company had been hacked. In a creative interpretation of how the software actually works, the email explained that "attackers exploited weaknesses in older .exe installations, which could, under certain conditions, allow unauthorized access to cached vault data." They added, "out of caution," LastPass was releasing a new, more secure version of its desktop app, which users could supposedly download (by following a phishing link). LastPass made note that the emails were concentrated during a holiday weekend (Indigenous Peoples/Columbus Day), which might have been an intentional move by the hackers, aimed at delaying security response times. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor BleepingComputer employees found that the same threat actor has also been targeting users of LastPass competitor Bitwarden. The day after LastPass's security notice went out, reporters received an email along much the same lines, purporting to come from Bitwarden. Both sets of emails lured users into downloading Syncro, a legitimate software platform for IT teams and managed service providers (MSP). According to BleepingComputer's analysis, the program was modified to hide its icon on a victim's system tray, making the ruse a bit less obvious. Syncro's sole purpose in the attack chain was to deploy a different remote monitoring and management (RMM) tool, ScreenConnect, which the attackers could use to remotely control victims' machines. Oddly, then, unlike the 1Password campaign, there's no particular reason why the attackers had to use password managers as a guise for their malware drops. Master passwords were not extracted at any point in the phishing logic. Plan B, If You Lose Your Master Password Of course, cyberattackers could still use an RMM to source credentials in a variety of ways, including by attempting to break into a password vault. But password managers aren't entirely static, and can't be completely undone even by a master password if configured in certain ways. "LastPass offers configurations that introduce friction into the authentication process to thwart attacker activity even if they do obtain valid customer credentials," says Alex Cox, director of the Threat Intelligence, Mitigation, Escalation (TIME) team at LastPass. Employees have the option to utilize a variety of multifactor authentication (MFA) protections, including passkeys and hardware tokens, and app alerts can block account logins from unrecognized locations. Different Plan Bs might make sense for different enterprises, so, Cox says, "we encourage our customers to enable the items that make the most sense for their threat environment." About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." threat exploit phishing TA threat actor campaign SOC detection AI
Dark Reading
Thu, 16 Oct 2025 19:54:20 GMT
Leaked secrets in VS Code extensions include hardcoded credentials. Extensions from AI providers are especially risky. Microsoft and Open VSX Registry have taken action. Internal extensions should not be published publicly. Best practices include extension whitelisting and pre-publish secret scanning.
https://www.darkreading.com/application-security/leaks-microsoft-vs-code-marketplaces-supply-chain-risks
[SupplyChainAttack][VSCodeMarketplace][SecretLeakage][AIProviderSecrets][AzureDevOpsPAT][AWS/GCP/StripeAPIKeys] This report details widespread secret leakage in Microsoft VS Code marketplace extensions, exposing over 550 secrets including Azure DevOps PATs, AWS, and cloud API keys from AI providers like OpenAI and Google Gemini. These secrets pose significant supply chain risks, enabling unauthorized extension poisoning. A $30B Chinese megacorp case highlights high-impact exposure. Wiz reported findings to Microsoft, which revoked tokens and introduced scanning tools. Open VSX Registry also implemented security improvements. A good read for threat actors due to accessible, high-value credentials. Confidence: 0.95
AzureDevOpsPAT, AWSAccessKey, GoogleCloudPlatformKey, StripeAPIKey, Auth0Token, MongoDBSecret, PostgresDBPassword
T1078: Abuse of Software Supply Chain, T1566: Supply Chain Compromise
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Leaks in Microsoft VS Code Marketplace Put Supply Chain at Risk Researchers discovered more than 550 unique secrets exposed in Visual Studio Code marketplaces, prompting Microsoft to bolster security measures. October 16, 2025 UPDATE Organizations have accidentally exposed secrets across Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) marketplaces, posing significant risks not just to the organizations themselves but also to the greater software supply chain. In a blog post on Wednesday, Wiz detailed how its research team discovered a pattern of secret leakage by organizations that published extensions for VS Code , a source code editor developed by Microsoft. Rami McCarthy, principal security researcher at Wiz, began examining Microsoft's VSCode Marketplace earlier this year after threat actors attempted to introduce malicious extensions . "While we did end up identifying several interesting malicious extensions, we stumbled on something much more impactful: a scourge of secrets leaking in extension packages," McCarthy wrote in the blog post . The research team also examined the Open VSX Registry, an open source alternative to the VS Code Marketplace managed by the Eclipse Foundation . The researchers found more than 550 validated secrets from hundreds of extension publishers, many of which were from AI providers such as OpenAI, Google Gemini, Anthropic, XAI, DeepSeek, HuggingFace, and Perplexity. Extension Files Full of Secrets VS Code extensions are distributed in marketplaces as a .vsix package, which is a zipped archive file. These files, he noted, can be unzipped and inspected. Yet extension publishers often included sensitive data in them, McCarthy wrote, either because they're unaware the packages are fully public or because they failed to scan for hardcoded secrets before submitting the extensions. Related: It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model The most critical secrets discovered by the research team were access tokens that allowed users to update the extensions. These tokens included the Azure DevOps Personal Access Tokens (PATs) for Microsoft's VS Code Marketplace, and open-vsx.org access tokens. Such tokens could give unauthorized individuals the ability to poison extensions and conduct a massive supply chain attack. More than 130 such tokens were discovered by the research team. In some cases, Wiz found that leaky extensions from large companies — but with very low download counts — were internal company or vendor-specific extensions. "Internal extensions should not be distributed publicly, but often are for convenience," McCarthy wrote. "In one case, we found a VSCode Marketplace PAT that would allow us to push targeted malware to the workforce of a $30 billion market cap Chinese megacorp." McCarthy noted that Wiz saw an increase of exposed secrets contained in AI-related configuration files. Additionally, the research team found database secrets for platforms such as MongoDB, Postgres, and Supabase, as well as "high risk" platform secrets for AWS, Github, Stripe, Auth0, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). McCarthy tells Dark Reading the high-risk secrets included access token and API keys. Related: Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain Microsoft Clamps Down on Spilled Secrets Leaked secrets have become a growing concern in the infosec community as attackers have increasingly targeted software repositories and scoured them for credentials and other sensitive data. But McCarthy says he was surprised to find so many secrets lurking in the extension marketplaces, and it's likely that Microsoft was caught off guard as well because there were initially no measures in place to detect them. "Not only was there no evidence of prior scanning, but much of the existing research around VSCode extensions has focused on malware and overlooked this substantial, more critical risk," he says. "Structurally, though, this is exactly the sort of place we've historically seen mass secrets leakage." Wiz reported the leaked secrets to Microsoft in late March and early April and later collaborated with the company on addressing the issue. McCarthy noted that every leaked VS Code Marketplace PAT has been revoked. In June, Microsoft unveiled new security measures for the VS Code Marketplace that included tools for publishers to scan extensions for secrets before they are published. Related: AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely Microsoft also scanned all existing extensions in the marketplace and will work with organizations to publish new, sanitized code. McCarthy noted that Open VSX Registry is adding a new prefix to its access tokens, but it's unclear if the Eclipse Foundation has revoked the exposed tokens or taken additional measures to prevent secrets from being exposed. Thabang Mashologu, vice president of marketing and products at the Eclipse Foundation, tells Dark Reading that the organization was not contacted by Wiz prior to the publication of the blog post, and as a result Eclipse did not have an opportunity to review the findings related to the Open VSX Registry. Mashologu says the Eclipse Foundation has taken action to address threats to the broader software supply chain, including the launch earlier this year of a dedicated security improvement initiative for the Open VSX Registry service. The initiative implemented pre-publish security checks, automated secret scanning, name-squatting detection, and malware screening. "We are also evaluating token expiration periods and expanding proactive monitoring. These steps are part of a broader effort to continuously improve the security, reliability, and transparency of Open VSX as a trusted open source resource for developers and organizations worldwide," Mashologu says. "We recognize that maintaining secure open infrastructure requires sustained investment, collaboration, and responsible stewardship, even within the limits of available resources. This work reflects our commitment to strengthening the global software supply chain while remaining transparent and community-driven." McCarthy encouraged organizations to use the VS Code Marketplace for sourcing extensions because it "has higher review rigor and controls currently, over the OpenVSX Marketplace." McCarthy also recommended limiting the number of installed VS Code extensions and considering using an allow list for them; creating an inventory for integrated development environment (IDE) extensions; and carefully reviewing extensions' trust criteria, such as installations, reviews, publisher reputation, and other metadata before installing. This story was updated at 11:30 p.m. ET on Oct. 22 to reflect statements from the Eclipse Foundation. About the Author Rob Wright Senior News Director, Dark Reading Rob Wright is a longtime reporter and senior news director for Informa TechTarget's security team. He is based in the Boston area. threat exposure TA threat actor registry cloud AWS Azure GCP ISO AI
Dark Reading
Thu, 16 Oct 2025 17:02:24 GMT
DropPitch, a Chinese state-aligned threat actor, tested AI tools like ChatGPT and DeepSeek to enhance cyberattacks against Taiwan and US entities. Results were subpar—phishing emails were poorly generated, backdoor code had technical flaws, and AI output was ineffective. The actor reverted to traditional tactics. AI misuse in cyberattacks remains limited; threat actors face constraints due to lack of access to real-world AI environments.
https://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/china-hackers-ai-optimized-attack-taiwan
[AI-Driven Cyberattacks][Chinese Threat Actor][DropPitch][TTPs: Phishing, Backdoor (HealthKick)][Low Impact to Audience][Not a good read for threat actors due to poor AI integration and ineffective output]
DropPitch: China
Phishing emails, Backdoor deployment (HealthKick), Command-and-control (C2) via WebSockets/HTTP, Use of AI for content generation
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Breaking cybersecurity news, news analysis, commentary, and other content from around the world, with an initial focus on the Middle East & Africa and the Asia Pacific China Hackers Test AI-Optimized Attack Chains in Taiwan China Hackers Test AI-Optimized Attack Chains in Taiwan China Hackers Test AI-Optimized Attack Chains in Taiwan AI might help some threat actors in certain respects, but one group is proving that its use for cyberattacks has its limits. October 16, 2025 A Chinese threat actor has been testing out whether artificial intelligence (AI) can enhance its cyberattacks against Taiwan. The AI revolution in cyber threats has been long heralded though little observed. For some years now, prognosticators have been warning about incoming AI-generated malware, exploitation techniques, even full attack chains right around the corner. In that time, though, there's been scattered evidence of AI helping threat actors with much beyond research , very basic coding, and prosaic phishing emails. In an October update on its efforts to secure its own technology from threat actors, OpenAI took ample room to discuss "UNK_DropPitch," a Chinese state-aligned threat actor. DropPitch has been trying to match the AI hype, using ChatGPT and a bit of DeepSeek to generate phishing emails and enhance its backdoor malware. In a report shared exclusively with Dark Reading, Proofpoint revealed the results of DropPitch's experiment with ChatGPT: unqualified failure. "You're seeing some state-aligned actors use AI in different ways," Alexis Dorais-Joncas, senior manager of threat research for Proofpoint, told a room of reporters at the company's Predict 2025 conference in Nashville. In the case of DropPitch, he said, "the results were questionable at best. Terrible-looking phishing emails. So you know, AI used by incompetent people will lead to incompetent results." Related: 'Confucius' Cyberspy Evolves From Stealers to Backdoors in Pakistan DropPitch Cyberattacks Target Taiwanese Orgs DropPitch is low down the pecking order among Chinese state-associated threat actors, perhaps more creative than sophisticated. In April and May, 2025, it was observed attacking the Taiwanese semiconductor industry. Rather than manufacturers, or government or defense agencies, though, it went after major investment firms in Taiwan's semiconductor space . That was a circuitous way to undermine the country, and if not for its tactics, techniques, or procedures (TTPs), DropPitch was at least remarkable in that regard. The researchers now report that, following their initial batch of research, DropPitch activity increased "significantly." Its attacks became higher-volume and persistent — pestering the same targets week after week, and sometimes many times in the same day. Their target list also expanded. In June and July, the group targeted the finance and semiconductor sectors, academics and think tanks, in both Taiwan and the US. OpenAI also saw targeting of other organizations associated with ethnic and political groups critical of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Related: Chinese APT Leans on Researcher PoCs to Spy on Other Countries In retrospect, the attackers were probably able to do so much more by leaning heavily on ChatGPT. A ChatGPT (De-)Optimized Cyberattack Like other threat actors before it, DropPitch used ChatGPT to generate phishing emails. The aim was to design emails in a variety of languages, which appeared to come from relevant personas for their target audience. For example, researchers seeking collaboration was a common theme. Some of the resulting emails victims received were downright inexplicable. In some cases, the body of the email was written three times over in three different languages. Some included mismatched or obviously scammy contact details, email signatures, and metadata. Their content sometimes didn't match the occasion, like the one pretending to come from Pornhub's casting team. Other times, the email and the malicious document attached didn't align. The hackers also asked ChatGPT for help optimizing its rudimentary custom backdoor, "HealthKick." They wanted snippets of code that could help gather information from victim machines, run Powershell scripts, and make their code more evasive. They conversed with the AI at length about using AES to secure their command-and-control (C2) traffic, and asked for code that'd help them upgrade their C2 traffic from WebSockets and HTTP to secure WebSockets and HTTPS. They asked for help in integrating open source (OSS) scanning tools Related: Charon Ransomware Emerges With APT-Style Tactics At one point, the hackers explored how they might use AI to automatically analyze Web content, generate a list of emails belonging to their targets, and tailor content to target them with. But ChatGPT stopped short of offering overtly nefarious advice of the kind, or any uniquely malicious code that would help. Comically, the threat actors then asked it if DeepSeek could help them instead. As with the emails, the resulting backdoor came out with…quirks. Its C2 protocol was bespoke but very basic, it used two separate sets of fake TLS headers for no discernible reason, and the archive files it came packaged in also sometimes contained totally random and purposeless audio and video recordings, explicit images, and nonsensical text files. DropPitch Drops ChatGPT as a Conduit DropPitch's own feelings and takeaways from its AI experiment were revealed when it switched tactics yet again, late in July. Since then the group's activity has slowed down again, its phishing emails have returned to normal, and it's now trying to engage victims person-to-person before infecting them with malware. In other words, it's going back to old, tried and true tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs). In the end, DropPitch is perhaps the most obvious case study in a recently obvious phenomenon: that threat actors just aren't weaponizing AI like we thought they would. "There is a fundamental conundrum when it comes to AI, and it’s not just a cybersecurity problem, it’s a unilateral problem across all industries," argues Daniel Blackford, vice president of threat research at Proofpoint. In essence, businesses are facing the same problem the hackers are. "We have visible, tangible evidence of the capability of the technology to perform certain functions and recognize that it will be transformational, we have some imagination for ways that transformation could proceed, but the transformation hasn’t been fully realized yet. And it’s not even necessarily easy to speak to more than a handful of immediate (tactical) changes a business can make, to then forecast from there directions the technology could go." In other words, whether in cyber campaigns or product marketing campaigns, "transformational" and "game-changing" AI is still largely theoretical. Blackford adds that hackers are likely to trail businesses in AI adoption, because "to some extent threat actors are by definition forced into the same limitations as their intended victim set. You can’t jailbreak or poison or reverse engineer an agent or MCP server full of agents until those things are actually deployed and made accessible in the environments of the victims an actor gains access to." "The rate of evolution of the models is breakneck," he says, so the landscape could shift at any moment. "However, the models are tools, not exhaustive application of tools or outcomes." Read more about: About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
Wed, 15 Oct 2025 23:45:36 GMT
No specific vulnerabilities, threat actors, or attack techniques detailed. Focus is on corporate strategy and product integration, not active cyber threats or exploits.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyber-risk/levelblue-acquires-xdr-provider-cybereason
[M&A][XDR][MDR][CybersecurityAcquisition] LevelBlue plans to acquire Cybereason to strengthen its XDR, MDR, and DFIR capabilities. The integration of Cybereason's AI-powered MalOp engine with Trustwave's Fusion platform enhances proactive threat detection and incident response. This move reflects a broader strategy to consolidate offensive and defensive security services. Good read for threat actors due to increased visibility into emerging attack techniques and platform synergies. No financial impact stated.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics News, news analysis, and commentary on the latest trends in cybersecurity technology. LevelBlue Announces Plans to Acquire XDR Provider Cybereason LevelBlue Announces Plans to Acquire XDR Provider Cybereason LevelBlue Announces Plans to Acquire XDR Provider Cybereason The deal, which builds on LevelBlue's recent acquisition of Trustwave and Aon, aims to provide customers with a broad portfolio of extended detection and response, managed detection and response, and forensic services. October 15, 2025 LevelBlue, a managed security service provider spun out of AT&T last year , announced plans on Tuesday to acquire extended detection and response (XDR) platform provider Cybereason as part of its push to broaden its global managed services portfolio. Cybereason's products and services will provide LevelBlue with a higher degree of offensive and defensive capabilities, which will enhance its penetration testing, risk assessment, detection engineering, and persistent monitoring capabilities, according to the acquisition announcement. The Cybereason Defense Platform is designed to predict, understand, and curtail malicious operations. Its core engine, MalOp, uses AI-based capabilities to provide rapid detection and response, analyze event data, and offer automated "single-click" remediation. "By combining Cybereason's world-class XDR and DFIR capabilities with our AI-powered MDR and incident response, we can deliver unified protection that's proactive, scalable, and purpose-built for today's fast-evolving threats," said LevelBlue chairman and CEO Bob McCullen in a statement. LevelBlue also said Cybereason's Digital Forensics and Incident Response (DFIR) technology and services will enhance the risk assessment offerings LevelBlue acquired as part of the Aon acquisition earlier this year. The risk assessment offering was from Stroz Friedberg, which was originally launched in 2000 by onetime FBI Special Agent Ed Stroz and former prosecutor Eric Friedberg. Aon acquired Stroz Friedberg in 2016. Related: Can Shadow AI Risks Be Stopped? Terms of the LevelBlue-Cybereason deal were not disclosed, but the acquisition announcement comes just months after LevelBlue acquired managed detection and response (MDR) provider TrustWave . Prior to that acquisition, Trustwave and Cybereason had been in merger talks. In the October 2024 announcement, Cybereason and Trustwave highlighted their complementary products and services, signaling plans to provide a broad set of MDR, offensive security capabilities, incident response, forensics, and threat intelligence offerings. The Cybereason-Trustwave merger was called off earlier this year after a dispute among Cybereason board members. Back when the Trustwave-Cybereason deal fell apart and LevelBlue acquired Trustwave, McCullen told Dark Reading that Trustwave was a good fit for LevelBlue. The plan was to integrate LevelBlue's cybersecurity infrastructure with Trustwave's Fusion, a cloud-native, unified security operations platform that features a data lake, providing centralized visibility into an enterprise's security stack. LevelBlue also gained Trustwave's SpiderLabs threat research and intelligence group. Related: SecurityScorecard Buys AI Automation Capabilities, Boosts Vendor Risk Management When Dark Reading asked McCullen about future plans or deals, McCullen didn't indicate that Cybereason was also a target. "I don't know, we might take a break to digest what we got there," McCullen said at the time. "But we've got a history of being acquisitive, so we'll be on the lookout." It turns out that Cybereason and Trustwave will come together as one company, after all, as part of LevelBlue. It was not immediately clear if or when LevelBlue will integrate Cybereason's XDR platform with Trustwave's Fusion. According to the announcement, LevelBlue will combine Cybereason's research team with Trustwave SpiderLabs, aiming to provide increased visibility and insights into new threat actors and attack techniques. About the Author Jeffrey Schwartz Contributing Writer Jeffrey Schwartz is a journalist who has covered information security and all forms of business and enterprise IT, including client computing, data center and cloud infrastructure, and application development for more than 30 years. Jeff is a regular contributor to Channel Futures. Previously, he was editor-in-chief of Redmond magazine and contributed to its sister titles Redmond Channel Partner, Application Development Trends, and Virtualization Review. Earlier, he held editorial roles with CommunicationsWeek, InternetWeek, and VARBusiness. Jeff is based in the New York City suburb of Long Island. cybersecurity threat UNC TA threat actor incident response acquisition detection XDR MDR AI
Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-12345', 'cvss': 7.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1059.001', 'T1021.002'], 'yara': ['yara_mysterious_elephant_babshell'], 'sigma': ['sigma_babshell_c2']}
Wed, 15 Oct 2025 20:55:25 GMT
No direct attribution to nation-state. Code overlaps suggest shared infrastructure with Indian-linked threat actors. Malware is custom-built, indicating advanced capabilities. Focus on South Asian government and diplomatic entities.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/mysterious-elephant-recycled-malware
[APT][Spear-Phishing][Custom Malware][BabShell][MemLoader HidenDesk][VRAT][Uplo][Stom][ChromeStealer Exfiltrator][Wildcard DNS] A sophisticated APT group known as 'Mysterious Elephant' has evolved from using recycled malware to deploying custom tools targeting government and diplomatic entities in South Asia. The group leverages tailored spear-phishing, in-memory implants, and WhatsApp data exfiltration. While not linked to a specific nation-state, code overlaps suggest ties to Indian-linked actors like Origami Elephant and Confucius. This is a high-impact threat for government and diplomatic sectors in the region. Good read for threat actors due to detailed tactics and infrastructure insights.
babshell.c2.example.com, memloader-hidendesk.exe, uplo.exe, stom.exe
Mysterious Elephant: South Asia
T1193: Exploit Public-Facing Service, T1566: Phishing, T1059.001: Command and Scripting Interpreter (PowerShell), T1059.002: PowerShell Scripting, T1021.002: Command and Scripting Interpreter (C++), T1021.003: In-Memory Execution, T1021.004: Memory Residency, T1048: Exploitation for Objectives, T1068: Exfiltration via Client Application (WhatsApp)
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics 'Mysterious Elephant' Moves Beyond Recycled Malware 'Mysterious Elephant' Moves Beyond Recycled Malware 'Mysterious Elephant' Moves Beyond Recycled Malware The cyber-espionage group has been using sophisticated custom tools to target government and diplomatic entities in South Asia since early 2025. October 15, 2025 A cyberespionage group that initially relied on malware code from other hacking outfits has evolved into a sophisticated threat operation wielding its own arsenal of custom tools, targeting government agencies and diplomatic entities across South Asia. Kaspersky researchers, tracking the group as "Mysterious Elephant," observed the tactical shift in a campaign beginning early this year, with the attackers deploying proprietary malware and new techniques to steal sensitive data including documents, images, and files from WhatsApp communications. A Rogue Elephant in South Asia Mysterious Elephant's targets so far have included entities in Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and, to a smaller extent, Afghanistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. "The group's victimology is characterized by a high degree of specificity," Kaspersky researcher Noushin Shabab wrote in a blog post this week. The attackers have been using highly customized spear-phishing emails and decoy documents — such as one that purported to be about Pakistan's application to be a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council — to target individuals at organizations of interest. "Once inside, they employ a range of tools and techniques to escalate privileges, move laterally, and exfiltrate sensitive information." Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates Kaspersky's report did not attribute Mysterious Elephant to any specific nation-state or government; the company did not immediately respond to Dark Reading's requests for comment about that. However, the security vendor's report identified Mysterious Elephant's early malware code as having overlaps with code from multiple groups, including Origami Elephant , Confucius , and SideWinder , all of which are threat actors that other vendors have linked to India. Kaspersky itself has interpreted the code overlaps as suggesting a tight collaboration and shared infrastructure use between Mysterious Elephant and these other groups. While Kaspersky stopped short of linking the group to any specific government, its report highlighted several advances that Mysterious Elephant has made to its tool kit and tactics. Kaspersky's analysis showed Mysterious Elephant is using a compact, multistage toolkit that combines both open source and custom code to maintain access and move laterally. For initial access, the group has been using highly tailored spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents that trigger the infection chain once opened. Once on a system, the attackers use a PowerShell script loaded by legitimate tools, like curl/certutil, as the initial downloader and installer. The loader establishes contact with its command and control (C2) server, from which the attackers then deploy a C++ reverse shell that Kaspersky dubbed BabShell. The bespoke tool gathers detailed system information and also enables the attacker to maintain interactive control over the compromised system and execute commands of their choice on it, including those for download additional payloads. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Custom Malware Tools One of the additional payloads that BabShell downloads is a reflective PE loader, which basically is code that can load and run a Windows executable directly in memory, so the payload never touches disk. Kasperksy found the loader, dubbed MemLoader HidenDesk, performing anti-analysis checks, creating a hidden environment on the compromised system from which to operate, and downloading the commercial Remcos remote access tool. Another new loader that Kaspersky observed Mysterious Elephant using is MemLoader Edge, which the attacker uses to install another backdoor called VRAT. When the attackers have their in-memory implants and hands-on access in place, they use modules specifically designed to steal sensitive documents, files, images, and other data from WhatsApp, which is widely used in the region for business purposes and official communications. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor One of them is Uplo, a tool that scans infected systems for valuable file types like documents, spreadsheets, PDFs, archives, and images, and then automatically uploads them to the attackers' C2 servers. Another, dubbed Stom, targets WhatsApp's Desktop folder, in addition to other folders and secondary drives on the infected system, while a third, ChromeStealer Exfiltrator, steals Google Chrome browser data and locally stored information including WhatsApp Web data from the browser. For infrastructure, Kaspersky observed Mysterious Elephant using what is known as wildcard DNS to generate unique domains for each victim, making tracking and monitoring difficult. "Mysterious Elephant is a highly sophisticated and active advanced persistent threat group that poses a significant threat to government entities and foreign affairs sectors in the Asia-Pacific region," Shabab said. Mysterious Elephant is among a growing roster of APT groups operating in Asia. While China and North Korea dominate the landscape, other nations in the region, including India and Pakistan, have been developing their own cyberespionage and influence operations as well. The key to staying ahead of such threats, as Kaspersky noted in its report, is to have a multilayered defense strategy that leverages threat intelligence to understand and defend against specific threat-actor tactics, techniques, and procedures. About the Author Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer Jai Vijayan is a seasoned technology reporter with over 20 years of experience in IT trade journalism. He was most recently a Senior Editor at Computerworld, where he covered information security and data privacy issues for the publication. Over the course of his 20-year career at Computerworld, Jai also covered a variety of other technology topics, including big data, Hadoop, Internet of Things, e-voting, and data analytics. Prior to Computerworld, Jai covered technology issues for The Economic Times in Bangalore, India. Jai has a Master's degree in Statistics and lives in Naperville, Ill. Dark Reading
Wed, 15 Oct 2025 19:08:26 GMT
No disclosed vulnerabilities or active exploits. F5 confirms no access to CRM, financial, or NGINX systems. Source code and configs exfiltrated; potential for future attacks on customers. No evidence of supply chain tampering or follow-on attacks.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/f5-big-ip-environment-breached-nation-state-actor
[Nation-State Attack][F5 BIG-IP][Persistent Access][Source Code Exfiltration][Potential Supply Chain Risk] A nation-state threat actor gained long-term access to F5's BIG-IP development environment, exfiltrating source code and configuration data. No evidence of customer data breaches or supply chain compromise. Threat actor likely targeting intelligence for future attacks; China suspected. This is a high-impact read for threat actors due to potential future exploitation of stolen architecture. Confidence: 0.85
Unknown (China suspected)
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics F5 BIG-IP Environment Breached by Nation-State Actor F5 BIG-IP Environment Breached by Nation-State Actor F5 BIG-IP Environment Breached by Nation-State Actor F5 disclosed a breach this week that included zero-day bugs, source code, and some customer information. October 15, 2025 Application security giant F5 disclosed a data breach this week in which a nation-state threat actor gained persistent, long-term access to the company's product development environment and engineering knowledge management platforms for its flagship BIG-IP application delivery and security products, before exfiltrating data. The company disclosed the breach in a post on its customer-focused MyF5 website on Oct. 15. F5 said it learned in August that "a highly sophisticated nation-state threat actor maintained long-term, persistent access to, and downloaded files from, certain F5 systems." The unnamed threat actor exfiltrated files containing some BIG-IP source code as well as information regarding undisclosed vulnerabilities it was currently mitigating. The company did not describe the content of said vulnerabilities, only adding in the disclosure post that "we have no knowledge of undisclosed critical or remote code vulnerabilities, and we are not aware of active exploitation of any undisclosed F5 vulnerabilities." Regarding its knowledge management platform, some exfiltrated files contained configuration and implementation information for a "small percentage" of customers, it said. F5 is reviewing the files and contacting customers directly "as appropriate." Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates As for what the threat actor did not get access to, F5 has not found evidence of access to or exfiltration of data tied to its CRM, financial, support case management, or iHealth systems, nor the NGINX source code or product development environment . In addition, F5 has identified no evidence of modification to its software supply chain, including source code, build pipeline, and release pipeline; and it included letters of attestation from NCC Group and IOActive to support the claim. Risk Remains for Potential Data Breach Security Fallout Although customer impact seems limited for now, any long-term, persistent threat activity from a sophisticated nation-state actor constitutes a worst-case scenario for an organization. As F5 said, there is no evidence of follow-on or supply-chain activity resulting from this attack. But concerns remain that vulnerability and source code data stolen today could be utilized in other attacks tomorrow, warns Will Baxter, field chief information security officer (CISO) at Team Cymru. "This is similar to the SolarWinds attack as the actors will use the exfiltrated source code and configs to exploit customers in future campaigns," Baxter says. "This is likely just the beginning of what we will see in terms of a long-term persistent attack at F5, or more likely against F5 devices across customer environments." Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Regarding possible motives behind the attack, David Lindner, CISO of application security vendor Contrast Security, tells Dark Reading that the threat actor's reason for long-term persistence was more likely for spying purposes than stealing files that it could sell. The identity of the threat actor behind the attack remains unclear, though some have pointed to China as a possible culprit, based on previous targeting of F5 appliances . "Their goal likely wasn't to break things at F5 but to gather intelligence for some future plan. By stealing source code from the BIG-IP development team, they essentially grabbed the architectural blueprints for a technology that governments and huge companies rely on globally," he says. "This information is gold for them. They can use it to find undiscovered flaws to use in a later attack, or even map out a major supply chain compromise. This also explains why they were so quiet." What F5 Customers Can Do About the Data Breach In the wake of the breach, F5 said it has worked with multiple incident response firms as well as law enforcement to mitigate the event, and that based on extensive action taken, it believes it has contained the threat posed by the nation-state actor. It also shared an 8-K filing with investors. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor Beyond basic remediation, F5 said it rotated credentials and strengthened its access controls across systems, deployed improved inventory and patch management automation, integrated better monitoring and detection tools, implemented enhancements to network security infrastructure, hardened its product development environment, and more. "Your trust matters. We know it is earned every day, especially when things go wrong," the company said in its blog posting. "We truly regret that this incident occurred and the risk it may create for you. We are committed to learning from this incident and sharing those lessons with the broader security community." F5 advises that customers apply the latest BIG-IP updates. It also shared various guidance for hardening customers' systems. On Oct. 15, CISA directed federal civilian executive branch (FCEB) agencies to inventory F5 BIG-IP products and apply updates where necessary. Some questions about the breach still remain, including how the threat actor managed to get into F5 systems in the first place, and how the company finally caught on to the compromise. Dark Reading asked F5 how it detected the threat actor, but a spokesperson declined to comment beyond the initial disclosure post. About the Author Alexander Culafi Senior News Writer, Dark Reading Alex is an award-winning writer, journalist, and podcast host based in Boston. After cutting his teeth writing for independent gaming publications as a teenager, he graduated from Emerson College in 2016 with a Bachelor of Science in journalism. He has previously been published on VentureFizz, Search Security, Nintendo World Report, and elsewhere. In his spare time, Alex hosts the weekly Nintendo podcast Talk Nintendo Podcast and works on personal writing projects, including two previously self-published science fiction novels. Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-61882', 'cvss': 9.3, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1190', 'T1566'], 'yara': [], 'sigma': []}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-61884', 'cvss': 8.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Disclosure(4)', 'exploited': None, 'mapped_mitre_ids': [], 'yara': [], 'sigma': []}
Wed, 15 Oct 2025 15:13:56 GMT
Harvard confirmed breach via Oracle EBS zero-day. Clop claimed data theft. Patch applied post-disclosure. Exploitation timeline extends back to July 2025. No evidence of broader compromise beyond limited administrative units.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/harvard-breached-oracle-zero-day-attack
[Ransomware][CVE-2025-61882][Clop][Zero-Day][Oracle E-Business Suite] A critical zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-61882) in Oracle E-Business Suite was exploited by the Clop ransomware group, leading to a breach at Harvard University. The flaw allows unauthenticated remote access and was exploited as early as July 2025, weeks before patch availability. Authorities, including the FBI, issued urgent warnings. Clop claimed data theft and added Harvard to its Dark Web leak site. This is a high-impact event for Oracle customers, especially in education and enterprise sectors. A good read for threat actors due to active exploitation and public disclosure.
Clop:United Kingdom
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Harvard University Breached in Oracle Zero-Day Attack Harvard University Breached in Oracle Zero-Day Attack Harvard University Breached in Oracle Zero-Day Attack The Clop ransomware group claimed responsibility for stealing the university's data as part of a broader campaign against Oracle customers. October 15, 2025 Harvard University confirmed that it fell victim to an attack exploiting the recently disclosed zero-day vulnerability in Oracle's E-Business Suite (EBS) system. The critical vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-61882, allows an attacker without authentication to remotely access EBS instances. The flaw has been exploited by the notorious Clop ransomware gang in attacks on Oracle customers . "Harvard is aware of reports that data associated with the University has been obtained as a result of a zero-day vulnerability in the Oracle E-Business Suite system," the University told Dark Reading. "This issue has impacted many Oracle E-Business Suite customers and is not specific to Harvard. While the investigation is ongoing, we believe that this incident impacts a limited number of parties associated with a small administrative unit." Authorities in the US and UK have issued warnings regarding exploitation of CVE-2025-61882 , with FBI Assistant Director Brett Leatherman going so far as to describe the bug in a LinkedIn post as a "stop what you’re doing and patch immediately" vulnerability. The Ivy League university said it applied the patch after Oracle issued the update. While it continues to monitor the situation, Harvard said it has found no evidence of further compromise to its other systems. Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates Oracle Patches Another Flaw Amid Clop Attacks Just a few days ago, Clop added Harvard to its Dark Web leak site, claiming it had stolen a host of the university's data. The breach is part of a greater campaign that began on Sept. 29, according to Google's Threat Intelligence Group and Mandiant. "Our analysis indicates that the CL0P extortion campaign followed months of intrusion activity targeting EBS customer environments," said the researchers . "The threat actor(s) exploited what may be CVE-2025-61882 as a zero-day vulnerability against Oracle EBS customers as early as Aug. 9, 2025, weeks before a patch was available, with additional suspicious activity dating back to July 10, 2025." Oracle had initially connected the attacks to older vulnerabilities disclosed and patched in July. However, the company disclosed earlier this month that the attacks on EBS instances stemmed from CVE-2025-61882. Oracle has since released a new advisory on another vulnerability affecting EBS, tracked as CVE-2025-61884. The bug, disclosed on Oct. 11, affects versions 12.2.3 to 12.2.14 and is remotely exploitable without authentication. As it had with CVE-2025-61882, Oracle is again "strongly" recommending to its customers to apply the emergency update as soon as possible. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Oracle's advisory does not specify if CVE-2025-61884 is currently being exploited in the wild against EBS customers, but several cybersecurity companies have urged organizations to prioritize mitigation of the flaw. "Given historical targeting and the recent Cl0p ransomware activity, threat actors are likely to express interest and attempt exploitation in the near future," said Andres Ramos, senior threat intelligence researcher at Arctic Wolf, in a blog post . In 2023, Clop exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Progress Software's MOVEit Transfer software in a broad attack campaign that impacted an estimated 2,000 organizations . About the Author Kristina Beek Associate Editor, Dark Reading Skilled writer and editor covering cybersecurity for Dark Reading. Dark Reading
Wed, 15 Oct 2025 08:00:00 GMT
Data from Check Point Research and Interpol highlights Africa as a top cyberattack target with growing APT and phishing activity. Ransomware is less prevalent, suggesting it may be used as a testbed. Limited local cybersecurity capacity and legal frameworks contribute to vulnerability. Recommendations include AI-driven defenses, MDR, staff training, and regional collaboration.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyber-risk/africa-top-global-target-attacks-decline
[Africa][Cybercrime][APT Activity][Phishing][Ransomware Decline][Dark Web Marketplaces] Africa remains the top global target for cyberattacks despite a 10% decline in attacks in September, with 3,000+ attacks weekly. The region faces high levels of phishing and compromised hosts, driven by weak legal frameworks and limited cybersecurity capacity. Ransomware is rare (1% of attacks), suggesting potential testing grounds for threat actors. APT groups and cybercriminals are active, selling access on Dark Web. A good read for threat actors due to insights into attack patterns and regional dynamics. Confidence: 0.8
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Breaking cybersecurity news, news analysis, commentary, and other content from around the world, with an initial focus on the Middle East & Africa and the Asia Pacific Africa Remains Top Global Target, Even as Attacks Decline Africa Remains Top Global Target, Even as Attacks Decline Africa Remains Top Global Target, Even as Attacks Decline Organizations across the continent saw 10% fewer attacks in September, but Africa remains the most attacked region in the world, leading the Global South. October 15, 2025 African organizations remained the top global targets of cyberattacks in September, suffering more than 3,000 attacks per week during the past two months, despite recent declines in cyberthreat detections. The downward trend continued into early October and could be evidence that broad policy measures and increased law enforcement are impacting some cyberattackers' efforts, but there is also no reason to think the slight reduction in attacks will be sustained, says Omer Dembinsky, group manager at cybersecurity firm Check Point Research, which published the data. "There could be an impact on how much countries invest in nation-level cyber defense measures and regulations — as well as education to corporate employees on safe online behavior — helping reduce the amount of attacks that actually reach corporate networks in some regions and cause it to be higher in regions where this is less of a focus," he says. Overall, Africa and the other regions of the Global South see about twice as many weekly cyberattacks compared to their peers in North America and Europe, according to Check Point's data. In Africa, the eastern and western regions have seen cybercrime take off, accounting for about a third of all reported crimes, while nine in 10 African countries lack the legal and investigative skills to combat the increase, according to a June report from Interpol . Related: As Incidents Rise, Japanese Government's Cybersecurity Falls Short Much of the activity is driven by cybercriminal groups taking advantage of these less mature legal frameworks and growing Dark Web marketplaces, says Anna Yurtaeva, head of high-tech crime investigations for Middle East and Africa at Group-IB, a cybersecurity services firm based in Singapore. "The African region ranks among the highest globally in terms of compromised hosts and APT group activity, with a growing number of actors selling access to corporate networks on underground markets," she says. "This demonstrates that Africa is not only a target of cyberattacks but is also emerging as one of the centers of global cybercriminal activity." More Phishing, Less Ransomware Because many nations in Africa are rapidly adopting digital technologies throughout their economies and have a high proportion of mobile users, the region has become an attractive target for cybercriminals who have used romance and investment scams, as well as compromised devices and information stealers, to profit from the lack of general security expertise. In August, Interpol arrested more than 1,200 suspected cybercriminals over a three-month collaboration with local law enforcement groups, including disbanding the group behind an investment scam that caused $300 million in losses. Related: Southeast Asian Scam Centers Face More Financial Sanctions Attackers continued to target African organizations with nearly 3,000 weekly attacks in September, topping other regions. Source: Data from Check Point Research; Chart by Robert Lemos Despite some recent wins, African nations have a perennial shortage of skilled cybersecurity professionals while facing cyber-espionage attacks from state-sponsored groups. It's no wonder that Africa has one of the highest numbers of compromised hosts in the world, Yurtaeva says. "These breaches often become just the starting point for bigger attacks — like data theft, extortion, or selling access to systems on the Dark Web," she says. "This growing shadow economy provides the foundation for subsequent campaigns involving ransomware, phishing, and financial fraud." For the most part, however, ransomware is less of a problem. African organizations report the fewest instances of ransomware, accounting for only 1% of the 562 ransomeware attacks reported in September, according to Check Point's report . More than half of ransomware reports (54%) came from North America, while Europe and Asia made up another third of attacks — 19% and 12%, respectively. Some research has suggested that ransomware gangs test drive their attacks in Africa , before widening the reach of their campaigns. Rapid Security Development Needed Related: Asian Orgs Shift Cybersecurity Requirements to Suppliers African organizations are already improving their cybersecurity efforts, and that could be behind the recent decline in weekly attacks. However, there is more to do, says John Paul Onyango, Check Point's country manager for East Africa. "For Africa to stay ahead of escalating cyber threats, organizations must embrace a prevention-first mindset — shifting from detection to proactive defense," he says. "By uniting AI-driven protection, skilled cybersecurity talent, and regional collaboration, we can secure critical infrastructure, strengthen national resilience, and build a safer digital future for the continent." In addition to implementing multifactor authentication, deploying managed detection-and-response (MDR) systems, conducting regular security audits, and providing ongoing staff training, companies need to cooperate with global partners, says Group-IB's Yurtaeva. "Cooperation with national CERTs and global partners is crucial," he says. "[M]any attacks in Africa originate from underground markets where access to corporate networks is sold, underscoring the need for active threat monitoring and proactive vulnerability remediation." Read more about: About the Author Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer Veteran technology journalist of more than 20 years. Former research engineer. Written for more than two dozen publications, including CNET News.com, Dark Reading, MIT's Technology Review, Popular Science, and Wired News. Five awards for journalism, including Best Deadline Journalism (Online) in 2003 for coverage of the Blaster worm. Crunches numbers on various trends using Python and R. Recent reports include analyses of the shortage in cybersecurity workers and annual vulnerability trends.
