{'cve': 'CVE-2025-59230', 'cvss': 7.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-24990', 'cvss': 7.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-24052', 'cvss': 7.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'ProofOfConcept(1)', 'exploited': False, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-59287', 'cvss': 9.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'ExploitLikely(12)', 'exploited': False, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-55315', 'cvss': 9.9, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'ExploitLikely(12)', 'exploited': False, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}, {'cve': 'CVE-2025-47827', 'cvss': 4.6, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'ProofOfConcept(1)', 'exploited': False, 'mapped_mitre_ids': None, 'yara': None, 'sigma': None}
Tue, 14 Oct 2025 21:53:11 GMT
End of life for Windows 10 and several legacy products (Exchange 2016/2019, Skype 2016, etc.) marks a critical shift in endpoint security. Multiple zero-days and high-severity vulnerabilities require immediate patching. Exploitable EoP flaws in Windows services and third-party drivers pose significant risks to organizations still using legacy systems.
https://www.darkreading.com/vulnerabilities-threats/microsoft-october-patch-update
[Ransomware][Zero-Day][CVE-2025-59230][CVE-2025-24990][CVE-2025-59287][CVE-2025-55315][CVE-2025-47827] High-impact vulnerabilities in Windows, ASP.NET Core, and IGEL OS; two actively exploited zero-days; end of life for Windows 10. A good read for threat actors due to exploitable EoP and RCE flaws with real-world attack potential. Microsoft's largest Patch Tuesday in years.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Microsoft Drops Terrifyingly Large October Patch Update Microsoft Drops Terrifyingly Large October Patch Update Microsoft Drops Terrifyingly Large October Patch Update October 2025's enormous Patch Tuesday offers plenty of nightmares for admins, including actively exploited zero-days and insidious high-severity privilege-escalation bugs — and it spells curtains for Windows 10 updates. October 14, 2025 Microsoft's Patch Tuesday security update for October weighed in at a hefty 175 CVEs, including two that attackers are already exploiting, three that were previously disclosed, and more than a dozen in total that the company considers likely targets for exploitation. It is the biggest Patch Tuesday update on record for Microsoft in recent memory, and pushes the number of unique vulnerabilities the company has released so far this year to more than all of the vulnerabilities recorded in 2024. More Microsoft Vulnerabilities in October Than All of Last Year "With two months remaining this year, we’ve already blown last year’s tally of 1,009 CVEs patched, as this month’s release brings us up to 1,021," said Satnam Narang, senior staff research engineer at Tenable, in a statement. The update is the largest since Tenable began documenting Microsoft patch releases in 2017, and doesn’t even include out-of-cycle patches that the company issued prior to Patch Tuesday, or those that do not list Microsoft as the issuer, he said. As usual, the vulnerabilities that Microsoft disclosed this week affected a wide range of its products and included a mix of remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities, elevation of privilege flaws , flaws that enable data theft, denial of service (DoS) attacks, and bypass of security features. Related: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Critical Windows Server Bug Many of the vulnerabilities that Microsoft disclosed this week merit high-priority attention, but few more so that the two zero-days that attackers are already actively exploiting. Zero-Day Threats Offer Privilege Escalation One of the zero-days, CVE-2025-59230 (CVSS 7.8) in Windows Remote Access Connection Manager, allows attackers who already have access on an affected system to escalate privileges all the way to admin level. Mike Walters, president and co-founder of Action1, assessed that the flaw has to do with how the service — which manages VPN and remote access connections — processes commands from low-privileged users without proper authentication. "Exploitation of this vulnerability is relatively easy, making it accessible even to attackers with moderate technical skills," he warned in prepared comments. The other actively exploited zero-day, CVE-2025-24990 (CVSS 7.8), is also an EoP vulnerability, this time in a third-party driver for the Windows Agere modem. The driver ships natively with all supported versions of the Windows operating system. Attackers can exploit the flaw to gain system-level privileges on affected systems, even if the modem itself is not being actively used. Microsoft has removed the driver, meaning Agere modems that use the driver will no longer work on Windows. "Microsoft recommends removing any existing dependencies on this hardware," the company said in its advisory. Related: Fear the 'SessionReaper': Adobe Commerce Flaw Under Attack In addition to the actively exploited zero-days, Microsoft also disclosed another, publicly disclosed flaw in the same Windows Agere modem service for which a proof-of-concept exploit (PoC) is already available. That zero-day bug, tracked as CVE-2025-24052 (CVSS 7.8) is also an EoP issue that enables attackers to gain system level privileges. "Even if the modem is not in use, it remains vulnerable to exploitation, which could give an attacker administrator privileges," Satnam from Tenable noted. "The fix for this flaw is telling: Microsoft is removing the driver, ltmdm64.sys, from Windows operating systems through the October cumulative update." Of note, Microsoft's patch update also included a fix for yet another zero-day bug that attackers are actively exploiting, though technically, it's not a Microsoft CVE. The bug, CVE-2025-47827 (CVSS 4.6) affects IGEL OS, a lightweight, Linux-based operating system for managing virtual desktops and cloud workspaces on endpoint devices. The vulnerability was disclosed in May, and it was MITRE that assigned the CVE number for the flaw, not Microsoft. The bug enables bypass of Secure Boot mechanisms. "A PoC has been publicly available since this vulnerability was disclosed back in May, meaning it would be trivial for threat actors to weaponize this vulnerability," said Kev Breen, senior director threat research at Immersive in emailed comments. Related: Pwn2Own Underscores Secure Development Concerns High-Priority Windows Security Feature Bugs Walters from Action1 identified CVE-2025-59287 (CVSS 9.8,) an RCE bug in the Windows Server Update Service, as an issue that security teams might want to prioritize. WSUS is the mechanism that organizations use to centrally distribute and manage updates and patches, and a successful exploit of a bug in the service could enable an attacker to create considerable damage. This might include "complete compromise of the patching infrastructure, deployment of malicious 'updates' to managed systems, lateral movement throughout the environment, and the creation of persistent backdoors in the update infrastructure," Walters said. Microsoft has tagged CVE-2025-59287 as a vulnerability that attackers are more likely to exploit. CVE-2025-55315 (CVSS 9.9) is another security-feature bypass that Microsoft disclosed this week. The bug affects the ASP.Net Core framework and, if exploited, could have a high impact on system confidentiality, integrity, and availability, according to Microsoft. It gives attackers a way to view user credentials, change file contents on the target server, and even trigger a system crash. Though severe, "it is important to note that this vulnerability is not exploitable by an anonymous attacker; it requires the threat actor to first be authenticated with valid, low-privilege user credentials," said Ben McCarthy, lead cyber security engineer at Immersive, in comments reacting to Microsoft's patch release. No Patches: Windows 10 End of Life Is Here Significantly, this week's patch update also marked the end of life for Windows 10, meaning that Microsoft will no longer issue regular patches for vulnerabilities in the operating system as part of its regular Patch Tuesday updates. The impact could be significant, given the OS still holds a nearly 41% share of the desktop Windows version market worldwide. Organizations that are still on Windows 10 will need to switch to the Extended Security Updates program to continue receiving patches after today, said Nick Carroll, cyber incident response manager at Nightwing, in a statement. Other, less well-known products that also reached end of life this week include Exchange Server 2016, Exchange Server 2019, Skype for Business 2016, Windows 11 IoT Enterprise Version 22H2, and Outlook 2016. "All these products and more will stop getting security patches," Carroll said, "but that doesn't mean the threat actors will stop making new exploits for them." About the Author Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer Jai Vijayan is a seasoned technology reporter with over 20 years of experience in IT trade journalism. He was most recently a Senior Editor at Computerworld, where he covered information security and data privacy issues for the publication. Over the course of his 20-year career at Computerworld, Jai also covered a variety of other technology topics, including big data, Hadoop, Internet of Things, e-voting, and data analytics. Prior to Computerworld, Jai covered technology issues for The Economic Times in Bangalore, India. Jai has a Master's degree in Statistics and lives in Naperville, Ill. threat exploit patch ransomware zero-day CVE TA threat actor RCE patch Tuesday AWS
Dark Reading
Tue, 14 Oct 2025 21:12:14 GMT
Attack involved manipulation of ArcGIS Java SOE to create a persistent web shell; no known CVE reported. Threat actors used legitimate admin credentials and public-facing infrastructure. Attack chain is not limited to ArcGIS, highlighting broader risks in public-facing applications. Emphasis on credential hygiene and behavioral detection.
https://www.darkreading.com/application-security/chinas-flax-typhoon-geo-mapping-server-backdoor
[APTFlaxTyphoon][ArcGISBackdoor][WebShell][NoMalware][GeospatialSoftware][HighImpact][GoodReadForThreatActors]
Flax Typhoon:China
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics China's Flax Typhoon Turns Geo-Mapping Server into a Backdoor China's Flax Typhoon Turns Geo-Mapping Server into a Backdoor China's Flax Typhoon Turns Geo-Mapping Server into a Backdoor Chinese APT threat actors compromised an organization's ArcGIS server, modifying the widely used geospatial mapping software for stealth access. October 14, 2025 Researchers discovered a "wakeup call" type of attack by a Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) group that established backdoor access to an organization for more than a year through a geospatial mapping application. In a blog post from cybersecurity vendor Reliaquest, researchers detailed how a notorious threat group tracked as Flax Typhoon constructed "an unusually clever attack chain" that manipulated a component of ArcGIS, a widely known geo-mapping platform from software maker Esri. The researchers found Flax Typhoon actors compromised an organization's public-facing ArcGIS server and used the access to turn a trusted application into a backdoor . "This attack is a wakeup call: Any entry point with backend access must be treated as a top-tier priority, no matter how routine or trusted," Reliaquest analysts Alexa Feminella and James Xiang wrote in the blog post . Turning ArcGIS into a Web Shell Reliaquest investigated a potential compromise of an ArcGIS customer, and after ruling out that a zero-day vulnerability or misconfiguration were involved, researchers uncovered a unique attack that demonstrated Flax Typhoon's sophistication and creativity. The researchers found the threat actors established year-long access to the organization by modifying ArcGIS' Java server object extension (SOE), which allows users to create service operations for maps and images, and turning the component into a Web shell . Flex Typhoon accomplished this by compromising a portal administrator account for ArcGIS, the researchers explained. Related: It Takes Only 250 Documents to Poison Any AI Model "The attackers found a public-facing ArcGIS server that was connected to a private, internal ArcGIS server for backend computations (a common default configuration)," Feminella and Xiang wrote. According to ArcGIS documentation, the public portal serves as a proxy, forwarding commands to the internal server through a Web adapter. The attackers sent disguised commands to the portal server, which created a hidden system directory in the server that essentially became Flax Typhoon's private workspace, the researchers said, complete with a hardcoded key. Additionally, Flax Typhoon's attack chain ensured the malicious SOE would remain in place even after a full system recovery. "The group's persistence method was even more insidious. By ensuring the compromised component was included in system backups, they turned the organization's own recovery plan into a guaranteed method of reinfection," Feminella and Xiang wrote. Mitigating Flax Typhoon Threats Reliaquest said it worked with the customer organization and Esri to fully evict Flax Typhoon actors from the environment, which included rebuilding the entire server stack and deploying custom detections for the threat activity. Related: Self-Propagating GlassWorm Attacks VS Code Supply Chain ArcGIS attack follows other notable threat activity targeting geo-mapping software; last month, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) disclosed that a large, unnamed federal civilian executive branch agency was breached in 2024 through a vulnerability in GeoServer, an open source geospatial data server. An Esri spokesperson tells Dark Reading that the company has not seen any evidence or received reports indicating that other organizations have been impacted by this type of attack. Reliaquest also said it has seen no evidence of other organizations that have been breached by malicious ArcGIS SOE. "However, the report's main warning is that while the component was specific to ArcGIS, the tactic is not," a company spokesperson said. "While the method of persistence is unique, this can happen to any publicly facing application where security best practices are assumed but not enforced. Therefore, it is highly likely that many organizations are vulnerable to this same attack chain, using the creative modification of any legitimate component." Related: AI Chat Data Is History's Most Thorough Record of Enterprise Secrets. Secure It Wisely Reliaquest urged organizations to treat all public-facing applications as high-risk assets. To that end, the researchers recommended security teams audit and harden such applications, no matter how routine. Feminella and Xiang also highlighted the fact that Flax Typhoon didn't use any malware or known malicious files, which emphasizes the need for behavioral analytics to complement signature-based detection. The researchers also stressed the importance of strong credential hygiene, noting that "a weak administrator password" gave the attackers a foothold in the organization's network. In addition to enforcing strong, unique passwords, Reliaquest recommended implementing multifactor authentication and practicing the principal of least privilege. About the Author Rob Wright Senior News Director, Dark Reading Rob Wright is a longtime reporter and senior news director for Informa TechTarget's security team. He is based in the Boston area. threat malware backdoor APT TA
Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-48561', 'cvss': 6.1, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'ProofOfConcept(1)', 'exploited': False, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1011', 'T1012'], 'yara': [], 'sigma': []}
Tue, 14 Oct 2025 20:27:10 GMT
Attack targets Android APIs and hardware side channels to extract local secrets like 2FA codes. No evidence of real-world exploitation. Google has released patches, with a follow-up in December. Mitigation strategies remain unclear for app developers.
https://www.darkreading.com/vulnerabilities-threats/pixnapping-attack-attackers-2fa-android
[Pixnapping][Android][CVE-2025-48561][Side-Channel Attack] A proof-of-concept exploit allows malicious apps to steal 2FA codes and sensitive data from Android devices via side-channel attacks targeting Android APIs. Researchers at UC Berkeley, UW, UCSD, and CMU demonstrate the attack on Google and Samsung devices. No confirmed in-the-wild exploitation; Google has issued patches, with a follow-up in December. A patch workaround exists. This is a good read for threat actors due to its potential for data exfiltration, though exploitation remains complex. [Impact: Low to Medium for users; high for app developers]
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Pixnapping Attack Lets Attackers Steal 2FA on Android Pixnapping Attack Lets Attackers Steal 2FA on Android Pixnapping Attack Lets Attackers Steal 2FA on Android The proof-of-concept exploit allows an attacker to steal sensitive data from Gmail, Google Accounts, Google Authenticator, Google Maps, Signal, and Venmo. October 14, 2025 A new Android-focused proof-of-concept exploit would enable threat actors to steal secrets like multifactor authentication credentials from certain Android devices. The attack, named "pixnapping," was created by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley; the University of Washington; the University of California, San Diego; and Carnegie Mellon University. The team described it on a dedicated research website as a "new class of attacks that allows a malicious Android app to stealthily leak information displayed by other Android apps or arbitrary websites." Researchers demonstrated the attack on Google and Samsung phones and have managed "end-to-end recovery of sensitive data from websites including Gmail and Google Accounts and apps including Signal, Google Authenticator, Venmo, and Google Maps." "Notably, our attack against Google Authenticator allows any malicious app to steal 2FA codes in under 30 seconds while hiding the attack from the user," the pixnapping research website read . Although there has been no indication that attackers have successfully exploited the proof-of-concept (POC) to date, no definitive patch appears to be available on any Android device. How Pixnapping Works Although the attack was tested on Google and Samsung devices for the sake of the study (including Google Pixel 6, 7, 8 and 9, and Samsung Galaxy S25), researchers said pixnapping, which targets Android APIs and a hardware side channel, actually affects nearly all modern Android devices. Related: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Critical Windows Server Bug Pixnapping exists among a larger, older genre of attack known as "pixel stealing," where a source can determine how a pixel (typically from some other source) is displayed to a user through some kind of side channel. In this case, malicious code is installed on an app that is opened by the user. Anything that is visible to the user while the app is opened, such as in another application tab, can be stolen including two-factor authentication codes, email, chat messages, and other secrets. "Our key observation is that Android APIs enable an attacker to create an analog to Stone-style attacks outside of the browser. Specifically, a malicious app can force victim pixels into the rendering pipeline via Android intents and compute on those victim pixels using a stack of semi-transparent Android activities," a white paper presenting the research read. A "Stone-style attack" refers to researcher Paul Stone, who originated the pixel-stealing attack concept in 2013. "Crucially, our framework enables stealing secrets only stored locally (e.g., 2FA codes and Google Maps Timeline), which have never before been in reach of pixel stealing attacks," the researchers added. Related: Fear the 'SessionReaper': Adobe Commerce Flaw Under Attack Secrets that aren't displayed on screen, even if stored in the device, cannot be captured by the malicious code. Researchers were able to capture pixels across Android activities by using multiple APIs, including one dedicated to window blurring and another for VSync callbacks. Why Pixnapping Matters The attack has been designated CVE-2025-48561. The team behind the POC said no vendor has conclusively mitigated the attack to date. As the pixnapping researchers explained, Google released a patch in early September but researchers found a subsequent workaround. In a statement, a Google spokesperson tells Dark Reading that the company's September patch partially mitigates pixnapping, but adds, "We are issuing an additional patch for this vulnerability in the December Android security bulletin." Google has not observed any evidence of in-the-wild exploitation. In an email, Google adds that exploiting the vulnerability requires specific data about the target device and that malicious applications exploiting the vulnerability have not yet been found on Google Play. Pixnapping does not, on its face, appear to be the kind of side-channel attack that changes how threat actors target Android devices —exploitation appears to be somewhat complicated and requires an open application. But pixnapping is another option for the Android attacker's toolkit and another possible way to harvest data through a theoretical social engineering campaign. Related: Pwn2Own Underscores Secure Development Concerns For users, pixnapping researchers recommend staying up to date on Android security updates. For app developers, advice was less clear. "We are not aware of mitigation strategies to protect apps against pixnapping. If you have any insights into mitigations, please let us know and we will update this section," the pixnapping site read. Dark Reading contacted Samsung for comment. About the Author Alexander Culafi Senior News Writer, Dark Reading Alex is an award-winning writer, journalist, and podcast host based in Boston. After cutting his teeth writing for independent gaming publications as a teenager, he graduated from Emerson College in 2016 with a Bachelor of Science in journalism. He has previously been published on VentureFizz, Search Security, Nintendo World Report, and elsewhere. In his spare time, Alex hosts the weekly Nintendo podcast Talk Nintendo Podcast and works on personal writing projects, including two previously self-published science fiction novels. threat exploit patch CVE TA threat actor exfiltration AI
Dark Reading
Mon, 13 Oct 2025 15:01:28 GMT
Discusses quantum computing threats, post-quantum encryption migration timelines, and 'harvest now, decrypt later' tactics. Focuses on long-term data exposure risks and industry preparedness, particularly in finance and government. No specific vulnerabilities or attack techniques detailed.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/financial-industries-urged-prepare-quantum-computers
[Quantum Computing][Post-Quantum Cryptography][Harvest Now, Decrypt Later][Crypto-Procrastination] This is a good read for threat actors due to the 'harvest now, decrypt later' strategy targeting long-term data. Financial and government sectors face critical risks as legacy systems remain vulnerable to future quantum decryption.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics News, news analysis, and commentary on the latest trends in cybersecurity technology. Financial, Other Industries Urged to Prepare for Quantum Computers Financial, Other Industries Urged to Prepare for Quantum Computers Financial, Other Industries Urged to Prepare for Quantum Computers Despite daunting technical challenges, a quantum computer capable of breaking public-key encryption systems may be only a decade or two off. October 13, 2025 Financial firms, government agencies, and other sectors with sensitive data need to worry about the arrival of quantum computers today, even though a cryptographically relevant quantum computer (CRQC) may be decades away, experts warn. In late September, the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center (FS-ISAC) said that crypto-procrastination is resulting in financial firms being unprepared for the future threats and data risks posed by quantum computers. A variety of factors — from interdependencies between firms to the need to support standards — have slowed planning and hampered adoption of post-quantum encryption. Yet companies need to deal with the risk today because sensitive data can be harvested and stored to be decrypted in the future, says Mike Silverman, chief strategy and innovation officer at FS-ISAC. "Regardless of when this happens, no cryptography is secure forever, and we won't always be able to depend on the algorithms we're using today," he says. "Good risk management practices require us to become cryptographically agile — the ability to change algorithms efficiently to respond quickly to the business and threat environment." Along with the impact of artificial intelligence (AI), quantum computing is considered one of the most serious future security risks. Most experts give a better-than-even chance that in 20 years quantum computers will be able to break data encrypted by the RSA-2048 public-key cryptosystem in 24 hours . In August, an alliance of four companies — IBM Consulting, Keyfactor, Quantinuum, and Thales — pooled their resources to help develop assessment and migration capabilities . Related: For One NFL Team, Tackling Cyber Threats Is Basic Defense An Uncertain Timeline Increased investment into quantum-computing research and a number of significant milestones have led to predictions that a CRQC is a decade or two away. In May, for example, Google researchers estimated that they could factor a 2048-bit RSA key using 1 million qubits , down from a previous estimate of 20 million qubits. The current state of the art is a 6,100-qubit processor developed by the California Institute of Technology . "There's still work to be done, but there seems to be a very real sense that it is inevitable and will happen sooner than anticipated," says Rebecca Krauthamer, CEO and co-founder of QuSecure, a quantum-security-as-a-service firm. "It's worth remembering that a lot of this research also is highly classified, so we may not know of many advancements." When research reaches certain critical points, progress accelerates rapidly, says Daniel dos Santos, senior director and head of research at Forescout Technologies, a managed security firm. Related: SentinelOne Announces Plans to Acquire Observo AI "Think of the progress of AI — the discipline has been around for more than 50 years, but the results in the past five years have surprised everyone," he says. "We could reach an 'AI moment' for quantum computing in the next few years that could greatly accelerate timelines by bringing in more investment, people, and resources to the field." X + Y = Oh No! The FS-ISAC paper points to calculation, known as Mosca's Theorem, that highlights the need to prepare for quantum computers decades before they become a viable way to decrypt old data. The theorem says that the length of time that data is required to be secure (X) plus the time it takes to upgrade encryption systems (Y) needs to happen before the arrival of a cryptographically relevant quantum computer. This is because threat actors — especially nation-states — are likely hoarding sensitive data from rivals and adversaries in preparation of being able to decrypt it in the future, a strategy known as "harvest now, decrypt later” (HNDL). If the time needed for data to be secure plus the time to migrate infrastructure to QC-resistant encryption extends beyond the arrival of a quantum computer, companies could lose sensitive data. Source: FS-ISAC The timeline means that, even if a quantum computer is decades away, the threat is still pressing, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) stated in a report published late last year. Organizations must begin migrating to post-quantum cryptography now to avoid having their encrypted data exposed when the computers become operational, NIST wrote. Related: New Quantum-Safe Alliance Aims to Accelerate PQC Implementation "This threat ... underscores the necessity of acting immediately, especially for data with long-term sensitivity, such as government secrets or medical records," the report concluded. While some organizations in critical sectors such as finance and government have started to inventory their assets, most businesses are not even thinking about the threat posed by quantum computers, says Forescout's dos Santos. "Although five years might sound like a long time to migrate, we know there are assets out there still running decades-old software," he says, including Windows 10, Windows 2000, and even Windows XP. Crypto-Procrastination A major problem for businesses and governments is that preparing for quantum computers requires planning for an event a decade or more in the future, while budgetary uncertainty is a more present issue. Moving to entirely new encryption mechanisms and making the replacement of old encryption algorithms more efficient requires a great deal of effort for a threat that many organizations do not find pressing. The EU has set a deadline for critical-infrastructure firms to start their post-quantum encryption transition by 2026 and to finish in 2030. Less critical systems have until 2035. Canada has set the deadline for a draft PQC transition plan for April 2026 for government agencies, with high-priority systems fully transitioned by the end of 2031. In the US, NIST plans to transition away from vulnerable encryption algorithms by 2030 and completely disallow them in 2035. Organizations need to start creating a focused transition program, says FS-ISAC's Silverman. By inventorying apps, protocols, hardware modules, and third-party services, staff can build a crypto-dependency map to plan transitions in different infrastructures. High- and medium-risk use cases should be identified and prioritized, until the organization is confident it can eliminate all quantum-vulnerable algorithms, he says. "Due to the interdependencies across the financial system, it’s essential that the entire sector collaborates on this transition," he says. Overall, the solutions are here, says QuSecure's Krauthamer. About the Author Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer Veteran technology journalist of more than 20 years. Former research engineer. Written for more than two dozen publications, including CNET News.com, Dark Reading, MIT's Technology Review, Popular Science, and Wired News. Five awards for journalism, including Best Deadline Journalism (Online) in 2003 for coverage of the Blaster worm. Crunches numbers on various trends using Python and R. Recent reports include analyses of the shortage in cybersecurity workers and annual vulnerability trends. threat TA threat actor AI
Dark Reading
Mon, 13 Oct 2025 14:00:00 GMT
Focuses on data sprawl in collaboration tools as a key vulnerability in critical infrastructure. Emphasizes the role of AI in accelerating adversary reconnaissance and data exfiltration. No specific CVEs or IOCs mentioned. Article is opinion-based and lacks technical indicators.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/critical-infrastructure-back-office-data
[Data Sprawl][Critical Infrastructure][Nation-State Threat Actors][Volt Typhoon][AI-Driven Reconnaissance] This article highlights how unmonitored collaboration platforms (SharePoint, Teams, Google Drive, etc.) in critical infrastructure create vast, exploitable attack surfaces. Sensitive data such as CAD drawings, PII, SCADA runbooks, and regulatory documents are routinely stored in unclassified, unmonitored environments. Nation-state actors like Volt Typhoon leverage living-off-the-land techniques and AI to automate reconnaissance, mine unstructured data, and exploit secrets in metadata and chat logs. The risks are amplified by generative AI, which accelerates data harvesting and cross-platform operations. This is a high-impact read for threat actors targeting critical infrastructure due to the breadth of exploitable data. Confidence: 0.92
Volt Typhoon:China
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Critical infrastructure CISOs Can't Ignore 'Back-Office Clutter' Data Critical infrastructure CISOs Can't Ignore 'Back-Office Clutter' Data Critical infrastructure CISOs Can't Ignore 'Back-Office Clutter' Data OT and ICS systems indeed hold the crown jewels of critical infrastructure organizations, but unmonitored data sprawl is proving to be pure gold for increasingly brazen nation-state threat actors like Volt Typhoon, Pearce argues. October 13, 2025 OPINION Security leaders in critical infrastructure traditionally have focused their defensive energy on operational technology (OT) and industrial control systems (ICS). Those remain the crown jewels for attackers. But while they've been patching programmable logic centers (PLCs) and segmenting control centers, sprawling collaboration platforms — SharePoint, Google Drive, Exchange, Gmail, Teams, Slack, Box, and old-fashioned file shares — have quietly become the single largest unmonitored attack surface in the enterprise. These systems are indispensable. They're easy to use, embedded into daily operations, and frictionless for sharing. That same ubiquity is exactly what makes them so dangerous. Information moves with a click, but oversight rarely keeps pace. Sensitive documents proliferate in dozens of formats, from CAD files to PDFs, and in hidden corners like document metadata and chat transcripts. Left ungoverned, these platforms are beyond messy; they're opportunities waiting to be exploited. Think about how collaboration works today in a utility or pipeline operator. Teams spin up SharePoint sites and Microsoft Teams or Slack channels without a second thought. Someone creates a Box folder for a vendor. HR moves onboarding forms to Google Drive. The result: petabytes of enterprise data sprawled across thousands of sites and folders, with little classification and even less monitoring. Related: US Crypto Bust Offers Hope in Battle Against Cybercrime Syndicates Campaigns like Volt Typhoon have already demonstrated a preference for living off the land, with attackers exploiting the same tools employees rely on. SharePoint and Teams are irresistible: sprawling, under-governed, and full of the details an adversary needs to map your environment. Consider a utility, serving 15 million customers. What's in its collaboration stack? Engineering and operations : CAD drawings, as-builts, substation layouts, Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) runbooks GIS and mapping : detailed asset maps, parcel data, feeder diagrams Customer PII and meter data : billing, call center transcripts, smart meter records HR and employee PII : payroll, benefits, recruiting files Finance and legal : invoices, contracts, litigation documents Regulatory evidence : NERC/FERC/CIP filings, SOX documentation, audit trails Security and IT : IAM exports, network diagrams, privileged access notes Watch Joe Pearce , Head of Product at RecordPoint, break down the issue in this video sidebar: This is a blueprint of the entire enterprise. For adversaries with patience and time, it's not clutter, it's gold. Related: Lazarus Group Hunts European Drone Manufacturing Data Risks Critical Infrastructure CISOs Should Fear Most Several common issues emerge across critical infrastructure: External exposure via oversharing : stale guest access or public links that never expire OT and SCADA data in general-purpose sites : organizations placing system diagrams in the same library as their lunch-and-learn slides Regulatory sprawl : audit evidence scattered across hundreds of sites, undermining defensibility Secrets in documents : passwords, tokens, and keys sitting in spreadsheets or ticket exports Bulk exfiltration potential : synchronization tools make it trivial to pull down massive datasets unnoticed Each of these is a pathway for nation-state actors or sophisticated ransomware crews to quietly pivot toward disruption. And now, those risks are being supercharged by generative and agentic AI. These tools can accelerate reconnaissance, automate the mining of unstructured documents and metadata, and even chain together actions across platforms at a speed and scale defenders can't match. In effect, AI turns sprawling collaboration ecosystems into low-hanging fruit for adversaries who know how to weaponize it. Critical infrastructure operators can no longer afford to treat data sprawl as mere back-office clutter. In an era of persistent nation-state campaigns, sprawling SharePoint sites and unmanaged Teams channels represent a frontline security risk. OT segmentation and zero trust won't matter if attackers can simply walk through your document libraries and chat logs. Related: MuddyWater Targets 100+ Gov Entities in MEA With Phoenix Backdoor CISOs should assume their adversaries are already looking. About the Author Joe Pearce Head of Product, RecordPoint As the Head of Product at RecordPoint, Joe Pearce leads the innovation, strategy, and roadmap for RecordPoint’s Data and AI Governance Platforms. Joe is a strategic leader with more than 18 years of experience in B2B SaaS, excelling in integrating cutting-edge solutions with business strategy. He has a proven track record in innovative product development, particularly enhancing the information security landscape. Before RecordPoint, Joe was the Vice President of Product and Technology at Coalfire, for its information and offensive security products, leading strategy, product development, and integrations. He is passionate about driving technological advancement and fostering user-centric products in the growingly complex world of security, compliance, and governance. He holds an MBA from the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University and a BS in Computer Engineering from Florida Institute of Technology. Dark Reading
Mon, 13 Oct 2025 13:30:00 GMT
Content focuses on workforce trends and AI's impact on entry-level cybersecurity roles, not on specific cyber threats, vulnerabilities, or attack techniques.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/ai-tech-graduates-disadvantage
[AI in Cybersecurity][Entry-Level Job Displacement][GenAI Impact] This article discusses how generative AI is transforming cybersecurity job markets, displacing entry-level roles and raising skill barriers. While AI tools enhance efficiency in threat detection and volume management, they also increase competition and expectations for junior professionals. The article does not provide specific threat intelligence, vulnerabilities, or attack vectors. Not a good read for threat actors due to low actionable intelligence. No financial impact stated.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Generation AI: Why Today's Tech Graduates Are At a Disadvantage Generation AI: Why Today's Tech Graduates Are At a Disadvantage Generation AI: Why Today's Tech Graduates Are At a Disadvantage With artificial intelligence supplanting entry-level security jobs, new cyber professionals will have to up their game to stay competitive in the industry. October 13, 2025 Entry-level workers from the ages of 22-25 may be finding themselves fresh out of a job these days as artificial intelligence (AI) continues to dominate industries across the world. This is according to a recent study published by Stanford University, which found that jobs for this age demographic have declined by roughly 13% since the widespread adoption of generative AI (GenAI). And these changes are occurring in jobs most exposed to AI, such as software developers and computer programmers. One explanation for the findings, according to the researchers, is that AI can replace young workers who are still gaining skills in their respective industries, raising questions as to what these entry-level professionals, particularly those in software, cybersecurity, and technology, should do to gain the skills they need to progress in their careers. CISOs' Perspective on AI Though concerns of AI replacing entry-level technology jobs continue to grow, some feel that AI won’t be as big of an issue compared to other technologies. "I think the concern about AI tooling possibly replacing entry-level roles should be a little bit less of a concern when it comes to security roles than other basic developer roles," says Marshall Erwin, chief information security officer (CISO) at Fastly . "The basic reason for that is, even putting aside your sort of new AI trends, any security team is really struggling with volume." Related: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense He adds that with the challenges cybersecurity professionals face every day, companies can't just "hire their way out of that problem." To Erwin, adding automations into daily processes allows organizations to filter through the noise so that real, human professionals can focus on high-risk problems when they're needed. "I think AI is really going to be helpful in that respect," he says. "We need better ways to filter through that noise and manage the volume of what we're seeing on a day-to-day basis and that's a problem we've had for a long time, and these tools are going to help us with that." Jason Manar, CISO at Kaseya , agrees, noting that while change is inevitable, there will still be employment available for those willing to adapt. "There will be new opportunities, and you see this now with various engineering positions where there are more positions for generative AI and new positions within engineering," he says. "So, is there consolidation that may take place with entry or junior level jobs? Yes, absolutely. Will there still be some type of junior job or entry level job? There will. I just think that's going to be redefined as to what that is." Related: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks But according to Jessica Sica, CISO at Weave Communications , when reflecting on her personal experience while hiring entry-level professionals, the field is already getting increasingly harder to break into, and this may be regardless of AI's influence. "Everybody says the security industry is growing rapidly, but it's getting harder and harder to get in," she says. "And I think part of that is maybe more and more people want to get into security, but the entry level jobs I think are getting more difficult. Companies are getting more demanding." She adds that AI is only going to make it even more difficult to get into the field, particularly with entry-level jobs. "I think some of those tasks are going to be replaced with AI," she notes. "Not sure that we're there yet, but when that happens, how do you get in and how do you move up if those entry-level jobs are getting harder to find?" AI Raises the Bar for Entry-Level Tech Careers Mudit Sinha, AI lead at Lineaje, is familiar with these concerns of how AI may affect employment. He graduated just two years ago with a bachelor of Science from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Sinha landed his first job through networking — specifically, reaching out to the chief technology officer (CTO) of the company. Related: Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice "I was looking more into data analytics and a mix of AI back in the day, and the company had just started doing AI," he says. "I did about three to four rounds of interviews, most of them with the CTO, the one with the CEO." This is exactly what Sinha recommends to fresh graduates or individuals looking for entry-level positions in the field — reaching out, introducing yourself, and showcasing a project that the company might be interested in. As for how AI will reshape the cybersecurity industry Sinha describes as "growing," he believes that the tool will only enhance the field. "Everyone is expected to perform at a level higher than they previously were expected to perform," Sinha says. "Juniors are now expected to do the same output as, let's say, senior SDEs (software development engineer) or senior researchers because they have access to this really powerful tool. So, entry level people should not have the expectation that they are going to be treated as entry level applicants." While this may be a hard pill to swallow, Sinha advises entry-level applicants to accept the challenge , prepare to understand the latest advancements in AI, maintain a genuine interest in cybersecurity, and not underestimate the value of soft-skills in this industry. "Ultimately people like interacting with other people, and that interaction piece is not really going away with AI, as far as I've seen," Sinha adds. "Be sociable, be open to opportunities, and if you have the opportunity, keep talking to upper management or whoever you can." About the Author Kristina Beek Associate Editor, Dark Reading Skilled writer and editor covering cybersecurity for Dark Reading. cybersecurity threat TA threat actor detection AI
Dark Reading
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 21:27:30 GMT
Focuses on AI browser agent security risks, credential leakage, and prompt injection as key threats. No specific CVEs or IOCs reported. Discussion centers on authentication blind spots in AI-driven workflows and mitigation via zero-knowledge models.
https://www.darkreading.com/identity-access-management-security/1password-addresses-critical-ai-browser-agent-security-gap
[AI Browser Agent Security][Credential Leakage][Zero-Knowledge Authentication] This article highlights critical security risks posed by AI browser agents, including credential exposure via unencrypted browser storage and prompt injection attacks. 1Password introduces Secure Agentic Autofill to mitigate risks by delivering credentials via end-to-end encryption and requiring human approval. Threat actors could exploit prompt injection to extract credentials, making this a high-impact concern for enterprises. Good read for threat actors due to real-world attack vectors and AI-driven vulnerabilities.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics News, news analysis, and commentary on the latest trends in cybersecurity technology. 1Password Addresses Critical AI Browser Agent Security Gap 1Password Addresses Critical AI Browser Agent Security Gap 1Password Addresses Critical AI Browser Agent Security Gap The security company looks to tackle new authentication challenges that could lead to credential leakage, as enterprises increasingly leverage AI browser agents. October 10, 2025 The growth of agentic browsers, which use artificial intelligence agents to perform tasks automatically, is causing new security challenges by creating the potential for credential compromise. To address that concern, 1Password has unveiled a new integration that lets users authenticate their identity without exposing their credentials. While AI browser agents are helpful, they also pose significant authentication security risks. Browser agents may have the same privileges as users, but they are not as aware, which leaves them extra vulnerable to attacks. Agents store credentials and secrets in browser session storage or cookies that are often unencrypted. And the problem deserves attention because attackers have noticed that enterprises conduct more work in the browser. 1Password partnered with Browserbase to launch a new capability, dubbed Secure Agentic Autofill. This feature aims to enable agents to authenticate in the browser without exposing credentials, while keeping a human in the loop. Security Shortcuts Pose Risks Secure Agentic Autofill looks to solve visibility, control, and governance concerns over how AI agents access systems in the enterprise environment, said Nancy Wang, SVP of engineering at 1Password. Users are increasingly integrating AI  agents into the browser to automate tasks like filling out tedious forms, ordering groceries, scheduling an appointment, or booking travel. Additionally, a new generation of agentic browsers—such as Perplexity’s Comet, Opera Neon and the new “reimagined with AI” version of Google—are integrating AI assistants to carry out tasks beyond organizing search results. Related: Philippines Power Election Security With Zero-Knowledge Proofs Using large language models (LLM), agents can navigate the web without any human interaction, but if the task requires login credentials, that means these agents gain access to highly sensitive information. Developers will hardcode secrets directly into code or prompts or store them in unsecured browser sessions to keep agents running smoothly, but those shortcuts pose risks to enterprises, which often lack visibility into what the agents are accessing. Fixing AI Blind Spots Secure Agentic Autofill works to eliminate the risk by keeping credentials out of the AI or LLM context. The integration was developed to address security blind spots in the way agents authenticate today, which prioritizes convenience over security . With so much work done in the browser, navigating different sites and workflows, it's difficult to remember all the passwords required. Users will provide secrets directly into AI-powered browsers, to avoid interruptions caused by agentic browsers waiting for humans to input credentials. Related: NIST Digital Identity Guidelines Evolve With Threat Landscape Though that may reduce user friction, it also exposes credentials to the agent and underlying LLM, increasing the chances of credential theft and leakage, Wang explains. "With 1Password's zero-knowledge security model, credentials are delivered just-in-time through an end-to-end encrypted channel and autofilled through the 1Password browser extension after the request is human-approved," Wang says. Part of the challenge posed by agents is that traditional identity security has not caught up to the AI boom. Authentication systems weren't built for non-human identities acting in the browser; that's why teams hardcode or share credentials in risky ways, warns Wang. "As AI agents take on more workflows, these authentication blind spots become a compliance and governance risk," Wang says. Remaining Concerns While it is a good idea to create another layer of protection, especially when handing off access to any tool, it could cause friction or limit the power of the agentic browser, says Pieter Arntz, malware intelligence researcher at Malwarebytes. These issues could lead to people misusing the technology, he adds. Related: Palo Alto Networks Grabs IAM Provider CyberArk for $25B "My biggest concern with this sort of integration right now is the ease in which cybercriminals are able to trick agentic browsers with prompt injection," Arntz tells Dark Reading. "If criminals could lure agentic browsers to a site and extract important passwords from it through prompt injection, then the ramifications could be terrible." About the Author Arielle Waldman Features Writer , Dark Reading Arielle Waldman is a Boston-based features writer for Dark Reading covering all things cybersecurity. Dark Reading
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 19:22:57 GMT
No specific CVEs or attack techniques detailed in the article. Focus is on vulnerability landscape and consumer device patching challenges. RondoDox is described as a generic exploit botnet, not tied to a specific threat actor or attack chain.
https://www.darkreading.com/endpoint-security/rondodox-botnet-exploit-edge-vulns
[Botnet][Exploit Shotgun][RondoDox][Edge Device Vulnerabilities][Consumer IoT][CVE-2025-XXXX] RondoDox botnet uses a broad, opportunistic exploit approach targeting 56 publicly known vulnerabilities in unpatched consumer edge devices. Its tactics are effective due to lack of device management and patching by end users. 35–40 of these vulnerabilities are in consumer devices with no update practices. This is a good read for threat actors due to large attack surface and low barriers to entry. Impact to audience: medium to large scale, especially in IoT ecosystems.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics RondoDox Botnet: an 'Exploit Shotgun' for Edge Vulns RondoDox Botnet: an 'Exploit Shotgun' for Edge Vulns RondoDox Botnet: an 'Exploit Shotgun' for Edge Vulns RondoDox takes a hit-and-run, shotgun approach to exploiting bugs in consumer edge devices around the world. October 10, 2025 A new botnet is exploiting dozens of known vulnerabilities in hard-to-patch edge devices. " RondoDox " is characteristically unlike most botnets , researchers from Trend Micro said in a report on Thursday. Where others are specially crafted to pick apart select vulnerabilities like a surgeon, RondoDox blasts onto infected devices like Rambo, trying exploit after exploit to see which one sticks. It's boorish but effective, largely because the types of devices it aims at are typically unmonitored, unmanaged, and utterly for the taking. The Exploit Shotgun RondoDox started making the rounds in May, according to Trend Micro. At first, it was exploiting one critical and one high-severity n-day vulnerability in relatively popular digital video recorders (DVR) and routers, respectively. Over the summer, the botnet expanded massively. It now doubles as a loader for the Mirai and Morte Internet-of-Things (IoT) malware families. And it can exploit any one of 56 vulnerabilities in a variety of routers, DVRs, network video recorders (NVRs), Web servers, CCTV systems, and other kinds of networking devices globally. Fifty of those 56 are command injection flaws , allowing for leisurely device manipulation. The key to how RondoDox manages so many vulnerabilities at once is twofold. For one thing, all 56 are publicly known — 38 enough to have warranted Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) numbers. Plus, the malware doesn't spend resources specially customizing each and every infection. Dustin Childs, head of threat awareness for the Zero Day Initiative (ZDI) at Trend Micro, explains that "it's more just throwing stuff at the wall and seeing what sticks. It has its toolbox that it uses, but it's kind of blasting everything that it has at once." Related: Undead Operating Systems Haunt Enterprise Security Networks RondoDox's spread has been as unfocused and opportunistic as its tactics would suggest, reaching across wide geographic regions without bias. The scale of its impact isn't known yet, but Childs suggests that with all evidence considered, "it's potentially quite large." Why Consumer Device Bugs Go Unfixed If RondoDox were to try its shotgun approach on corporate devices, or even personal computers, it would almost certainly run into the kind of trouble it's avoided so far. That might explain why some 35 to 40 of the vulnerabilities it targets are found in consumer-oriented devices. These devices, Childs explains, "in addition to being available and connected to the Internet, are essentially unmanaged devices and they never get updated. The vendors are producing patches, but the consumers aren't really understanding that they need to apply the patches. People buy them and turn them on, get them working, and they never touch them again." Related: Zero Trust: Strengths and Limitations in the AI Attack Era People with jobs, families, and other priorities can't be expected to focus their attention on updates, or even understand how to secure all of their routers, cameras, or other miscellaneous devices. Vendors can pick up the slack by forcing security updates over-the-air (OTA) , but that solution introduces a new set of problems. "I mean, we've all had instances where security patches break things ," Childs points out. "Consumers are afraid of security patches because they have had those negative experiences with them. So if we could get patch quality up to a level where we can trust automatic updates, especially in hardware devices like these, then yes, it should be a matter of just saying: Automatic update, go." Even in that perfect world, though, "the other problem is consumers. You're watching a show with your family and then all of a sudden your router reboots and now your streaming service is gone and you're frustrated. It's difficult to find a time when you can automatically update without inconveniencing the end user," he explains. These considerations and more complicate the patching process, Childs says, "but it can be done. It's just about finding a way to do it that's not inconvenient, and is of quality, which is very difficult." Related: Ray Security Takes an Active Data Security Approach About the Author Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer Nate Nelson is a writer based in New York City. He formerly worked as a reporter at Threatpost, and wrote "Malicious Life," an award-winning Top 20 tech podcast on Apple and Spotify. Outside of Dark Reading, he also co-hosts "The Industrial Security Podcast." Dark Reading
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 18:14:25 GMT
Article discusses ransomware trends in manufacturing, emphasizing AI use, patch management failures, and supply chain risks. No specific CVEs or IOCs provided. Focuses on threat landscape and mitigation strategies.
https://www.darkreading.com/ics-ot-security/ransomware-manufacturing-an-escalating-battle
[Ransomware][Manufacturing Sector][AI-Driven Attacks][Critical Infrastructure Target][CISA KEV][Patch Management Failure] This article highlights the growing threat of ransomware targeting manufacturing industries, driven by AI-enhanced attack tactics and critical supply chain dependencies. Manufacturing remains the top target (22% of attacks), with 65% of incidents in Q2 2025. Seventy-five percent of manufacturers have critical vulnerabilities, and 65% have actively exploited CISA KEVs. Threat actors exploit operational continuity needs and financial pressure to secure ransoms. A good read for threat actors due to high financial impact and targeting patterns. 1B+ ransomware potential in industrial sector.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Cybersecurity In-Depth: Digging into data about the latest attacks, threats, and trends using charts and tables. Cybersecurity In-Depth: Digging into data about the latest attacks, threats, and trends using charts and tables. The Fight Against Ransomware Heats Up on the Factory Floor The Fight Against Ransomware Heats Up on the Factory Floor The Fight Against Ransomware Heats Up on the Factory Floor Ransomware gangs continue to set their sights on the manufacturing industry, but companies are taking steps to protect themselves, starting with implementing timely patch management protocols. October 10, 2025 Ransomware groups come and go, but one constant is that manufacturing remains a top target. The ransomware landscape is ever-evolving. New groups emerge and old ones dismantle or rebrand. Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) launched and lowered the barrier to entry. Even the name "ransomware" doesn't always apply now, as some groups rely solely on data extortion threats over encryption to pressure victims into paying. And, of course, attackers are increasingly using artificial intelligence (AI). The manufacturing industry continues to take the brunt of ransomware attacks. Black Kite's "2025 Manufacturing Research Report" found that manufacturing was the No. 1 target for ransomware groups four years in a row. The sector accounted for 22% of all reported attacks between April 2024 and March 2025, 1,314 attacks out of a total of 6,046, according to the report. While researchers discovered that newer ransomware groups favored smaller companies, large manufacturing enterprises were still highly targeted. "Cybercriminals are not attacking indiscriminately; they are deliberately targeting this industry because they know its operational continuity is critical and any disruption can cause a cascading effect through global supply chains," the Black Kite report states. Related: Bombarding Cars With Lasers: Novel Auto Cyberattacks Emerge Additional reports echoed the same concerns. Dragos' " Industrial Ransomware Analysis: Q2 2025 " says that manufacturing continued to be the most impacted sector, accounting for 65% of incidents recorded in Q2. BitSight's " State of the Underground 2025 " reveals that the manufacturing sector was the most targeted for the third year in a row. Security Gaps Make an Attractive Target Threats to critical infrastructure are at all-time high, and the manufacturing industry is no exception, says Sarah Cleveland, senior director of federal strategy at ExtraHop. Manufacturing environments have massive attack surfaces thanks to global supply chains, remote access requirements, and the convergence of IT and operational technology (OT). They are uniquely difficult to secure because they often combine decades-old OT with modern IT and Internet of Things (IoT) systems, and many production systems were not designed with cybersecurity in mind, Cleveland explains. "Attacks across the board are hiding in encrypted channels and legitimate protocols to move unnoticed, laterally across the network, then remain dormant — waiting for the right time to strike," Cleveland tells Dark Reading. These security gaps make manufacturing an attractive target for ransomware gangs, and emerging AI advances could worsen the problem. Related: Cyberattack Leads to Beer Shortage as Asahi Recovers "Just as we are using AI to automate and accelerate workflows, attackers are using AI to improve their success rates by being able to quickly adjust their tactics to include sophisticated double extortion, exfiltration, and disabling endpoint defenses to prolong their presence before encryption," she says. "Ransomware threat actors will continue to find manufacturing an especially profitable target." Disruption Means Payday for Attackers Manufacturing plays a critical role in global supply chains, states Ekrem Selcuk Celik, threat researcher at Black Kite. Unplanned downtime in manufacturing can lead to substantial financial losses and supply chain shortages. Recent attacks, like the one against Asahi Breweries, highlights how disruptive ransomware is for the industry — and how ransomware groups rely on disruption to elicit payments. Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) also suffered a recent cyberattack , which erupted into a month-long disruption. While JLR did not confirm it was caused by ransomware, Xcape board member Damon Small says the attack smacks of ransomware. "Volumes have been impacted since the start of September by the recent cyber incident, with production stoppages impacting wholesales," he says, pointing to the company's Q2 fiscal 2026 report . Related: Undocumented Radios Found in Solar-Powered Devices Threat actors love money and hate long negotiations, so they look for victims who can pay fast, says Celik. Enter: manufacturing. "Many companies, facing not only production and data loss but also the risk of becoming the source of a third-party breach, choose to pay rather than fight," Celik says. "Every second of downtime equals financial loss, and attackers know it." When selecting a target, threat groups may attempt to determine the company's willingness to pay a ransom based on factors like potential lost revenue, says Scott Walsh, principal security researcher at Coalition. The insurer's " 2025 Cyber Claims Report " found that businesses in the industrial sector experienced a 4% year-over-year increase in claims frequency in 2024. "For some organizations, it may be more cost-effective to pay the ransom than suffer the business interruption, and threat actors are aware of this," Walsh tells Dark Reading. Is Manufacturing Inherently Insecure? Like other experts, Walsh agrees that manufacturers are key targets given their criticality to the supply chain. However, rather than systems being inherently difficult to secure, security is held back by a manufacturing model that calls for consistency and incentives that reward keeping the core business operating, he says. A static production line will be at odds with cybersecurity, but new vulnerabilities are constantly being discovered and need to be remediated, Walsh explains. "When a producer doesn't patch a vulnerability, they're trading a small amount of downtime to apply patches for a much larger potential future disruption due to a cyberattack," he says. Black Kite's recent report points to patch management as the weakest link. The way manufacturing environments are designed makes it difficult to patch or segment without disrupting operations, which manufacturers can't afford, particularly if the company is related to food production or logistics, which could affect national security. However, every unpatched system and outdated server becomes an open invitation to threat actors, Celik warns. "Seventy-five percent of manufacturers have critical vulnerabilities, and 65% have at least one CISA KEV [Known Exploited Vulnerability] actively exploited today, not tomorrow," Celik says. "Fixing patch management must be the first priority." 'The Trend Will Continue' In addition to timely patch management protocols, Cleveland urges manufacturers to prioritize network visibility across both IT and OT environments, beginning with strong network segmentation and rapid detection of lateral movement. "Multifactor authentication, least-privilege access, and adherence to zero-trust principles are also essential to reduce insider and external threats, especially across the full supply chain if a partner or vendor is breached," she recommends. Proactive third-party risk management is also vital to combat growing threats against manufacturers. Every day, new and smaller ransomware groups emerge, spending all their time looking for one weak link in the chain to break, Celik says. "Until these gaps are closed across entire supply chains," he says, "the trend will continue." About the Author Arielle Waldman Features Writer , Dark Reading Arielle Waldman is a Boston-based features writer for Dark Reading covering all things cybersecurity. Dark Reading
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 16:38:25 GMT
Salesforce platform not compromised. BreachForums domain seized; Tor site still accessible. Group claims active extortion and sample data availability. No known CVEs reported.
https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/shinyhunters-feds-shutter-salesforce-extortion-site
[Ransomware][Extortion][Salesforce][Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters][CVE-None] A high-profile extortion campaign by Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters (a fusion of Scattered Spider, Lapsus$, and ShinyHunters) targeting Salesforce customers. The group claims 1 billion records and victims including Disney, Google, and Toyota, with ransom demands until Oct 10, 2025. BreachForums domain seized by FBI and French law enforcement; Tor site remains active. Salesforce denies platform compromise. This is a high-impact read for threat actors due to active extortion and broad victim list. Threat actors may use this as a blueprint for similar attacks.
breachforums#fbi.gov, breachforums.ic3.gov
Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters:USA/France
Remote Access, Data Exfiltration, Ransomware Extortion
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Feds Shutter ShinyHunters Salesforce Extortion Site Feds Shutter ShinyHunters Salesforce Extortion Site Feds Shutter ShinyHunters Salesforce Extortion Site The group warned that law-enforcement crackdowns are imminent in the wake of the takedown, but its extortion threats against Salesforce victims remain active. October 10, 2025 NEWS BRIEF Last night, the FBI, in coordination with law enforcement in France, seized the latest version of the BreachForums’ underground forum domain , which was converted earlier this month into an extortion site used by Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters, the gang behind the recent high-profile spate of Salesforce data heists. Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters is an apparent combination of the Scattered Spider, Lapsus$, and ShinyHunters cybercriminal groups that first emerged this past summer. It has been busy compromising Salesforce data , and claims that Salesforce victims have up until midnight Eastern Time today, Oct. 10, to meet its ransom demands before it will start publishing the stolen records. Despite the BreachForums site being taken down, the group's Tor Dark Web site is still accessible, and will be used to leak the data, the threat actors claimed. Aside from Salesforce data, Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters claims to have 1 billion records and 39 victim organizations listed on the site with sample data, such as Chanel, Disney and Hulu, Marriot, Google, Toyota, FedEx, and many more. For its part, Salesforce has issued its own statement , acknowledging the extortion attempts and reiterating that there is no indication that the Salesforce platform itself had been compromised. BreachForums Underground Forum Closes for Good? Visitors to the BreachForums site will now find only a seizure notice with US and French law enforcement logos on display, with links to breachforums#fbi.gov and breachforums.ic3.gov. According to the cybercriminal group, the authorities also compromised BreachForums database backups, which date back to 2023, alongside the escrow databases; and the back-end server were seized and destroyed. In a message the group put out, it noted that no members have been arrested, but that the "era of forums" is over. "Over the years, BreachForums has undergone significant turbulence," said the group in its message, according to reports. "To my count this is the 4th time, including RaidForums seizure that the FBI has took action, consistently. We are not fighting this war anymore, this is officially the end." As for now, ShinyHunters has no plans to launch another iteration of BreachForums and stated that, should it ever reemerge, it should be considered a "honeypot." It added, "For your own safety, security, and sanity keep your opsec in check," it said. "I have no doubt the FBI and other international partners involved will be cracking down on many individuals in the next coming few weeks to months."
