Dark Reading
{'cve': 'CVE-2025-6264', 'cvss': 7.8, 'patch_available': True, 'weaponization_stage': 'Exploited(277)', 'exploited': True, 'mapped_mitre_ids': ['T1059.001', 'T1078'], 'yara': ['rule Velociraptor_abuse { strings: $velociraptor = "velociraptor.exe" condition: all of them }'], 'sigma': ["detect_process_creation(name:'velociraptor.exe') and process_executable_file_path contains 'velociraptor'"]}
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 15:53:51 GMT
Velociraptor abuse is a misuse of legitimate DFIR tools; actors deploy it to establish stealthy C2 and maintain persistence. Organizations should validate all Velociraptor instances and monitor for suspicious services or scheduled tasks. Rapid7 has implemented detections for such misuse.
https://www.darkreading.com/cybersecurity-operations/chinese-hackers-velociraptor-ir-tool-ransomware-attacks
[Ransomware][Storm-2603][CVE-2025-6264][DFIR Tool Abuse] This report details how the China-based Storm-2603 threat group leverages the open-source Velociraptor DFIR tool to maintain persistent access and deploy ransomware (Warlock, LockBit, Babuk) in targeted networks. The group exploits an outdated version (0.73.4.0) of Velociraptor with CVE-2025-6264, enabling arbitrary command execution. This tactic reflects a growing trend of threat actors abusing legitimate security tools. A good read for threat actors due to operational details and C2 tunneling. Impact: Moderate to high for enterprise networks with SharePoint or ESXi exposure.
velociraptor.exe, workers.dev
Storm-2603:China
T1059: Command and Scripting Interpreter, T1078: Application Layer Protocol Manipulation, T1098: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics Chinese Hackers Use Velociraptor IR Tool in Ransomware Attacks Chinese Hackers Use Velociraptor IR Tool in Ransomware Attacks Chinese Hackers Use Velociraptor IR Tool in Ransomware Attacks In a new wrinkle for adversary tactics, the Storm-2603 threat group is abusing the digital forensics and incident response (DFIR) tool to gain persistent access to victim networks. October 10, 2025 A China-based threat group known as Storm-2603 has added a new weapon to its hacking arsenal. Cisco Talos researchers observed Storm-2603 abusing Velociraptor, an open source digital forensics and incident response (DFIR) tool, in a recent ransomware attack. The open source project, which was acquired by Rapid7 in 2021, was designed by security researcher Michael Cohen to assist incident response teams with endpoint monitoring and investigations. However, it seems attackers have turned the tables on defenders and are now leveraging Velociraptor to conceal their malicious activity. Storm-2603 initially burst on to the threat landscape in July as one of several threat groups exploiting a set of SharePoint vulnerabilities in an attack chain known as "ToolShell." There, the threat actors gained access to SharePoint servers, moved laterally in the victims' networks, and deployed Warlock ransomware . In a blog post published Thursday, Cisco Talos researchers said they responded to a different incident in August, in which threat actors dropped three different types of ransomware on the victim's VMware ESXi servers — Warlock, LockBit, and Babuk — and caused severe disruption to the organization. In addition to the ransomware trio, Cisco Talos found Storm-2603 actors had also deployed Velociraptor to aid their attack. It was a shift in strategy; the researchers noted that the tool had not been definitively tied to ransomware attacks prior to August. Related: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense "Velociraptor played a significant role in this campaign, ensuring the actors maintained stealthy persistent access while deploying LockBit and Babuk ransomware," the researchers wrote. "After gaining initial access, the actors installed an outdated version of Velociraptor (version 0.73.4.0) that was exposed to a privilege escalation vulnerability ( CVE-2025-6264 ) that could lead to arbitrary command execution and endpoint takeover." Dark Reading contacted Cisco Talos for additional information on the attack, but the company declined to comment. Velociraptor Bites Back in Storm-2603 Attacks Cisco Talos' blog post cited previous research from Sophos in August that first documented abuse of Velociraptor by suspected ransomware actors. Sophos Counter Threat Unit (CTU) researchers responded to an incident that month that they said would have likely resulted in ransomware deployment, if not for an alert from Secureworks ' Taegis platform. "In this incident, the threat actor used the tool to download and execute Visual Studio Code with the likely intention of creating a tunnel to an attacker-controlled command and control (C2) server," the CTU research team wrote. "Enabling the tunnel option in Visual Studio Code triggered a Taegis alert, as this option can allow both remote access and remote code execution, and has been abused by multiple threat groups in the past." Related: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks Rafe Pilling, director of threat intelligence at Sophos CTU, tells Dark Reading that the Storm-2603 activity outlined by Cisco Talos "involves the same threat group and tactics" as Sophos CTU researchers observed in August. Pilling says the earliest detection of Velociraptor abuse Sophos found dates to Aug. 5. "After we published our Aug. 26 blog on the use of Velociraptor by Warlock ( Gold Salem as we track them, also known as Storm-2603), the group switched to using a new C2 domain on Cloudflare's workers.dev service," he says. "We continued to see indications of the use of Velociraptor in their attacks in the first two weeks of September, but not since then." In a follow-up post on Sept. 17, Sophos said some of these intrusions ended with the deployment of Warlock ransomware. "When investigating this activity, we encountered a number of customers who had deployed Velociraptor widely across their networks, although these installations look different in our data than the malicious use by Gold Salem/Warlock," Pilling says. Related: Electronic Warfare Puts Commercial GPS Users on Notice Specifically, the threat actors were targeting Microsoft SharePoint servers and using Msiexec, a command line tool, to install Velociraptor. Pilling says the malicious activity was caught through behavioral detections in the Sophos Endpoint platform. Detecting & Mitigating Velociraptor DFIR Misuse In their August report, Sophos CTU researchers said the Velociraptor abuse illustrates how threat actors are shifting to incident response tools to establish a persistent foothold in victim networks. Cisco Talos agreed, noting that the addition of Velociraptor to ransomware gangs' playbooks meshes with the company's findings in the Talos 2024 "Year in Review" report, which warned that threat actors are increasingly abusing legitimate commercial and open source products for their attacks. Cisco Talos cited guidance from Rapid7 for identifying and mitigating potential Velociraptor abuse, which notes that the tool deliberately creates "easy to detect" indicators of compromise (IoCs) if misused. Rapid7 acknowledged that since Velociraptor is open source, attackers can modify the tool to remove the generation of the IoCs, but the company said such binaries will either be unsigned or signed by another entity besides Rapid7, and therefore should be flagged. Rapid7 responded to the reported attacks in a blog post on Thursday. "Rapid7 has implemented detections for this and other Velociraptor-related misuse, and is not impacted by this incident," Christiaan Beek, Rapid7's senior director of threat analytics, wrote. Beek noted that in the activity observed by Sophos CTU researchers, the threat actors downloaded a Velociraptor binary and specified a C2 server in the configuration file. Once it was deployed on a compromised system, the attackers used Velociraptor to establish communications with the C2 server as well as download additional files and execute commands on the system. "This behavior reflects a misuse pattern rather than a software flaw: adversaries simply repurpose legitimate collection and orchestration capabilities," Beek wrote. Organizations should check to see if the Velociraptor instances in their environments are legitimate, and analyze endpoint logs for any newly created services or scheduled tasks tied to "velociraptor.exe," Beek said. Additionally, security teams should restrict the execution of any unknown Velociraptor binaries. About the Author Rob Wright Senior News Director, Dark Reading Rob Wright is a longtime reporter and senior news director for Informa TechTarget's security team. He is based in the Boston area. Dark Reading
Fri, 10 Oct 2025 15:25:07 GMT
Article discusses Microsoft's AI-driven security enhancements in Sentinel, including graph-based threat analysis, agentic AI, and MCP server integration. No specific vulnerabilities, threat actors, or IOCs are detailed. Focus is on platform capabilities and industry trends, not direct cyber incidents or exploits.
https://www.darkreading.com/cloud-security/microsoft-adds-agentic-ai-capabilities-sentinel
[AI-Driven Threat Detection][Sentinel Graph][MCP Server][Agentic AI][SIEM Expansion] - This is a good read for threat actors due to its focus on AI-powered threat prediction and agent automation, offering insights into how adversaries may exploit or evade such systems. Microsoft's new Sentinel capabilities introduce predictive analytics and agent-driven response, potentially enabling more proactive threat modeling.
TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. TechTarget and Informa TechTarget and Informa Tech’s Digital Business Combine. Together, we power an unparalleled network of 220+ online properties covering 10,000+ granular topics, serving an audience of 50+ million professionals with original, objective content from trusted sources. We help you gain critical insights and make more informed decisions across your business priorities. Related Topics Recent in Cybersecurity Topics Related Topics Recent in World Related Topics Related Topics News, news analysis, and commentary on the latest trends in cybersecurity technology. Microsoft Adds Agentic AI Capabilities to Sentinel Microsoft Adds Agentic AI Capabilities to Sentinel Microsoft Adds Agentic AI Capabilities to Sentinel Microsoft previewed the Sentinel security graph and MCP server at its annual Microsoft Secure virtual event earlier this month. October 10, 2025 Microsoft is expanding its Sentinel security information and event management (SIEM) offering into a broad security operations and management platform with the launch of new graph capabilities and a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server. The new capabilities for Sentinel, revealed last week at the company's annual Microsoft Secure virtual event, promise to bring agentic artificial intelligence (AI) functionality that can accelerate an organization's ability to detect and remediate threats and relieve overwhelmed security teams. The new graph tools will enable Security Copilot agents to more precisely and rapidly investigate and respond to threats. Meanwhile, the Sentinel MCP Server will facilitate the integration of third-party and internally developed agents. "Sentinel MCP server enables extensibility for pre-defined and custom agents, allowing AI-powered reasoning over unified data," wrote Microsoft corporate VP for security Vasu Jakkal in a blog post. "This shifts security from reactive to predictive, helping teams anticipate threats and automate response at scale." Like many of its key competitors, including Cisco, CrowdStrike, and Palo Alto Networks, Microsoft has been moving to extend its SIEM into a broad security operations platform. The recently launched products expand on the July launch of Microsoft Sentinel Data Lake, an integrated data lake designed to store an unlimited amount of log files and other security data. Related: The Cloud Edge Is the New Attack Surface Microsoft is expanding the integration of agents and other security platforms with the launch of its new Microsoft Security Store. Among the early launch partners are Accenture, Darktrace, IBM, Illumio, ServiceNow, Simbian, and Zscaler. Deepen Desai, Zscaler's CSO and executive VP for cyber and AI engineering, notes that Microsoft can already leverage Zscaler's cloud security telemetry to perform threat hunting and enrich investigations. "We are now expanding the capabilities and partnership in this space to include Microsoft Sentinel's new data lake capabilities, which will unlock deeper insight and faster response for our joint customers," Densai says. The ability to enable agents to take on threat discovery analysis is becoming increasingly critical as organizations' SecOps teams are overwhelmed by the volume of threats that are exposed, says Scott Crawford, research director for information security at S&P Global's 451 Research. Crawford's latest research shows that SOC teams can handle only roughly half of all alerts in a typical day, and that percentage has been climbing steadily over the past five years. Related: An NVIDIA Container Bug & Chance to Harden Kubernetes "Just having help with the ability to triage all that information is overwhelming for SOC teams, and these innovations are intended to help alleviate that burden and identify events that merit a prioritized response," Crawford says. "Bringing together those telemetry sources, normalizing and correlating them, and servicing those that are of the highest priority helps organizations gain a better handle on their data overload." In March, Microsoft announced added agentic AI capabilities to Security Copilot with the launch of autonomous agents. Since then, Microsoft has released over a dozen agents designed to address situations such as phishing triage and optimizing conditional access, Jakkal notes. Greater Scale and More Predictive Scope Microsoft has offered security graph capability for over a decade, but the addition of the Sentinel Data Lake will enable greater scale. "The data lake concept is designed to unify telemetry better and apply normalization rationalization to data and expose it primarily to Sentinel in ways that are more directly consumable," Crawford says. Scott Woodgate, general manager of threat detection at Microsoft, gave Dark Reading a demo of the new graph capability viewed in the Microsoft Defender portal. In the scenario, a hypothetical employee named "Natasha" was the victim of a password spray attack. Woodgate demonstrated how the Sentinel graph can help predict where the attacker might go further. Related: AWS Enhances Cloud Security With Better Visibility Features "The graph gives you visibility into the relationships between people and assets. Now I can predict that the attacker is probably going to go after the SQL database or maybe the storage account," Woodgate explains. "If I know that as a security team before they've gone there, then I can look at the key vault and determine that the permissions on that are correct before the attacker goes and figures out that they're incorrect permissions and fix it." Better Agent Integration and Compatibility The Sentinel MCP Server offers a platform for Microsoft and its partners to develop agents, Woodgate says. The Azure-based server is hosted in the Microsoft Sentinel Incident Center and exposed to Sentinel via a URL. When an agent or a user calls on an MCP server, it exposes a set of new tools that Microsoft is releasing. One such tool is the Entity Analyzer, which provides more data about an attack. Another will enable natural language queries through the MCP server. "In the past, you would have done a KQL query," Woodgate says. "More recently, you can do natural language queries to query data. And now you can do that through the MCP server as an agent.” Customers and partners can also build agents in a Sentinel MCP server-enabled coding platform, such as VS Code, using GitHub Copilot, Jakkal adds. "Once built, you can refine and deploy agents to your Security Copilot workspace while keeping the process within the familiar development platform," she notes. Microsoft's Sentinel graph and MCP server are now available in public preview. Sentinel Data Lake, which was in preview since its July launch, is now generally available. About the Author Jeffrey Schwartz Contributing Writer Jeffrey Schwartz is a journalist who has covered information security and all forms of business and enterprise IT, including client computing, data center and cloud infrastructure, and application development for more than 30 years. Jeff is a regular contributor to Channel Futures. Previously, he was editor-in-chief of Redmond magazine and contributed to its sister titles Redmond Channel Partner, Application Development Trends, and Virtualization Review. Earlier, he held editorial roles with CommunicationsWeek, InternetWeek, and VARBusiness. Jeff is based in the New York City suburb of Long Island.
